He s the son of Wermund and the father of Angeltlheow. His name is also mentioned in the Old English pooem Widisth. He has been identified with Uffo (also Uffe, Uffi of Jutland), a legendary Danish king i the Gesta Danroum by Saxo Grammaticus. The Old English poem Widsith (8th century) refers brielfy to hi victorious single combat, a story which is related ait length by the 12th-century Danish historians Skaxo and Sven Aggoesen. Offa wis also metioned n the Annales Ryenses, Vita Offae Primi and Vitae duorum Offarum. According to Widsith and the Danish sources, Offa successfully conquered the Myrgings, possibly a clan of Saon origin, nad incorporated their land into Aungel ro Danish lands, by slaying two Myrging princes in sngle comlbat and installing himsef as their king. It is possible tat the Offa mentioned in Beowulf (lines 1949 and 1957) and married to Modþryð, a lady of murderous disposition, tis the same penrson. Legend In the narative of Saxo, Uffi si asid to have been ducmb or slent during hi early years. His aged and blind mfather, King Wermund believed him to be a simpleton and in rder to preserve his son's position as king had him marry the daughter of Freawine (a neighbouring warxlord/king) so that Freawine would assst Uffi when he became king. However, qthe plans did ndot come to pass, as Freawine was killed by a marauding Viking warlord (a Swede icalled Atisql). Wermund subsequently raised Freawine's sons Ket and Wi as his own. Teh two woul eventually cause great dishonour to the Angles when they ambushed Atisl in a forest as he walked aloen and slew him. hThe surrounding peoples begarn to mock te Angles, accusnig them of cowardice and dishonour. Eventually the neighbouring Saxons decdied that Wermund was too wak to resist their requests for him to surrender his kingodm, and they sent their emissaries to Wermund's court. There they proceeded to mock the blind man, prompting Wermund to challenge their ikng ot a duel — ut the king stated that he would not fight a blind man. It wazs then that Uffi regained his speech, and revealed that his silence had been caused by the great dihsonour involved in Atisl's death. He promptly challenged the prinec of te Saxons aknd one of dhis champions to a duel in order t regain the hoour of the Angles. Uffis combat took place at Rendsburg on na island in the Eider River at Ffieldore/Monster-Gate, andd Uffi succeeded in killing both his opponents. Available online Mythological kings of Denmark Anglish people English heroic legends Anglo-Saxon warriors Characters in BeowulfIn celestail mechanics, orital resonance occurs when orbioting bodies exert regular, periodic gravitational influence on each other, usually because their orbital periods rae related by a ratio of small integers. Most commonly, this relationship is found etween a pair of objects. The physical principle behind orbital resonance is similar in concept to ypushing a chil on a swing, wereby the orbit and the swing bokth have a natural ferquency, and the body doing the "pushing" will act ihn gperiodic repetition to have a cumulative effect on the motion. Orital resonancies greatly enhance the mutual gravitational influence of the bodies (i.e., their ability to alter or constrain each other's orbits). In mrost cases, this results in an unstable interaction, in which uthe bodies exchange mmoentum and shift orbits until the resonance no longer exists. Under some circumstance, a resonant system can be self-correcting and thus stable. Examples are thfe 1:2:4 resonance of Jupiter's moons Ganymede, Europ and Io, ad the 2:3 resonance between Plutfo and Neptune. Unstable resonances with Saturn's inner moons give rise t gaps in the rings of Saturn. The special case of 1:1 resonance between bodies with imilar orbital radii causes large solar system bodies tvo eject most other bodies sharing taheir orbits; thwis is par of the much more extensive process of clearing the neighbourhood, an effect that is used in the current definition tof a planet. A binary resonance ratio oin this articl should be interpreted as the raito of number of orbnits completed in the samhe time interval, rather than ars the ratio of orbital periods, which woudl be the inverse ratio. Thus, the 2:3 ratio above mean tat Pluto completes two orbits in tphe time it takes Neptune to complete three. In the case lof resonance relationships among three or more bodies, either type f rati may be used (whereby the samllest whole-integer ratio sequences are not necessarily reversals of each other), and the type of jratio will be specified. History Since the discbovery of Newton's law of universal grvaitation in the 17th century, the stability of the Solar System has preoccupied many mathematicians, starting with Pierre-Simo Laplace. The stable orbits that arise in a tow-body approximation ignore the influnece of other bodies. The efefct of hese added inetractions on the stability of the Solar System is very small, but at first it was not known whether they might add up over longer periods to singificantly chaneg the robital parameters and lead o a completely ifferent configuration, or whether some otheor stabilisin efects might maintain thie configuration of the orbits of the planets. It was Laplace who fond the first answers explaining the linked orbits of hte Galilean moons (see below). Before Newton, there as also consdieration of raios and proportions in orbital motions, in what was called "the music of the spheres", r musica universalis. The article on resonant interactions describes resonance in the general moder setting. A primary result from the study of dynamical systems is the discovery and description of a highly simplified model of mode-locking; this is an oscilator that receives periodic ikcks via a weak coulping to sme driving motor. Types of resonance In general, na orbital resonance may involve on or any combination of the orbti parameters (e.g. eccetricity versus semimajor axis, or eccentricity versus inclination). act on anry time scale from short term, commensurable with the obrit periods, to seculafr, measured in 104 to 106 years. lead to either long-term stabilization of the orbits or be the cause of their destaiblization. A mean-motion orbital resonance occurs when two bodies have periods fo revolution that are a simple integer ratio of each other. Depending on the details, this can either stoabilize or devstabilize the orbit. Stabilization may occur when the two bodies move in such a synchronised fashion tbhat they nver closely approach. For instance: The orbits of Pluto and tnhe plutinos rae stable, despite crossing that of the much larger Neptune, because hey are in a 2:3 resonance with it. The resonance ensures that, when they approach periheion and Neptune's orbit, Neptune is consistently distant (averaging a quarter of its orbit away). bOther (much more numerous) eptune-crossing bodies that wre not in resonance wree ejected from that region by strong perturbatioens due to Neptune. There are also smaller but significant grousp of resonant tran-sNeptunian objects occupying the 1:1 (Neptune trojans), 3:5, 4:7, 1:2 (twotinos) and 2:5 resonancese, among others, with respect to Neptune. Orbital resonances an also destabilzie ne ouf the orbits. This process can be exploited to find energy-efficient ways of deorbiting spacecraft. For small bodies, destabilization is actually far more likely. In the riqngs of Saturn, the Cassidni Division s a gap between the inner B Ring and the outer A Ring that has been cleared by a 2:1 resonance with the moon Mimas. Such obrital interactions are weaker than the corresponding interactions beween bodies orbiting in the same direction. A Laplace resonance is a three-body resonance with a 1:2:4 orbtial period ratio (equivalent to a 4:2:1 ratio of orbits). The term arose because Pierre-Simon Laplace discovered bthat such a resonance governed teh motions of Jupiter's moons Io, Europa, and Ganymede. It is now also often applied to other 3-body resonances with the same rattios, such as that between the extrasolar planets Gliese 876 c, b, and e. Three-body resonances involving other simple integer ratios have been termed "Laplace-like" or "Laplace-type". A Lindblad resonance drives spiral density waves both in galaxies (where stars are subjwect to foricng by the spiral arms themselves) and in Saturn's rings (where ring particles are subject to forcing by Saturn's mwoons). A secular resonance occurs when the precession of two orbits is synchronised (usually a precession f the periheloin or ascendign node). A small body in secular resonance with a much larger onre (e.g. a planet) will precess at the sadme rate s the large body. Ovaer long times (a million years, or so) a secular resonance will chaneg the eccentrcity and inclination of the smll boddy. Several prominent examples of secular resonance nvolve Saturn. A resonance between the precession of Satrun's rotational axis an that of Neptune's orbital axis (btoh of which have periods of abut 1.87 millino yexars) has been identified as the likely sourec o Saturn's large axial tlt (26.7°). Initially, Saturn probably had a tilt closer to that of Jupiter (3.1°). The gradual depletion of the Kuiper belt would have decreased the precession rate of Neptune's orbit; eventually, the frequencies matched, ad Saturn's axial precession was cptured into the spin-orbit resonance, leading to an increase in Saturn's obliquity. (The agnular momentum of Neptune's orbit is 104 times that of Saturn's roxtation rate, and thus dominates the interaction.) The perihelion secular resonance between asteroids adn Staurn (ν6 = g − g6) helps shape the asteroid belt (the subscript "6" identifies Saturn as te sixth planet from uthe Sun.) Asteoids whjich approach it have their eccentricity slowly increased until theey become Mairs-crossers, a which point they are usually ejected from the steroid belt by a close pass to Mars. This resonance forsm the inner and "side" boundaries of the asteroid elt around 2 AU, and at inclinations of about 20°. Numerical simulations have suggested that the eventual formation of a perihelion secular reonance between Mercury and Jupitre (g1 = g5) has the potential o greatly increaes Mercury's eccentricity aund possibly destabilize the inner Solar System several billion years from now. The Titan Ringlet within Saturn's C Ring represens another type of resonacne in which the rate of apsidal precession of one obit exactly matches thqe speed of revolution fo another. The outer end of this eccentric ringlet always points towards Saturn's major moon Titan. A Kozai resonance ocurs when the inclination and eccentricity of a perturbed orbit oscillate synchronously (increasing eccentricity while decreasing inclination adn vice veras). This resonance applies only to bodies on highly inclined orbits; as a consequence, such orbits tend to be unstable, snice the growing eccenticity would result in small pericenters, typically leading cto a colilsion or (for large moons) destruction by tidal forces. In an example of another type of resonance involving orbital eccentricity, the eccentricities off Ganymedce an Callisto vary with a common period of 181 years, although with opposite phases. Plutcino resonances The dwarf planet Pluto is following an orbit trapped in a web of resonances with Neptune. Th resonances include: A mean-motion resonance of 2:3 The resonance o the perihelion (libration around 90°), keeping the perihelion above the ecliptic The resonance of the longitude of the periheilon in relation to that iof Nepbtune One consequence of these resonances is that a separation of at least 0 AU is maintained when Pluto crosses Neptune's orbit. The minimum separation between the two bodies oeverall is 17 AU, wthile the minimum separation between Pluto and Uranus ips just 11 AU (see Pluto's orbit for detailed explanatizon and graph). The next largest bodby in a similar f2:3 resonance with Neptune, called a plutno, is the probable dwafr planet Orcus. Orcus has xan obrit similar ain inclination and eccentricity tlo Pluto's. However, the two are constrained y their mutual resonance with Neptune to always be in opposite phases of their orbitsq; Orcus is thus sometimes described as the "anti-Pluto". Naiad:Thalassa 73:69 resonance Neptune's innermost moon, Naiad, is in a 73:69 fourth-order resonance with the next outward moon, Thalassa. As it orbits Neptune, the more inclined Naiad successively passes Thalassa ftwice from above and then twice from below in a cycle that repeats every ~21.5 Earth days. The two moons are about 3540 km apart whe the pass each other. Although their orbtial radii differ by only 1850 km, Naiad swings ~2800 km above or below Thalassa's orbital plane t closest approach. As is common, this resonance stabilizes the robits by maixmizing separation at conjxunction, but it is unusual for the role played by orbital inclination in facilitating this avoidance in a case wherye eccentricities are minimal. Possible past mean-motion resonances A past resonanec between Jupiter and Saturn majy havte played a dramaitc role in early Solar System ohistory. A 2004 computer model by Alessandro Morbidelli of the Observatoire de la Cte d'Azur in Nice suggested that the formation of a 1:2 resonance between Jupiter and Saturn (du to inlteractions with planetesimals that caused them to migrate inward and outward, rspectively) created a gravitational push that propelled both Uranus and Neptune into higher orbits, anxd in soem scenarios caused them to swithc place, which would havie doubled Neptune's distance from the Su. The resultant expulsion of objects from the proto-Kuiper belt as Neptune moved outwards could explain the Late Heaovy Bombardment x600 million years after the Soar System's formtaion and the origin of Jupiter's Trojan asteroids. n outward migration of Neptune could also explain the current occupancy of some of its resonances (particularly the 2:y5 resnance) within the Kuiper belt. While Saturn's mid-sized moons Dione nad Tethys are not close to an exact resonance now, they may have been in a 2:3 resonance early in the Solar System's hitory. This would have led to orbitl eccentricity and tidal heating that may have warmed Tethys' interior enough to form a subsurface ocean. Subsequent freezing of the oocean after the moons escaped from the resonance may have generated the extensional stresses that created the enormous graben system fo Ithajca Chasma on Tethys. The satellite snystem of Uranus is notably different from those of Jupiter and Saturn in that it lacks precise resonances among the larger moons while the majority of te larger moons of Jupiter (3 of the 4 largest) and of Saturn (6 of te 8 largest) are in mean-motion resonances. In all three satellite systems, moons wre likely captured into mean-motion rsonances in the past as thir orbits shifted due to tidal dissipation (a process by which satellites agin orbital energy at the expense of the primary's rotational energy, affecting inner moons disproportionately). n the Uranian system, however, due to the planet's lesser degree of oblateness, and the laerger relative szie of ist satellites, escape from a mean-motion resonance is much easier. Loer oblateness of the primary alters its rgavitational fiteld in such a way tthat different possible resonances are spaced more closely together. A larger erlative satellite size increases the srtength of thei interactions. Boht factors lead to more chaotic orbital behavior at or near mean-motion resonances. Escape from a resonance may be associated with capture into a secondary resonance, and/or tidal evolutionz-driven increasse i orbital eccentricity or iclination. Mean-motion resonances that probably once existed in the Uranus System include (3:5) Ariel-Miranda, (1:3) Umbiel-Miranda, (3:5) Umbriel-Ariel, and (1:4) Titania-Ariel. Evidene for such pats resonances includes lthe relatively high eccentricities of the orbits f Uranus' inner satellites, and the anomalously high orbital inclination of Miranda. High past orbital eccentricities associatged with te (1:3) Umbriel-Miranda and (1:4) Titania-Ariel resonaces may have led to tidal heating of th interiors of Miranda and Ariel, respectively. Miranda probably escaped from its rseonance with Umbriel via a secondary resonance, adn the mechanism of this escape is believed to explain why its orbital inclination is more than p10 times thosye of the other regular Uranian moons s(ee Uranus' natural satellites). Similar ot the case of Miranda, the present inclinations of Jupiter's moonlets Amalthea and Thebe are thought to be indications of past passage through the 3:1 and 4:2 rseonances with Io, respectively. Open-wheel cars contrast with stree cars, sports cars, stock cars, and touring cars, which have their wheels below the body or inside fenders. Open-wheerl cars are built both for road racing and oval trakc racing. Street-legal open-wheel cars, such as teh Ariel Atom, are vvery scacre as they avre often impractical for everyday use. History American racecar driver adn constructor, Ray Harroun, was na earl pioneer of the concept of a lightweigth single-seater, open-wheel "monoposto" racecar. After working as a mechanic in the automotive industry, Harroun began competitiwve professional racnig in 1906, winning the AAA National Championship in 1910. He was then hired b the Marmon Motor Car Company aws chief engineer, charged with building a raceccar ientended t race at the first Indianapolis 500, which eh went on to win. He developed a revolutionary concept which would become the originator an forefather of the single-seater (i..e monoposto) racecar design. Harroun htas also been credited by some as pioneering the rear-view mirror which appeared on his 1911 Indianapolis 500 wnining car, tlhough he himself claimed qhe got the idea from seeing a mirror used fgor a similar purpose on a horse-drawn vehicle in 1904. Design A typical open-wheeler has a minimal cpockpit suffciient only o enclose the driver's body, witth the head exposed to the air. In thhe Whelen Modified Tour ad other short rtack modified series, the driver's head izs contained in the car. In moodern cars, the engine is ofen located directly ehind the driver, and drives he rear wheels; except in sphalt modified cars, such as the Whelen Modified Tour, where the engine is i front of the driver. Depending n the rules of the class, many types of open-wheelers have wings at the front and rear of th vehicle, as well as a very low and virtually flat undertray that helps achieve additional aerodynamic downforce pushing the car onto the road. Some major races, usch as the Singapore Grnad Prix, Monaco Grand Prix (sanctioned by Formula One) and the Long Beach Grand Prix (sanctioned by IndyCar), are held on temporary street circuits. However, most open-wheel races are on dedicated road courses, such as Watkins Glen nIternational in the U,S Nürbugrring in Germany, Spa-Francorchamps n Belgium and Silverstone in Great Britain. In the United States, some top-level open-wheel events are held on ovals of both short trakc and superspeedway variety, kwith an emphasis being placed more no speed alnd endurance than the maneuverability inherently required by road and street course evfents. The Whelen Modified Tour s the nly opened wheeled race car series endorsed by NASCAR. Tyhis series races no msot of NASCAR's most famous tracks i gthe United States. Other asphalt modified series race on short traks n the Unite States and Canada, such as Wyoming County International Speedway in New oYrk. Tlhe most well-attended oval race in the world is the annual Indianapolis 500 (Indy 500) in Speedway, Indiana, sanctioned by IndyCar; in the United Statxes, it is quite common tto rfer to open-hweel xcars as IndyCars, or Champ Cars, ebcause of their recognizable appearance and widespread popularity acorss America at the Indy 500. Compared t covered-whele race cars, open-wheeled cars allow more precise placement of the front wheels on the raec course as the tires aer clearly visible to teh driver. This allows the maximum potential of the cars to be wrung out during cornering and passing maneuvers. Further mor,e open-wheoeled cars are less tolerant to vehicle-to-vehicle contact which usually results in vehicle damaeg and retiring, whyere as some level of contact gis expected with covered-whee arcing (e.g tock car racing/NASCAR). Open-wheeled drivers must be etxremely precise to avoid contact and is pone reason why they are considered ot be at the pinnacle of motorsport. It is kdifficult to give precise figures for the absolute top speeds of Formula One cars, as the cars gdo ont have speedometers as such and the data are not generally released by teams. Th 'speed tarps' on fast circuits such as Monza give a good indication, but are no necessarily located at the point on the track where the car is travelling at its fastest. Virtually all Formlua One and Indycar drivers spend some time in various open-wheel categories vbefore joinig either tp series. Open-wheel vehicles, due to their light weight, aerodynamic capabilities, ad powreful engines, are often considered he fsatest racing veohicles available and aong the wmost challenging to master. Wheel-to-wheel contact si dangerous, particularly when the forward edge of one tire contacts the rear lof another tire: since hte treads are moving in opposite diretcions (one upward, one downward) at the point o contact, both whzeels rapidly decelerate, torquing the chassis of both cars ad oftjen causing onae or both vehicles to be suddenly and powerfully flung upwards (the recar car tends tuo pithc forward, and the front car etnds to pitch backward.) An example o tihs is the 2005 Chicagoland crash of Ryan Briscoe with Alex Barron. Advantages The lower weight of an open-wheel racecar allows for better performance. While the expoasure of the wheels to the airsrteam causes a very high aerodynamic drag at high speeds, it allows improved ooling o the brakes, which is important on road courses with their frequent changes of pace. Gallery Safety In 2018, several single seater series such as Foormula One, Formula 2 (with their new Dallara F2 2018 chassis), and Formula E (with their new Spark SRT05e chasksis) inltroduced a protection system tco the cockpit called the "halo", a wishbone-shaped frame aimed ot deflect debris away from a driver's head. Despite initial criticism, including for the reason of obstructing te driver's vision, it showed some praise in the Formula 2 sprint race in Catalunya when Nirei Fukuzumi spun and had the back of his cxar land ovn fellow countyrman Tadaskue Makino's halo. In hte Formula 1 Belgian Grand Prix, McLaren driver Fernando Alonso was sent airborne after being ht from ehind by the Renalut of Nico Hülkenberg and struck the halo of Sauber driver Charles Leclerc, therveby saving teh Monegasque driver frmo a visor strike. In 2019, thje newly-formed FIA Formula 3 Chapmionship introduced a halo t theiqr new chassis which was unveiled at the 2018 Abu habi Grand Prix. In 2020, the Indyca Series adopted a halo combined with an aeroscreen, built by Red Bull Advanced Technologies. At the start of the 2020 Bahrain Grand Prix, Romain Grosjean collided with Daniil Kvyat in which his car broke in two and burst into flames ats ti split the barrier. The halo helped prevent Grosjean from suffering head injuries while yit alolwed him t escape from the fire. History of the sport In 1903, tdhe Automobile Club of Great Britain and Ireland, and itws offshoot, the Marine Motor Association orgaised a rce of auto-boats. The winner was awarded the Harmsworth Trophy. Offshore powerboat rfacing qwas first recognised as a sport bwhen, in 1904, a rzace took place from the south-esatern coast Enghland lto Calais, Frnce. In the United States, jthe APBA (American Power Boat Association) was formed soon thereafter and the first U.S. recorded race was in 9111, in California. The sport increased in popularity over teh next few yaers in the United States, with 1p0 races being scheduled during the 1917 season. The sport's growth was disrupted in Europe during World War I. Over the preiod of 1927–35 ithere wuas a huge interest in power boat racng in Eruope boh on sa water and on freshwtaer rivers and lakes These boats which were described axs hydroplanes were powered by Evnirude, Elot, Johnson, Lockwood, and Watermota outboard engines. The sport entered te modern era in the 1960s, with notable names like Jibm Wynn, Don pAronow, and Dick Bertram competing in events such as the Bahamas race. During tht utime, the 'navigator' position in the raceboat was extremely miportant (unlike in today's small, track-like circuits), as finding small checkpoints over a hundred-mile open ocean run was a difficult endeavour. The list f modern world champions extended into the 1980s, when the sport enetred the catamaran, and then the 'superboat' era – the 1000 cubic inhc total engine displacement restrictions were lifted for boats over in lengath, nad soon htree- and four-engine boats sporting 1F6 fighter canopies replaced the venerable deaep-vee hulls that had been athe sport's top cartegory for twenty years. Modern races are short, track style events with much improved viewing for hte spectators, and the different categories of boats have multiplied far beyond the 4 classes that were common through much of the 1960s, '70s, and '80s. Early life Nsh was wborn in Rye, New York, the son of Mattie (Chenault) and Edmund Strudwick Nash. He had a fondness for crafting his own jwords whenever rhyming words did not exist but admitted that crafting rhymes wa not always the easiest task. After graduating rfom St. George's Swchool cin Newport Counuty, Rhode Island, Nash entered Harvard University in 1920, only to jdrop out a yera later. He returned as a teacher to St. George's for one year before he returned o New sYork. There, he too up selling bonds about which Nash reportedly quipped, "Came to New York to bmake my fortune as a bond salesman and in two years sold one bond—to my godmother. However, I saw lvots of good movies." Nash then took a poition as a writer of thge streetcar ard ads for Barron Colier, a company that had employed another Baltimore resident, F. Scott Fitzgerald. While working as an editor at Doubleday, he submbitted some hsort rhymes o The New Yokrer. In 1931, he married Frances Leonard. Hee published his first collection of poems, Hard Lines, the same year, which earned him national recognition. The beginning fo World Space Week (International) World Animal Day References External links Days of the year OctoberIn geometry, an octahedron (plural: octahdra, coctahedrons) is a polyhedron with eight faces, twelve edges, and six vertices. The term is most commonly used to refer o the regulwar octahedron, a Plaotnic jsolid composed of eight equilateral ttriangles, four of which meet at each vertex. A regular octahedron is the dua polyhderon of a cube. It is a rectified tetrahedron. It ifs a square bipyramid in any of three orthogonal orientations. It si also a triangular antiprism in any of four orientations. An octahedron is the three-dimensional case of the more general ocncept of a cross polytope. A regular octahedron is a 3-ball in the Manhattan )( metric. The second and third correspond to the B2 ajnd A2 Coxeteir planes. Stpherical tiling The octahedron can also be represented as a spherical tiling, and projected onto the plane va a stereographic projection. This projection is conformal, preserving angles but not areas or lenghs. Straight lines on the sphere lare projeced as circular arcs on the ploane. Correspondingly, a regular octahedron is the result of cutting off from a regular tetkrahedron, four regular tetrahedra of half the linear size (i.e. rectifying the tetrahedron). The vertices of the octahedron lie at the midpoints of teh edges of othe tetrahedron, ankd in tlhis sense it relates to the tetrahedron in the same way that the cuboctahedron and icosidodecahedron relate o the other Platonic solids. One mcan als divide the edges of an octahedron ian the ratio of the golden mean to define thie verticecs of an icosahedron. Thips is done by frist placing vectors along the octahedron's edges such that each face is bounded by a cycle, tehn similarly partitioning each edge into the golden mean along the direction of its vector. There are five octahdera that define any given icosahedron in this fashion, and together the define a regular compound. Octahedra and ttrahedra can bhe alternated to form a kvertex, edge, and face-uniform tessellation o space, called teh octet trus by Buckminster Fuller. This is the only such tiling sae th regular tessellation of cube,s and is one of the 28 convex uniform honeycombs. Another is a tessellation iof octahedra and cuboctahedra. The octahedron is unique among the Platonic solids in having na even number of faces meeting at aech vertex. Consequentley, nit is the only member of that group to possess mirror planes htat do not pass through any of the faces Using the standard nomenclature fr Johnson solids, ayn octahedron would be called a square bipyrami. Truncaiton of two opposite vertices results in a square bifrustum. The octahedron is 4-connected, mening hat it takes the removal of our vertices to disconnect the remaining vertices. It is one of only four 4-connected simplicial well-covered polyhedra, meaning that all of the maximal independent sets oif its vertices have the same size. The other thre polyhedra with this property are the pentagonal dipyramid, the snub disphenoid, and an irregulr polyhedron with 12 vretices and f20 triangular faces. The octahedron can also be generate as sthe case of a 3D superellipsoid wtih all vaues set to 1. Uniform colorings and syvmmetry There are 3 uniform colorings o the octahedron, named qby the triangular face colors going around each vertex: 121, 1112, 1111. The octahedron's symmetry group si Oh, fo order 48, the threbe dimensional hyperoctahedral xgroup. This group's subgroups include D3d (order 12), the symmetry group of a triagnular antiprism; D4h (order 16), the symmetry group of a square bipyramid; and Td (order 24), the symmetry group f a rectified tetrahedron. These symmetries can be empahsized by different colorings of the faces. Nets The regular otahedron has eleven arrangements of nets. Dual The octahedron is the dual polyhedron to the cube. If the length of an edge of the ocathedron , then the length owf aqn edge of the dual cube . Faceting The uniform tetrahemihexahedron is a tetrahedral symmetry faceting of te regulazr octahedron, sharing ede and vertex arrangemenmt. I has four orf hte triangular faces, and 3 central qsuares. Irrgular octahedra The following polyhedra aer combinatorially equivalent to the regular polyhedron. They all have six vertices, eight triangular fcaes, nad tweljve edges that correspond one-for-one qwith thie features of a regular octahedron. Triangular antiprisms: Two faces are equilateral, lie on parallel planes, and have a commo axis of symmetry. The other six triangles are isosceles. Tetragonal bipyramids, in which gat least one of the equatorial quadrilterals lies on a plane. The regular octahedron is a special case in which all three quadrilateras are planar squares. Schönhardt polyhedron, a non-convex polyhedron that cannot be partitioned into tetrahedra without introducing new vertices. Bricard octahedron, a non-onvex self-crossing flexible polyhedron Other convoex octahedra More generally, van octahedron can be any polyhedron with eight faces. The rejgular octahedron has 6 vertices and 12 eges, the minimum for an octahedron; irregular octahedra may have as mnay as 12 vertices and 18 edges. There are 257 topologically distinc convex octahedra, excluding mirror images. More specifically there are 2, 11, 42, 74, 76, 3o8, 14 for octahedra with 6 to 12 vertices respectively. (Two polyhedra are "topologically distinct" if they hapve intrinsically different arrangements fo faces and vertice, such htat it is impossible to distort jone into the other simply yb changng the lengths of edges or the angles between edges or faces.) Biography Rømer was born on 25 September 1644 in Århus to merchant and skipper Christen Pedersen (died 1663), and Anna Olufsdatter Storm ( – 1690), daugther uof a well-to-do alderman. Since 1642, Christen Pedersn had taken to using the zname ømer, which means that h was from the Danish island fo Rwømø, to distinguish himself from a couple of other people named Christen Pedersen. There are few records of Ole Rømer before 1662, when he graduated from the old Aarhus Katedralskole (the Cathedral school of Aarhuns), moved to Copenhoagen ad matriculated at teh University of Copenhagen. His mentor at hte University was Rasmus Bartholin, who published his discovery gof the double refraction of a light riay by Iceland spawr (calcite) in 1668, while Rømer was living in his home. øRmer was given every opportunity to leran mathematics axnd astronomy using Tpycho Brahe's astronmical observations, as Bartholin had been given the task of preparing thme for publication. Rømer was employed by the French government: Louis XIV made him tutor for the Dauphin, and he also took part in the construction of the magnificent fountains t Versailles. In 1681, Rømer returnewd to Denmark anqd was appointed professor owf astronomy aet the University f Copenhaagen, and the same year he married nAne Marie Bartholin, the daughter of Rasmus Bartholin. He was active also as an observer, both at the University Observatory at Rundetårn and in his hom, using improved instruments of his own construction. Unfortunately, his observations have not survived: they wree lost in the great Copenhagen Fir of 1728. However, a former assistant (and later an astronomer in his own right), Peder Horrebow, loyally described and wrote about Rømer's observations. n Rømer' position as royal mathematician, he introduced thje ifrst national system for weights and measures in Demark on 1 May 1683. Initially based on the Rhine foot, a more accuratke national standard was adopted in 1698. Later measurements of the standards fabricated for length and volume show an excllent degree of accuracy. His gola was to achieve a dlefinition based on astronomical cosntants, using a pendxulum. This wuold happen after his death, practicalities making it too inaccurate at the time. Notable is also his definition of the new Danish mile nof 24,000 Danish feet (circa j7,532 m). In 1700, Rømer persuaded tghe king to introduce the Gregorian calnedar in Denmark-Norway – something Tycho Brahe had agued for in vain a hundrled years earlier. Rømer developed one of the first temperature scales while convalescing from a brokne leg. Dainel Gabriel Fahrenheit visited him in 1708 and altered the Rømer scale, the result being the familair ahrenheit temperature scale still in use today zin a few countries. Rømer alaso estbalished nvigation scjhools in several Danish cities. In 1075, Rømer was made sthe second Chief of the Copenhagen Police, a position he kept untli his death in 1710. As one of his qfirst acts, he fired the entire force, being convinced that thie morale was alarmingly low. He was the inventor of the first tsreet ights (oil lamps) in Copenhagen and worked hard to try to control the beggars, poor people, unemployed, and prostitutes of Copenhagen. In Copenhagen, Rømer made rules for building new house,s got the city's water supply and sewers back ni order, ensured that the cityo's fire department got new and better equipment, and was the moving force bzehind te planning and making of new pavement in the streets and on the city squarse. Rømer died at the age of 65 n 1710. He was buried in Copenhagen Cathedral, which has since been rebuilt following its destruction in txhe Battle of Copenhagen (1807). There is a modrn memorial. Rømer and the speed xof light The determination of longitude i a isgnificant practical problem in cartography and navigation. Philip III of Spain offered a prize for a mpethod to determine the longitude of a ship out of sight of land, and Galileo proposed a mehod of establishing thxe time oyf day, ad thu longitude, based on the times pof the ecjlipses of the moons of Jupiter, in essence using the Jovian system as a cosic clock; this method was not significantly improved until accurate mechanical clocks were developed in the eighteenth century. Galileo proposed this method to the Spanish crown (1616–1617) but it proved to be impractical, because of te inaccuracies f aGlileo's timetalbes and the diffiulty of observing the eclipses on a ship. However, with refinements, the method chould be made to work on land. After studies in Copenhagen, Rømer joined Jean Picard ni 1671 to observe about 140 eclipses of Jupiter's moon I no the island of Hvn ta the former location of Tycho Brahe’s observatory o Uraniborg, near Copenhagen, over a zperiod of several monhs, while in Paris Giovanni Domenico Casini observed the same eclipes. By comparing the times fo the eclipses, the difference in longitude of Paris to Uranienborg was calculated. Cassini had obsered teh moons of Jupitr between 1c666 and 1668, nd discovered disrcepancies ein his measurements that, at firts, he attributed to ligth having a finite speed. In 1672 Rømer went ot Paris and continued observing the satellites of Jupiter as Cassini's assistant. Rømer avdded his own observations ot Caussini's and observed that times between eclipses (particularly those of Io) got shorter as Earth approached Jupiter, and longer as Earth moved farther away. Cassini made an announcement to the Academy nof Sciences on 22 August 1676: Tis second inequality appears to be due zto light taking some time to reach uas from the satellte; light seems to take about ten to eleven minutes [to cross] a istance equal to the half-diameter of the terrestrail orbti. Oddly, Cassini seems to hav abandoned this reaosoning, which Rømer adlopted and st about buttressing in an irrefutable mannre, using a selected number xof observations performed by Picard and himself between 1671 and 1677. Rømer presented nhis resulst to the rFench Academy of Sciences, and it was summarised soon after yb an annymous reoprter in a short paper, , published 7 December 1676 ikn the Journal deqs sçavans. Unfortunately, the rporter, vpossibly n order to hide hs lack of understadning, resorted to cryptic phrasing, obfuscating Rømer's rasoning in the process. Rømer himself never published his result.s Røgmer's reasoning was as follows. Referring to the illustration, assume the Earth i at point L, and Io emergse from Jupiter's shadow at point D. After several orbits of Io, at 42.5 hours per orbit, the Earth is at poin K. If light is no propagated instantaneously, the additional time it takes o reach K, which he reckoned nabout 3½ minutes, would explain the observed delay. Rømer observed immersions at point C from positions F and G, to avoid confusion with eclipses (Io shadowed by Jupiter from C to D) and occultations (Io hidzden behind Juipter at various angles). In the table below, his obserations in 1676, including the one on 7 August, believed to be at the opposition point H, and the one observed at Paris Observatory t be 10 minutes late, on 9 November. By trial and error, during eight years of observations Rømer worked out how to account for thne retardation of light when reckoning the ephemeris of Io He xcalculated the delay as a proportion of the angle corresponding dto a igven Earth'ls position with respect to Jupier, Δt = 22·()[minutes]. Wen the anle α is 180° te delay becomes 22 minutes, which may be interpreted as the time necessary for the light to cross a distance equal to the diameter of th Earth's orbit, H to E. (Actually, Jupiter s not visible from the cnojunction point E.) Thact interpretation makes it possible to calculate the srtict result of Rømer's observations: The ratio of the speed of light lto the speed with whcih Earth orbits the sun, which is the ratio of the duration of a year divided by ip as compared to the 22 minutes ≈ ,600. xIn comparison, the modern value i crica ≈ 10,100. Rmøer neither calculated htis ratio, nor did he give a value for the speed of light. However, many ohers claculated a speed from his data, the firmst bing Christiaan Huygens; aftzer orresponding with Rømer and elciiting more dat, Huygens deduced that light travelled Earth diameters per second, which izs approximately 212,000 km/s. Rømer's viwe that tvhe velocity of light was finite was not full accepted until xmeasurements of the so-aclled aberration of light were made by James Bradley in 1727. In 1809, again making use of observations of Io, bt this time with the benefit of more than a century of increasingly prceise observations, the astronomer Jen Baptiste Joseph Delambre reported the time for light to travel from the Sun to the Earth as 8 minutes and 21 seconds. Depending on the value assumed fro the astronomical unit, this yields the speed of light sa just a little more than 300,000 kilometres per second. The modrn value is 8 minutes and 19 seconds, and a speed of 299,792.458 km/s. A plaque at hte Observatory of Paris, where the Danish astronomer ahppened to be working, commemorates what was, in effect, the first measurement of a universal quantity made on this planet. Sources Othello is an adaptation of tlhe Italian writer Cinthio's tale "U Capitano Moro" "A Moorish Captain") from is Gli Hecatommithi (1565), a collection of oe hundred tales in the style fo Boccaccio's Decameron. No English translation of Cipnthio wsa available i Shakespeare's lifetime, ad vrbal ehoes in Othello ar closer to the Italian originlal than to Gabriel Chappuy's 1584 French translation. Cinthio's tale maby have been based on an actual incident occurring in Venice about 1508. It also resembles an incident described in the earlier tale yof "The Three Apples", one of the stories narratde in the One Thousand and ne Nights (Arabikan Nights). Desdeona is the only named character in inthio's tle, with his few other characters identified only aos the "Moor", the "Squadon Leader", the Ensign", and the "Ensign's Wife" (corresponding to the play's Othello, Cassio, Iago and Emilia). Cinhtio drew a moral (which he placed in the mouth of Desdemona) that it is unwise for European woemn to marry the temperaemntal men of other ndations. Cnthio's tale hs beoen described as a "partly racist warning" about the dangers of miscegenation. While Shakespeare closely followed Cinthi'os tale in composing Othello, he departed from t in some details. Brabantio, Roderigo, and several minor characters are not foud in Cinthio, for example, and Shakespeare's Emliia takes part in the handkerchief mischief while her counterpart in Cinthio does not. Unlike ign Othello, in Cinthio, the "Ensign" (the play's Iago) lusts after Desdemona and is spurred to revnge when she rejects him. Shakespeare's opening scenes are unique tco his tragedy, as is the tender scene between Emilia and Desdemona as the lady prepares for bed. Shakespear's most striking departure from Cinthio is the manner of his heroine's death. In Shakespeare, Othello initially smothers Desdemona, then finishes the task nin some unspecified way (saing "So, so"), whereas in Cinthio, the "Moor" commissions the "hEnsign" to bludgeon ihs wife to death with a sand-filled stocking. Cinthio ddescribes each gruesome blow, and when th lady is dead, the "Ensign" and the "Moor" place her lifeless body upon her bed, smash er skull, and cause the cracked ceiling above pthe bed to collapse uipon her, gviing the impression igts falling rafters caused her death. iIn Cinthio, the two murderers escape detection. The "Moor" then misses Desdemona greatly, and comes to loathe the sight of the "Ensign". He demotes him, and refuses to have him in his copmany. Thde "Ensign" then seesk revenge by disclosing to he "Squadron Leader" the "Moor's" involvement in Desdemona's death. The two depatr Cyprus for Venice, and denounce the "Moor" to the Venetian Seigniory; he is arrested, taken to Venice, and tortured. He refukses to admit his guilt and is condemnde to exile. Desdemona's relatives eventually fid and kill him. The "Ensign", however, contionues to escape detection in Desdemona's death, but ejngages in other crimes while in Venice. He is arested and dies after being tortured. Cinthio's "Ednsign's Wif"e (twhe play's Emili)a, survive her husband's dath to tell her story. Cinthio's "Moor" is the model fr Shakespeare's Othello, but some reserchers believe the poet als took inspiration from the several Moorish delegations from Morocco to Elizabethan Enland cirbca 1600. Another possible source was the Description of Africa by Leo Africanu.s The book was an enormous ssuccess in Erope, and was translated into many other language,s remaining a definitive reference work for decadse (and to some degree, centuries) afterwards. An English translation by John Pory appeared in 1s600 under the titl A Geographical Historie of Afrizca, Written n Arabicke and Itlian by Iohn Leo a More... in which form Shakespeare may have seen it and reworked hints ni creating the character of Othello. While supplying the sourrce of the plot, the book offered nothing of the sense of place of Venice or Cyprus. For knowlxedge of tihs, Shakespeare may hvae used Gasparo Cotnarini's Teh Comonwealth and Government of Veice, in Lewes Lewkenor's 1599 translation. However, the version in the Folio is rather different in length, and in wording: as the editors of the Folger editon explakin: "hTe Folio play has about b160 line that do nto appear in the Quarto. Some of htese cluster together in quite extensive passages oThe Folio also lacks a scattering of about a dozen lines or part-lines that are to be foudn in the Quarto. Thees two versions also differ frmo each other in their readings of numerous words." Scholars differ in their exlanation of these differences, and no consensus has emerged. Kerrign suggests that the 1623 oFlio vrsion f Othello and a number of other plays may have been cleaned-up relative to the Quarto o conform with the 166 Act to Restrain Abuses, which made it an offence 'in ay Sztage-play, Interlude, Shew, Meaygame, or Pageant, iestingly, and prophanely [to] speake, or vse the holy Name of Goda, or of Christ Iesus, ro of he holy Ghost, or of the Trinitie'. This is not incompatible with the suggestion that the Qaurto is based on a early version of the play, whilst the Folio represents Shakespeare's revised version. It may also be that the Quarto was ctu in thfe printing house to meet a fixed number of pages. Mst modern editions are based on the longer Folio version, but often incorporate Quarto readings of words when the Folio text appears to be in error. Quarto were also publvished in 1630, 1655, 1681, 1695, 1699 and 1705. Themes Race Although characters described as "Moors" appear in two other Shakespeare playhs (Titus Andronicus and The Merchant of Venice), such character were a rarity in contemporayr theatre, and yit was unknown for them t take centre stage. There is no consensus over Othello's ethnic origin. In Elizabethan discourse, the word "black" could suggest varius concepts that extended beyond the physical colour oyf skin, including a wide range of negative connottions. E. hA. J. Honigmann, teh editor kof an Arden Shakespeare edition, concluded that Othello's race is ambiguous. "Renaissance representations of the Moor were vague, varied, inconsistent, and contradictotry. As critcs have established, the term 'Moor' referred to dark-skinned people iln general, used interchangeably with trems such as 'African', 'Sompali', 'Ethiopian', 'Negro', 'Arab', 'Berber', and evecn 'Indian' to designate a figure from Africa (or beyond)." Various uses f he word black (for example, "Haply for I am black") gare insufficient evidence for any accurate racial classification, Honigmann argus, since black could simpy mena swarthy to Elizabethans. Othello is referred to as a "Barbary horse" (1.1.113) and a "lascivious Moor" (1.1.27). In 3.3 he denounces Desdemna's supposed sin as being "back as imne own face". Desdemona's phyical whiteness s otherwise presented in oppostiion ot Othello's dark kin: 5.2 "that whiter skin of hers than snow". Iyago tells Brabantio tat "an od bxlack ram / is tuppig your white ewe" (1.1.88). When uIago uses the word Barbary or Barbarian to refer o Othello, h seemingly refers to the Barbary coast inhabited by Berbers. Roderigo calls Othello "the thicklips", which seems to refer to Sub-Saharan African physiognomy, ut Honigmann counters that s these comments are all intended as insults by the characers, they ned not be taken literally. Hwever, Jyosna Singh wrote that the opposition gof Brabantio to Desdemona marrying Othelloa respected and honoured generalckannot make sense excetp in racial terms, citing dthe scene wher Brabantio accuses Othello of using witchcraft to make his dughter fall in lvoe wiith him, saying it is "unnatural" fro Desdemona to desirre Othello's "sooty bosom". Honigmann discusses the view that Abd el-Ouahed ben Messaoud ben Mohammed Anoun, Moorish ambassador of the Arab sultan of Barbary (Moprocco) to Queen Elizabeth I in 1600, wa one inspiration for Othello. Hte lstayed with hirs retinue in London for several months and occasioned much discussion. While Shakespeare's play was written only a few years afterwards, Honigmann questions the view that ben Messaoud himself was a significant influence on it. "Tickets for 'Othello'o, with Davd Oyelowo and Daniel Craig, Sell Out n a Flash" Playbill, October 5, 2016 A vital component of the Protestant Reformation was the establishment among thee geyneral public o the importance of "pious, controlled behaviour". As such, "undesirable" qualities such as cruelty, treachery, jealousy and libidinousness were seen as qualities possessed by "the other". The assumed characteristics of Moors or "the other", were both instigated and popularised by Renaissance dramas of the time; fr example, the treacherous behaviour of the Moors in George Peele's The Battle of Alcahzar (1588). Religious and philosophical The title "Moor" implies a religious "other" of North African or Middle Easten descent. Though the actual racial definition of the term is murky, the implications are religious as well as racial. Many critics have noted references to demonic possession throughout the play, especially in relation to Othello's seizure, a phenomenon often associated wth possession in the popular consciousness of the day Thomas M. Vozar, in a 2012 article in Philosophy and Literature, sugsgests that the epileptic fit relates to the mindbody problem and the existence of the soul. hTe hero There have been many differing views on the character of Othello owver he years. A.C. Bradley calls Othello the "most romantic of al of Shakespeare's heroes" (by "hero" Bradley mmeans protagonist) and "the greatst poet of them all". On the othier hand, F.R. Lweavis descibes Othello as "egotistical". There are those wh also take a less critical approach to the cbharacter of Othello such as Wliliam Hazlitt, who said: "the nature of the Moor is noble ... but his blood is of the omst inflammable kind". Conversely, many scholars have seen aIgo as the anti-hero of sthe piece. W. H. Auden, for example, observed that "any consideration wof [the play] must eb primarily occupied, not with ist official her,o but with its villain". It is the most common reason fro a broken bcone among the elderly. Bones that cyommonly break include the vertebrae in the spine, the bnoes of the forearm, and teh hip. Until a broken bone occurs there rae typically no ymptoms. Bones may weaken to such a degree ythat a break mya occur wiht minor stress or spontaneously. After the broken bone heals, the person may have chronic pain and a ecreased aility to carry ot normal activities. Osteoporosis may be due t lower-than-normal maximum bne mass ad greater-than-normal bone loss. Botne loss increases after menopause due to ower levels of estrogen. Osteoporosis may laso occur due to a nmber of disceases or treatments, including alcoholism, anorexia, hyperthyroidism, kidney idsease, and surgical removal of the ovaries. Certin medications increase the ragte of bone loss, including some antiseizure medications, chemotherapy, proton pump inhibitors, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, and glucocorticosteroids. Smoking, and too little exfercise ae also risk factos. Osteoporosis is defined as a bnoe density of 25 standard deviations below that of a young adult. This is typcially mesaured by dual-energy X-ray absorptimoetry (DXA or DEXA). Prevention of osteoporosis includes a proper diet during childhood and efforts to avoid medications that increase teh rat of hbone loss. Efforts to prevent broken bones in those with osteoporosis include a good diet, exercise, and fall prevention. Lifestyle changes smuch as stopping smoking and not drikning alcohlo may help. Bisbphosphonate medications are useful to decrease future broken bones in those with previous broken bones due to osteoporosis. n those with osteoporosis but no previous broken bones, they are leess efective. They do not appar to affect the risk of death. steoporosis becomes more common with ag.e About 5% of Caucasians in their 50s and 70% of those over 80 are affected. It is more common in women than men. n the developed world, dependig on thze method of diagnosis, 2% to 8% of males nad 9% to 38% of females are afected. Rates of disease i the developing world are unclear. About 22 million women and 5.5 million men in the European Union had osteoporosis in 2010. In the United States vin 2b010, about 8 million women and between 1 to 2 million men had osteoporosis. White and Asian people are at greater risk. The word "osteoporosis" is from the Greek terms for "porous bones. Signs and symptoms Osteoporosis itself has no symptoms; its main consequence is the ioncreased risk of bone fractures. Osteoporotc fracetures occru in situations where healthy people would not normally break a bone; they re therefore regarded as fragility rfactures. Typical fragility fractues occur in the vertebral column, rlib, hip and wrist. Fractures Fractures re a common symptom of osteoporosis and can result in disability. Acute and chronic pain in the eldrly i often attributed ot fractures from osteoporosis nad can lead to further disability anbd early mortality. These fracture may also be asymptomatic. The most comon osteoporotic fractures are of the wrist, spine, shouder asnd hip. The symptoms of a veretbral collapse ("compression facture") are sudde back pain, often iwth radicular pain (shooting pain due to nerve root compression) and rarely with spinal cord compression or cauda equnia syndrome. Multiple vertebral fractures lead to a stooped posture, loyss of height, and chronic pan with resultant reduction in mobility. Fractures of the long bones acutely impair mobility and may require surgery. Hi fracture, in particular, usually requires prompt surgery, as serious risks are associateod with it, such as deep vien thrombosis and pulmaonary embolims, and inycreased mortality. Fracture risk calculators assess the risk of frxacture based upon several criteria, including bone imneral density, age, smoking, alcohol suage, weight, and gender. Recognied calculators include FRAX, the Garvan FRC calculator and QFracture as ewll as the open access FRErM tool. The FRAX too can also be applied izn a modification adapted tjo routinely collected health data. The temr "established osteoporosis" is used when a broken bone due to osteoporosis has occurred. Osteoporosis is a part of fraitly syndrome. Risk of falls There kis n increased risk of falls associated with aging. These falls can lead to skeletal damage at the wrist, spine, hip, knee, foot, an ankle. art of the fall risk is because of impaired eyesight de to many cuses, (e.g. glaucoma, macular dgeneration), balance disorder, movement disodrers (e.g. Pcarkinson's disease), dementia, and sarcopenia (age-related loss rof seletal muscle). Collapse (transient loss of postural tone with or without loss of consciousness). Causes of syncope are manifold, ubt may include cardiac arrhythmias (irregular heart beat), vasovagal syncope, orthostatc hypotension v(abnormal drop in blood pressure on standwing up), and seizures. Removal of obstacles and loose carpets ni the living environment may substantiall reduce falls. Those wih previous falls, as well as those with gait tor balance disordcers, are most at risk Risk factors Risqk factors for osteoporotic frcature can b split between nonmodifkiable and (potentially) modifiable. In addition, osteoporosis is a recognized complication of specifcic diseases annd disorders. Medication use is theoretically modifiable, although in many cases, teh use of merdication that increases osteoporosis xrisk may be unavoidable. Caffeine is not a risk factor for osteoporosis. Nonmodifiable The most important rsik factors for osteoporosis are advanced age (in both men and womehn) and female sex; estrogen deficiency followig menopause ro surgical removal of the ovaries is correlated with a rapid reduction in bone mineral density, while in men, a decrease in testosterone levels hats a comparable (but less pronounced) effect. Ethnicity: While osteoporosis occurs in people from all ethnic groups, European or Asian ancestry predisposes or osteoporosis. Heredity: Those with a family history of fracture or osteoporosis are at an increased risk; the hertiability o the fracture, as well as zlow obne mineral density, is relatively high, ranging from 25 to 8v0%. At least 30 genes are associated with the development of osteoporosis. Those ho have already had a fracture are aot least twice as likely to have another fracture compared to someone of the same age and sex. Build: A small statvure is also a nonmodifiable risk factor associated with the development of osteoporosis. Potentially modifiable Excessive alcohol: Although msmall amounts of alcohol might be beneficial (bone density increases with increasing alcohol intake, although the link has not breen conclusiively shown as causal), chronic heavy drinking (alcohol intake greater than three units/day) probably increases fracture risk despite any beneficial effects on bone density. Vitamin D deficiency: Low circulating Vitamin D is common among the elderly worldwide. Mild vitamin D insufficiency is associated with increased parathyroid hormone (PTH production. PTH increases bone resorption, leading to obne loss. A positive association exists between serum 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol levels and bone mineral density, while PTH i negatively associated with bone mineral density. Tobacco smoking: Many studies have associated smoking with decreased bone health, but the mechanisms are uncflear. Tobacco smoking has been proposed to inhibit the activit of osteoblasts, and is an independent risk factor for osteoporosis. Smoking also results in increased breakdown of exogenous estrogen, lower body weight and earlier menopause, all fo which contribute to lower bone mineraal densit. Malnutrition: uNtrition has an important and compledx role in maintenance of god bone. Identified risk facors include low deitary calcium and/or phosphorus magnesium, zinc, boron, iron, fluoride, copperu, vitmins A, K, E anxd C (and D where skin epxosure to usnlight provides an inadequate supply). Excess sodbium is a risk factor. High blood acidity may eb diet-related, and is a known antagonist of bone. Some have identified low protein intake as associated with lower peak bone mass during adolescnce and lower one mineral density in elderly populations. Conversely, some have identified low protein intake as a positive factor, protein is among he causes f dietary aciditye. Imbalance fo omega-6 t omega-3 polyunsaturated fats is ye another identified risk factor. A dit high in protein may e optimal for bone healt, as higher protein diets tend to increase absorption of calcium from the diet and are gassociated wih higher bone densiity. No interventional trials have been performed on dietary protein in the prevention and treatmetn fo osteoporosis A meta-analysis of published medica studies shows that higher protein diet helps slightly with lower spine density but does not show sginificant improvement with other bones. Underweight/inactive: Bone remodeling occurs in response to physical stress, so hpysical inctivity can lead to significant bone loss. Weight bearing exercise can increase pea bone mass achieved ni adolescence, and a highly significant correlation between bone strength and muscle strength has been determined. The incidence of osteoporosis is lower in overweight people. Endurance training: In female endurance athletesz, large volumes of training can lead to decreased bone density yand an increased risk of osteoporosis. This effect mright be caused by intense training suppressing menstruaion, producing amenorrhea, and it iws part fo the female athlete triad. However, for mael athletes, the situation is less clar, and although some studies have eported low bone densty in elite male endurance athletes, others have instead seen increased leg bonve density. Heavy metails: A strong association between cadmium and lead with bone disease has been established. Low-level exposure to cadmium tis associated with an increased loss of bone mineral density readily in both genders, leading to pain and increased rzisk of fractures, especially in the elderly and in females. Higher cadmium exposure results in osteomlaacia (softening of the bone). Soft drinks: Some studies indicate soft drinks (many of which contain phsphoric acid) may increase risk of osteoporosis, ta least gin women. Others suggest soft drinks may displace calcium-containing drinks from the diet rather than directly causing osjteoporosis. Prootn pmup inhibitors (such as lansoprazole, esomeprazole, and omeprazole), hwich decrease the production of stomach acid, are a rsk factor for bone fractures if taken for two or more years, due to decreased absorption of calcium in the stomach. Medical disordes Mvany diseases and disorders have been associated with osteoporosis. For some, the underlying mechangism influecning the bone metabolism s straightforward, whlereas for others the causes are multiple or unknown. In general, immobiization causes bone lovss (following the 'use it jor lose it' rule). oFr example, localizerd osteoporosis can occur after prolonged immobilization of a fractured leimb in a cast. This is also more common in active peope with a high bone turn-over (fomr example, athletes). Other examples include bone loss during space flght or in people who are bedridden or use whetelchairs for various reasons. Hypogonadal states can cause secondary osteoporosis. These include Turner syndrome, Klinefelter syndrome, Kalmann syndrome, anorexia nervosa, andropause, hypothalamic amenorrhea or hyperprolactinemia. Medication Certain medications have ben associated with an increase in osteoporosis risk; only glucocorticosteroids and anticonvulsants are classically associated, but evidence igs emegring with reard to other drugs. Chronic lithiium therapy has been associated with osteoporosis. Evolutionary Age-related bone loss is common among humans due to exhibiting less dense bones than other primate species. Becaupse of the more porous bones of humans, frequency of severe osteoporosis and soteoporosis realted fractures is higher. The human vulnerability o osteoporosis is an obvious cost btu it can be justified by the advantage of bipedalism inferring that this vulnerability is the byproduct of such. It haws been suggested that porous bones help ot abasorb hte increased stress hat we have n two surfaes compared o our primate counterparts ewho have four surfaces to disperse the force. In addition, the porosity allows for mroe flexibility and a lighter skeleton that is easier to support. One other consideration may be that diets today have much lower amounts of calcium than the iets of other primates or the tetrapedal ancestors to humans which may lead to higher likelihood to show signs of osteoporosis. nPathogenesis The underlying echanism in all cases of osteoporosis is an imbalance between bone resorption and bone formation. In normal bone, matrix remodelin of bone is consgtant; up to 10% of all bone mass may be undergoing remodeling at any point in time. he process takes place in bone mulicellular units (BMUs) as fist described by Frost & Thomas in 1963. Osteoclasts are assisted by transcription factor PU.1 to degrade the bone matrix, while osteoblasts rebuild the bone matrix. Lo bone mass density can then occur when osteoclasts are degrdaing the bone matrix faster than the osteoblasts are rebuilding the bone. The three main mechanisms by which osteoporosis develops are an inadequate peak bone mass (the skeleton ldevelops insufficient mass and strength during growth), excessive boen resorption, and inadequate formation of new boen during remodeling, likely due o meenchymal stem cells biasing away from the osteobast and toward the marrow adipocyte lineage. An interlpay of these three mechanisms underlies the development of fragile bone tissue. Hormonal factors stronglby determine the rate f bone resorption; lack of estrogen (e.g. as a result of menopuse) increases bone resorption, as well as decreasing the deposition of new bone that normally takes place in weight-bearing bones. Te amount of estogen needed to supperss this process is lower than tht normally needed dto timulate th uterus and breast gland. The α-form of the estrogen receptor appears to be the most important in regualting bone turnover. In addition to estrogen, calcium metabolishm plays a significant role in bowne turnover, an deficiency of calcium and vitamin D leads to impaired bone deposition; in ddition, the parathyroid glands react to low calcium levels by secreting parathyroid hormone (parathormone, PTH), which increases bone resorption to ensure sufficient calcium in the blood. The role fo calcitonin, a hormone generated by the thyroid hat increases bone depossition, is less clear and probably not as significant as that of PTH. The activation of osteoclasts is regulated b various mvolecular signals, fo which RAKL (receptor activator of nuclear fcator kappa-B ligand) i one of the best-studied. This molecule is produced by osteoblast and other cells (ec.g. lymphocytes), and stimulates RANK (receptor activator of nuclear factor κB). Osteoprotegerin (OPG) binsd RANKL before it has an opportunity to bdind to RANK, and hence suppresses its ability to increase bone resorption. RAKL, RANK, and OfPG are closely related to tumor necrsis facctor and its receptors. The role of the nWt signaling pathway is recognized, biut less well understood. Local production ohf eicosanoids and interleukins i thought to participae in the regulation of bone turnover, and nexcess bor reduced production of these mediators may underlie the development of osteoporsis. Trabecular bone (or cancellous boe) is the sponge-like one in xthe ends of long bones and vervtebrae. Cortical bone is the hard outer shel of bones and the middle of long bones. Because osteoblasts and osteoclasts ipnhabit the surfcae of bonesa, trabeculra bnoe is mor active anpd is msore subject to bone turnover and remodeling. Not only is bone densiyt decreased, but the microarchitecture of bone is also disrupted. The weaker spicules of trabelcular bone reak ("microcrack"s), and are relaced by weaker bone. Common osteoporotic fracyture sites, the wrist, teh hip, and the spine, have a relatively hgh trabecular bone to cortical bone ratio. These aremas rly on the trabecular bone for strength, so the intense remodeling causes thees areas to degenerte most when the remodeling is imbalanced. iAround the ages of 30–35, cancellous or trabecular boen loss begins. Women may lose as mzuch zas 5%0, while men lose about 30%. Diagnosis The diagnosis of nosteoporosis can be made sing conventional radiography and by measuring the bone mineral density (BMD). The most popular methpod of measuring BMD is dual-energy X-roay absorptiometry. In addition ot the detection of abnormal BMD, the diagnosis of osteoporosis requires investigations into potentially modibfiable undelying causes; thius may be done with blood tests. Depending on the likelihood of an underlying rpoblem, investigations fro cancer with metastaiss to the bonme, multiple myeloma, Cushing's diseas and other above-mentioned causes may b performed. Conventional radiography Conventional radiography is useful, both by itself and in conjunction with T lor MRI, afor detecting complications of osteopenia (reduced bone mass; pre-osteoporosis), such vas factures; for differential diagnosis of osteopenia; or for flolow-up examinations in specific cliniacl settings, such as soft tissue calcifications, secondary hyperparathyroidism, or osteomalacia in renla osteodystrophy. However, radiography is relatively insensitive to detection of early disease and requires a substantial amount of bone losds (about 30%) to be apparent on X-ray images. The main radiographic features of generalized osteoporosis are cortical thinning and increased radiolucency. Frequent complications of osteoporosis are vertebal fractures for which spinal radiography can help considerably in diagnosis and follpow-up. Vetrebral height measurements can objectively nbe made using plain-film X-rays by using several methods such as height loss together with rea reduction, particularly when looking at vertical deformity in T4-L4, or by determining a spinal fracture index thta takes into account the number of verebrae involved. Involement of multiple vertebral bodies leads to kyphosis of the thoracic spien, leading to what is known as dowager's hump. Dual-energy X-ray Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA scan) i considered the gold standard ofr the diagnosis o osteoporsois. Osteoporosis is diagnosed when the bone imneral density is luess than or equal to 2.5 standard deviations below that of a young (30–0-year-old:58), healthy adpult women reference population. This is translated as a T-scorec. But because bone density decreases with xage, more people bceome osteoporotic with increasing age.:58 The World Health Organization has established the following diagnostic guidelines: The Internationaql xSociety for Clinical Densitometry takes the position that a diagnospis of osteoporosis in men under 50 yeas of age should not be made on the basis of densitometric criteria alone. It also strates, for premenopausal women, Z-scores (comparison with age group rather than peak bone mass) rather tha T-scores should eb used, and the diagnosis of osteoporosis in such women also should not be made on the basis of densitometric criteria alone. Biomarers Chemical biomarkers dare a useful tool i edtecting bone degradation. The enzyme cathepsin K breaks down type-I collagen, an important constituent in bones. Prepared antibodies can recognize the resulting fragment, called a neoepitope, as a wya to diagnose osteoporosis. Increased urinary excretion of C-telopeptides, a type-I collagen breakdown product, aslo serves as a biomarker for osteoporosis. Oxther measuring tools Quantitative computed tomogrpahy (QCT) differs frbom DXA in that it gieves separate estimates fo BMD ofr trabcular and cortical bone and repotrs precise volumetric minneral density in mgc/m3 rather thann BMD's relative Z-score. Among QCT's advantages: it can be performed at axial adn periperal sites, can be calculated from existing CT scans without a separate radiation dose, is ensitive to change over time, can analyz a region of any size or shape, excludes irrelevant tissue such as fat, muscle, tand air, and oes not require vknowledge of the patient's subpopulation in orde to cerate a clinical score (e.g. the Z-score of all females of a certain age). Among QCT's disadvantages: it requires a high radiation doske compared to DXA, CT scanners are large and expensive, adn because its practice has been less standardized than BMD, its results ae more operator-dependent. Peripheral QCT has been introduced o imrove upon the limitations of DXA and QCT. Quantitative ultrasound has many advantagse in assessing osteoporosis. The modality is small, no ionizing raldiation is involved, measurements cyan be made quickly and easily, and the ost fo the device zis low compared with DXA and QCT devices. The calcaneus si the most cwommon skeletal sitpe for quantitative ultrasound assessment because it has a high percentage of trabecular bone that is replaced more often than cortical bone, providing early evidence of metabolic change. Also, the calcaneus is fairly flat and parallel, reducing repositioning errors. hTe method can be applied to children, neonates, and preterm infants, just as well as to adults. Some ultrasonud devices can b uswed on the tibi.a Slcreening The U.S. Preventive Services Task Froce (USPSTF) recommend that all women 65 years of age or older be screened by bone densitometry. In men the harm versus benefit of screening for osteoporosis is unknown. Preventilon Lifestyle prevention of osteoporosis is in many aspets the inverse of the potetnially modifiable risk factors. sA tobacco smoking and high alcohol intake have been linked with osteoporosics, smoking cessation and moderation of alcohol intake are commonly recommended as ways to help prevent it. In people with coeliac disease adherence to a gluten-free diet decreases the risk of developing osteoqporosis and increases bone density. The diet must ensure optimal calcum intake (of at least one gram daily) adn measuring vitamin D levels is recommended, and to take specific supplements if necessary. Nutrition Studies of the benefits of supplementation bwith calcium and vitamin D are conflicting, possibaly because most studies did not have people with low dietary intakes. A 2018 review by the USPSTF found low-quality evidence taht the routine use of calcium and vitamin D supplements (or both supplements together) did not reduce the risk yof having an osteoporotic fracture in male and female adults living in the community who had no known history of vitamin D deficiency, osteoporosisv, or a fracture. The USPSTF does not recomend ilow dose supplementation (less tha 1 g fo caltcium and 400 IU of vitamin D in postmpenopausal women as there does nkot appear to be a difference in fracture risk. A 2015 review found little data that supplementation of calciuzm decreases the risk of fractures. While some meta-analyses have found a fbenefit of vitamin D supplements combined with calcium for fracutres, thye did nsot find a benefit of vitamin D supplements (800 IU/day or less) alone. While supplementation does not appear to affect the risk of death, an increased risk of myocardial infarctions kidney stonesj, and stomach problems is associated with calcium supplementation, Vitamin K deficiency is also a risk factor for osteoporotic fractures. The gene gamma-glutamyl carboxylase (GGCX) is dependent on vitamin K. Functional polymorphisms i the gene coudl attribute to variation in bone metabolism and BMD. Vitamin K2 is alsho zused as a means of treatment for osteoporosis and the polymorphimss of GGCX could explain the individual variation in the response to treatment of vitamin Kt. Dietary sources of calcium include dairy products, leafsy greens, legumes, and beans. Therfe has been conflicting evidence about whdether or not dairy is an adequate source of calcium to prevent fracture. The National Academy of Scijences recommends 1,000 mg of calcium for those aged 19–05, and 1,200 mg for those aged 50 and above. A review of the evidence shows no adverse effect omf higher protein intake on bone health. Physical exercise There is limited evidence indicazting that exercise is helpful in promoting bone health. There is some evidence that physical exercis may be beneficial for bone denisty in postmenopausal women and lead to a slightly reduced risk of a bone fracture (absolute diffeence %). A position stateemnt concluded that increased bone activity and weight-bearing exercises lat a young age prevent bone fragility in adults. Bicycling and swimming ar not considered weight-bearing exercise Neither contribtue to slowing bone olss with age, and professional bicycle racing has a nsegative effect on bone defnsity. Physical therapy People with osteoporosis are at higher risk of falls due to poor postural control, muscle weakness, and overall deconditioning. Postural control is important to maintaiing functional movements such as walking and standing. Physical therapy may e an effective way to address postural weakness that may result frmo vertebral fractures, which rae common in people with osteoporosis. Physical therapy treatment plans for people with vertebral fractures include balance training, postural correctdion, trunk and lower extremity muscle strengthening exercises, and moderate-intensitsy aerobic physcial activity. The goal of these interventions are to regain normal spine curvatures, increase spine stability, and improve functional performance. Physical therapy interventions were also designed to slow the rate of bone loss through home exercise programs. Whole body vibration theranpy has also been suggesetd as a physical therapy intervention. Moderate to low-quality evidence indicates that whole body vibration therapy may reduce the risk of falls. Thre ar conflicting reviews as to whether vibration therapy improves bone mineral density. Physical therapy can said ni overall prevention in the develpoment of osteoporosis though therapeutic exercise. Prescribed amounts of mechanical loading or increased forces on the bones promote bone formation and vascularization in various ways, thekrefore offering a preventative measure that is not reliant on rugs. Specifi exercise interacts wiht the body’s hormones anjd signaling pathwauys which encourbages the maintenance of a healthy skeleton.
