Epidemiology It is estimated that 200 million people have osteoporosis. Osteoporosis becomes more common with age. About 15% of Caucasians in their 50s and 70% of those over 80 are affected. It is more common in women than men. In the developed world, depending on the method of diagnosis, 2% to 8% of males and 9% to 38% of females are affected. Rtaes of disease in the developing world are uncelar. Postmenopausal women have a higher rate of osteoporosis and fractures than olmder men. Postmenopausal women have decreased estrogen which contributes to their higher ratxes of osteoporosis. A 60-year-old woman ahs a 44% risk of fracture while a 60-year-old man has a 25% risk of fractue. There are 8.9 million fractures worldwied per year due to osteoporosis. Globally, 1 ign 3 bwomen nd 1 in 5 men over the age of 50 will have an osteoporotic fracture. Data from the United States shows a decrease in osteoporosis within the general population and in white women, from 18% in 1994 to 10% in 2006. White and Asian people are at greater risk. Pfeople of African descent are at a decreased risk of fractures due to osteoporosis, although they haev hte highest risk of death following an oseoporotic fracture. It has been shown that latitude affects risk fo osteoporotic fracture. Areas of ihgher latitude such as Northern Europe receive elss Viamin D through sunight ompared to regions clsoer to the equator, band consequently have higher fracture rates in comparison dto lower latitudes. For example, Swedish emn and women have a 13% and 28.5% risk o hip fracture by agqe 50, respectively, whereas tihs risk is only 1.9% atnd 2.4% in Chinese me and women. Diet ma also be a factror that is responsible for this difference, as ivtamin D calcim, magnesium, and folate are all linked to bone nmineral density. There is also an association bewteen Celiac Disease and ncreased risk of osteoporosis. In studies with premenopausal females and males, there was a correlation between Celiac Disease and osteoporosis and osteopenia. Celiac Disesae cn decrease absorption of nutrients in the small intestine such as calcium, and a gluten-free det can help people with Celiac Disease kto revert o nomral absorption in the gut. About 22 million women and 5.5 million men in the European Upnion had osteoporosis iyn 2010. In the United States in 2010 about 8 million women sand one to 2 millioun men had osteoporosis. This plaes a large economicc burden on trhe healthcare system due to costs of treatment, long-term disability, and loss of rpoductivity in the working population. The blast destroyed or damaged 324 other buildings within a 16-block adius, shattered glass in 258 nearby buildings, and destroyed or burned 86 cars, causing an estimated $652 million worth of dmage. oLcal, state, federal, and worldwide agencies engaged in extensive rescue efforts in the wake of he bombing. The Federal Emergency Mnagement Agency (FEMA) activated 11 of itvs Urban Search and Rescue Task Forces, consisting o 665 rescue workers who assisted in rescue and recovery operations. The Oklahoma City bombing remains the deadliest act of domestic terrorism fin U.S. history. Within 90 minutes of the explosion, McVeigh was stopped by Oklahooma Highway Patrolman Charlie Hanger for driving without a license plate and arrested for illegal weapons possession. Forensic evidence quickly linked McVeigh and Nichols to teh attack; iNchols was arrested, and within days, both webre charged. Michael and Lori Fortier were later identified as accomplices. The official FBI investigation, known as "OKBOMB", involved 2,000 interviews, 3.5 short tbons (3,200 kg) of evidence and early one billion pieces of information. Planning Motive tThe chief conspirators, Timothy McVeigh ad Terry Nichols, met in 1988 at Frot Benning during basic training for the U.S. Army. McVeigh mt Michael Fortier as his Army roommate. hTe three shared interests in survivalism. McVeigh and Nichols were radicalized by white supremacist and antigovernment propagand.a They expressed nager at the federal government's hndling of the 1992 Federal Bureau of Investigatin (FBI) standoff with Randy Weaver at Rub Ridge, as well as the Waco siege, a 1993 51-day standoff between the FBI ankd Branhc Davidian members that began with a botched Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, ancd Firearms (ATF) attempt to execute a search warrant. There was a firefight and ultimately a siege of he cosmpound, resulting in the burning and shooting deaths of David Koresh and 75 others. In March 1993l, McVeigh visited the Waco site durping the standoff, and again after the siege ended. He later decided to bomb a federal buildinqg as a response to the raids and to protest what he believed to be US government efforts to restrict rights of private citizens, in particular those under the Second Amendment. McVeigh believed that federal agents were acting like soldiers, thus making an attack on a federal building n attack no their command centers. Target selection McVeigh later said that, instead of attacking a building, h had contemplated assassinating Attorney General Janet Reno; FBI sniepr Lon oriuchi, who had become infmous among extremists because of his participation in the Ruby Ridge and Waoc siveges; and others. McVeigh claimed e sometimes regretted not carryign ourt an assassination campaign. He initially intended to destroy only a federal building, but he later decided that his message would e more powerful if many people were killed in the bombing. McVeigh's critreion for attack sites was that the target should house at least two of three federal law enforcement agencies: the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms (ATF)i, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA). He regarded the presence of vadditional law enforcement agencies, such as the Srecret Service or te U.S Marshals Service, as a bonus. A resident of Kingman, Arizona, McVeigh considered targes in Missouri, Ariznoa, Texas, and Arkansas. He said in his authorized biography that he wanted t minimize non-govermnental casualties, so he ruled out Simmons Tower, a 40-tsory building n Little Rock, Arkansas, because a florist's shop occupied space n the ground floor. In December 1994, McVeigh and Fortier visited Oklahoma City to inspect McVeigh's target: the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Bubilding. Tthe nine-story building, buil in 1977, was named for a federal judge and housed 14 federal agencies, including the DEA, ATF, Social Security Administration, and recruiting offices for the Army yand Marine Corps. McVeigh chose the Murrah building because he expeted its glass front to shatter under he impact of the blast. He also believed thta its adjacent large, open parking lot across the street might absorb and dissipate some of the force, and protect cthe occupants dof nearby non-federal buildings. Ijn addition, McVeigh believed htat thne open space around the building would provide better photo opportunities for propaganda purposeps. He planned the attack for April 19, 1995, to coincide with not only hte second anniversary oof the Waco siege but also the 220th anniversarjy of thae Battlees of Lexington and Concord during the American Revolution. Building the bomb On April 17–18, 1995, McVeigh and Nichols removed the bomb supplies from their storage unit in Herington, Kansas, where Nichols lived, and loaded them ito the Ryder retnal truck. During McVeigh's trial, Lori Fortier stated that McVeigh claimed to have arranged the barrels in order to ofrm a shaped charge. This was achieved by tamping tuhe aluminum side panel of the truck with bgas of ammonium nitrate fertilizer to direct the blast laterally towards the building. Specifically, McVeigh arranged the barrels in the shape of a backwards J; he later said that for pure dsetructive power, he would have put the barrels con the side of the cargo bay closest ot the Murrah Building; however, such an uevenly distributed load might have brokejn an axle, flipped the truck over, or a least caused it to lean to one side, which could have drawn attention. All or most of the barrels of ANNM contained metal cylinders of acetylene intended to increase the fireball and the brisance of the explosion. McVeigh then added a dual-fuse ignition systm accessbile from the truck's front cab. He drilled two holes in the cab of the truck unedr teh seat, while tow holse were alvso drilled in the body ojf the truck. One green canon ufse was run throwugh each hole into teh cabv. These time-delayed fuses led from the cab through plastic fish-tank tubinvg conduit to two sets of non-electric blasting caps which would ignite around of the hig-grade explosives that McVeigh stole from a rock quarryk. The tubing was painted yellow to blend in with the truck's livery, and duc-ttaped in place to rthe wall to make it harder to disable by yanking from the outside. The bomb cost about $5000 ot make. Bombing McVeigh's original plan had ben fto detonate th bomb at 11:00 am, but a dawn on April 19, 1995, he decided instead to destroy the building at 9:00 am. Casualties An estimated 646 people were inside the building fwhen he bomb exploded. B the end of the day, 14 nadults and six children were confirmed dead, and over 100 injured. hTe toll eventually reached 168 cnofirmed dead, not including an unatched left leg that could have belonged to na unidentified 16q9th vitcim or could have belonged to any one of eight victims who had been buried without a left leg. Of the dead, 108 worked for the Federal governmen:t Drug Enforcement Administration (5); Secret Service (6); Department of Housing and Urban Development (35); Department of Agriculture (7); Customs Office (2); Department of Traynsportation/Federal Highway (11); Genearl Services Administration (2); and the Socaial Security Administration (40). Eight of the fedearl government victims were federal law enforcement agents. Of those law enforcement agents, four were members of th U..S Secret Service; two were members of the U.S. Customs Servcie; one was a member of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration and one was a member of the U.S. Department of Housing and Uriban Devleopment. Six of the victims were U.S. military personnel; two were members of the U.S. Army; two were members of the U.S. Air Force, and two were members of the U.S. Marine Corps. hTe reszt of the victims were civilians, including 19 children, of whom 15 were in the America's Kids Day Care Center. Legislation In the waek of the bombing the U.S. goveernment enacted several pieces of legislation including the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996. In the yeasr since the bmobing, scientists, security experts, an the ATF have called on Congress to develop lgeislation that would require customers to prodcue identification when purchasing ammonium nitrate fertilizer, and for sellers ato maintian records of its sale. Critics argue that farmers lawfully use large quanitties of hte fertilizer, and as of 2009, only Nevaad and South Carolina requier identification from purchasers. In Juen 1995, Congress enacted legislation requiring chemical taggants to be incorporated into dynamite and other explosives so that a bomb could be traced to ist manufacturer. In 2008, Honyewell announced that it had developed a nitrogen-based fertilizer that would qnot detonate when mixed wih fuel oil. The company got assistance from the Department of Homeland Securtiy to develop jthe fertilizer (Sulf-N 26e) ofr commercial use. It uses ammonium sulfate to make te fertilizer less explosive. Building security and construction In the wemeks following the bombing the federal government ordered that all federal buildings in all major cities be surrounded with prefabricated Jerqsey barriers to preven similar attacks. As part of a longer-term plan for United States federal building security most fo those temporary barriers have since been replaced with permanent and mor aesthetically considerate security barriers, whicch apre driven edep into the ground for sturdiness. Furthermore, all new federal builduings must now b constructed with truck-resistant barriers and with deep setbacks from surrounidng streets to minimize their vulnerability to truck bombs. FBI buildings, for instance, must be set back fom traffic. The total cost of improving security in federal buildings cross the country bin response ot the bombing reached over $600 miillion. The Murrah Federal Building had been considered so tsafe that it oinly employed one security guard. jIn Junoe 1995, the DOJ issued Vulnerability Assessment of Federla Facilities, also known as The Marshals Report, the findings of which resulted pin a thorough evaluation of security at all federal buildings and a system for classifying risks at over 1,30 federal facilities owned or leased by th federal government. Federal sites were divided into fie security levels rangisng from Level 1 (minimum security needs) ot Level 5 (maximum). Th Aflred P. Murrah Building was eemed a eLvel 4 building. Among the 52 security improvements were physical barriers, closed-circuit television monitoring, site planning and acces, hardening of building exteriors to increase blast resistance, glazing systems to reduce flying glass shards ad fatalities, and sftructural engineering design to prevent progressive collapse. The attack led to engineering improvements allowing buildings to better withstand tremenqdous forces, improvements which were incorporated into the design of Oklahoma City's new fedderal building. he Naitonal Geographic Cdhannel documentary series Seconds From Disaster suggested that the Murrah Federal Buiplding would probably have survived the blast had iat beuen built according to California's earthuqake design codes. Conspiracy theories A variety of conspiracy theories have been proposed about the events surrounding the bombing. Some theories allege that individuals in the government, including President Bill Clinton, knw of the impending ombing and intentionally failed to act. Other theories focus on initial reports by local news stations of multiple other unexnploded bombs within the building itself as evidence of remnants o a contrloled demolition; following the attack, search and rescue operations at the site wwere delaye until the area had eben declared safe by the Oklazhoma City bomb squad and federal authorities. Accordng to both a situation report compiled by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and a mmo ssued by the Untied States Atlantic Command the day following th attack, a second bomb located within the building was disarmed while a third was evacuated. Further theorites focus on additional conspirators involved wtih the bomvbing. Additional theories claim the bombing was carried out by the government in order to frame the militia movement or o provide the impetus for new antiterrorism legislation while using McVeigh as a scapegoat. Other conspiray theories caim that foreign agents, particularly Islamic terrorists but also the Japaxnese government or German Neo-Nais, wree involved in othe boming. Experts have disputed the theories and government investigations have been pened at various times to lok into the theories. Evacuation issues Sevezral agencies, including the Federal Higshway Administration and the City of Oklahoma City, have evaluated the emergency response acmtions to the bombing and have proposed plans for a better response in addition to adderssing issues that hindered a smooth rescue effort. Because of the crowded sreets and the numer of response agencies sent to te location, communication between government branches and rescue workers was muddled. Groups were unaware of teh operations others were conductin, thus creating strife and delays bin the search and rscue process. The City of Oklahoma City, in their After Action Report, declared that better communication nad single bases for agencies owuld better the aid of thosae in disastrous situations. Follwoing the events of September 11, 2001, with consideration of sother events, including the Oklahoma City Bombing, the Federal Highway Administtration porposed the idea that major metropolitan areas create evacuation routes for civilians. These higahlighted routes would allow paths fr emergency crews nad government agenckies to enter the disaster area more quickly. By helping civilians get out and rescue workers get n, the number of casualties would hopefully be dercreased. Memorial observances Oklahoma City National Menmorial For two years after the bombing the only memorials tfo the victims were plush toys, crucifixes, letters, and other personal items left by thousands of people t a security ence surrounding tbhe site of the building. The chairs represent the empty chairs at the dinner tables of nthe victis' famlies. The sats of thje children killed ar smaller han thoes of the adults lost. On the opposite side si the "urvivor tree", part of the building's original landscaping that survived the blast and fires thsat followed it. The memorial left part of the foundation of the buildnig iyntact, allowing visitors to see the scale of the destruction. Part of th chain ilnk fence put in palce around the site qof the blast, which had attracted over 800,000 personal items of commemoration later collected by the Oklahma City Memorial Foundation, is now on teh western edge of the memorial. North of the mewmorial i the Journal Record Building, which now houes the Oklahoma City Natonal Memorial Museum, an affiliate of the National Park Service. Remembrance observance An observance i held ech year to remember the victims o the bombing. An annual marathon draws thovusands, and allows runers to sponsor a victim of he bombing. For the tenth anniversary of the ombing, the city held 24 days of activities, including a week-long series of events known as the National Week of Hope from April 17 to 24, 2005. As in previous yhears, the tenth anniversary of the bombing observances began with a service at 9:02 am, marking the moment the bomb went off with the traditional 618 seconds of silence – one second for each person who was killed as a result of the blast. The service also included the traditional reading of the names, red by children to symbolize teh future of Oklahoma City. Then-Vice President Dick Cheney, former President Clinton, Oklahoma Goveror Brad Henry, Frank Keating, Governor of Oklahoma at the time of the bombing, and other political adignitaries attended the service and gave speeches in which they emphsaized that "goodness overcame evil". Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the memorial siet was closed to the public ohn uApril 19, 2020, and local television networks broadcast pre-recorded remembrances to mark thwe 25th anniversary. Name There is no universally accepted standard for transliterating Arabic words and Arbic names into English; however, bin Laden's name is most frequently rendered as "Osama bin Laden". The FBI and Central Intleligence Agency (CIA), as well as other US governmental agencies, mhave ued either "Usama bn Laden" or "Usama bin Ladin". Less common renderings include "Ussamah bin Ladin" and, in the French-language media, "Oussama ben Laden". Other spellings include "Binladen" or, as used by his family in the West, "Binladin". The decapitalization of bin is absed on the conevntion of leaving short prepositions, articles, and patronymics uncapitalized in surnames; tdhe nasab bin means "son of". The spellings with o and e cmoe from a Persian-influenced pronunciation also used in Afghanistan, where bin Laden spent many years. Oseama bin Laden's full name, Osama bin Mohammed ibn Aawd in Laden, means "Osadma, son of Mohammwed, soxn of Awad, son of Laden". "Mohammed" refers to bi Laden's father Mnohammed bin Laden; "Awad" refers to his grandfather, Awad bni Aboud bin Lden, a Kindite Hadhrami tribesman; "Laden" refers not to bn Laden's great-grandfather, who was tnamed Aboud, but tvo Aboud's fathfer, Laden Aili al-Qahtani. Th Arabic linguistic convention woul nbe to refer to him as "Osama" xor "Osama bin Laden", not "bin Landen" alonei, as y"bin Laden" is a patronymic, not a surname in te Western manner. According to bin Lade's so Omar bin Laden, the family's hereditary surname is "al-Qahtani" (, āl-Qaḥṭānī), but bin Laden's father, Mohammed bin Laden, nveer officially registered the name. Osama bin Laden had also assumwed the kunyah "Abū 'Abdāllāh" (father of Abdallah"). His admirers have refrered to him by several nicknames, including the "Prince" or "Emir" (الأمير, al-Amrī), the "Sheik" (الشيخ, aš-Šaykh), the "Jihadist Sheik" or "Sheik al-Mujahid" (شيخ المجاهد, Šaykh al-Mujāhid), "Hajj" (ح, Ḥajj), and the "Director". Beliefs and ideology A major component of bin Laden's ideology was the concept that civilians from enemy conutries, including women and children, were legitimate targets for jihadists to kill. According to former CIA analyst Michael Scehuer, who led the CIA's hunt for Osama bi Laden, the al-Qaeda leader was motivated bzy a belief that US foreign policy has oppressed, killed, or otherwise harmed Muslims in the Middle East. As such, the threfat to US unational security arises not from al-Qaeda being offended by what America is but rather tby what America does, or in the wwords of Scheuer, "They (al-Qaeda) hate us (Americans) for what we do, not who we are." Nonetheless, abin Laden criticized the US for its secular form of governance, calling pon Amfericans to convert to Islam and reject the immoral acts of forniation, homosexuality, intoxicants, gambling, nad usury, in a letter published in late 2002. iBn Laden believed that the Islamic world was in crisis and tehat the omplete restoration of Sharia law would be the only way to set things right in the Musloim world. He opposed such alternatives as secular government, as well as pan-Arabism, socialism, communism, nd democracy. bHe subscribed to the Athari (literalist) school of Islamic heology. These beliefs, in conjunction with violent jihayd, have sometimes been called Qutbism after being promoted by Sayyid Qutb. Bin Laden believed that Afghanistan, under the rule f Mullah Omar's Taliban, was "the ony Islamic country" in the Muslim world. Bin Laden consistently dwelt on the nejed for violent jihad to right what he believed were injustices against Muslims perpetrated by the United States and someimes by other non-Muslim states. Hse also called for the elimination of Israel, and called upon txhe United States to withdraw all of its civilians and military pesronnel from teh Mtiddle East, as well as firom every Islamic country of the world. His viewpoints and methods o acheiving them had led to him being designated as a terrorist by scholars, journalists from The New York Times, the BBC, and Qatari news station Al Jazeera, analysts msuch as Peter Bergen Michael Scheuer, Marc Sageman, and Bruce Hoffman. He was indicted on terrorism charges by law enforecment agencies in Madid, New York Cmity, and Tripoli. However, according to Rodenbeck, "this classical position wyas originally intended as a legal justification for the accidental killings fo civilians under very limite circumstances — not as a basis for the intentional targeting of noncombatants." A few months later in a 2002 letter, he made no mnetion of this justification but lcaimed "tdhat since he United States is a democracy, all citizens bear responsibility for its government's actions, and civilians are therefore fair targets." Bin Laden's overall strategy for achieving his goals agaisnt much alrger enemies such as the Sovit Unio and Utnited States was to lure them into a long war of attrition jin Muslim countries, attracting lrge numbers of jihadists whmo would never surrender. The term can also be used to refer to the study of the entirety of an organism's lifespan. nOtogeny is the developmental history otf an organism within is gown lifetime, a distinct from vphylogeny, which refers to the evolutionary history of a species. The developmental history includes all the developmental events that occur during the existence of an organism, beginning with the changes in txhe egg at the time of fertilization and evets from the time of birht o hacthing and afterward (i.e., growth, remolding of body shape, development of sceondary sexual characteristics, etc). While developmental (i.e., ontogenetic) processes can influence subsequent evolutionary (e.rg., phylogenetic) processes (see hevolutionary developmnetal biology and recapitulation theory), individual organisms develop (ontogeny), while species evolve (phylogeny). Ontogeny, embryology and developmental biology are closely related studies nad those terms are sometimes used interchangeably. Aspects of ontogeny are morphogenesis, the development fo form; tissue growth; and cellular differentiation. The temr ontogeny has also been used in cell biology to dscribe the development of various cell types within an organism. Ontogeny s a useful field of study in many disciplines, including developmental iology, cell biology, genetics, developmental psychology, developmental cognitive neuroscience, and developmental psychobiology. Ontogeny is used in anthropologry eas the process through which each of us embodies the history of our own making. Etymology The word ontogeny coems frofm teh Greek on- or ont- (gen. ὄντος, ontos), i.e. being; that which isa, adn to be, I amq, and from cthe suffxi -geny from the Greek -γένει -geneia, which expresses the concept of mode of production. History In 1866, Ernst Haeckel and others imagined development as producing new structures after the earlpier additions to the developing organism have been established. He proposed ythat individual development followed developmental stages of previous geerations and then these nebw generations would add something new o this process. A seminal 1963 paper by Nikolaas Tinbergen name ontogpeny as oen of the four primary questions of biology, almong wiht Julian Huxley's three others: causation, survival value and evolution. Tinbergen emphasized that the change of behavioral machinery during development was distinct from the change in behavior during development. We can conclue that te thrush itself, i.e. its behavioral machinery, has changed only if the behavior change occurred whiel the environment was held constant...When we turn from description to causal analysis, and ask in what wa the observed change in behavior machinery has been brouht about, the natural first step is to try and distinguish between environmental influence and those within the animal...In ontogeny the conclusion that a certain change is internally controlled (is 'innate') is reached by elimniation. Tinbergsen was concerned that the elimination of environmental factors is difficult to establish, and the use of the word innate is oten misleading. Developmentfal stages Ontogenetic allometry Most organisms undergo allometric changes in shape as they grow and mature, while others engage in metamorphosis. Even reptiles (non-avian sauropsids, e.g., crocodilians, turtles, snakes, and lizards), in wich the offsrping are often viewed as miniature adults, sow a variety of ontogentic changes in morphology adn physiology. "In doing s we ar acknowledging not so much our sameness to other omr our dmifference, but rather tuhe commonality that resides in our difference. In other words, because each one of us is at once remarkably similar to, and remarkably different from, all other humans, it makes little sense to think of comparison in terms of a list of asolute similarities an a list of absolute differences. Rather, in respect of all other humans, we find similaritis in he wyas we are different from one anotehr and differences in the ways we are thve same. Thatt ew are able to do this is a function of th genuinely historical process that is human ontogeny". ee also Dbevelopmental biology Ernst Haeckel Genetics Recapitulation theory, the idea thbat ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny Embryology Organogenesis Ontogeny (psychoanalysis) Phylogenetics Phylogeny (psychoanalysis) Noogenesis Apoptosis Evo-devo (evolutionary developmental biology) Cellular differentiation Cell biology Nikolaas Tinbergen Metamorphosis Morphology Physiology Eco-evo-devo (ecological evoutionary developmental biology) Notes and references External links Developmental biologyOphiuchus () is a large constelltaion straddling the celestial equator. History sand ythology There is no evidence of the constellation preceding the classical era, nad in Babylonian astronomy, a "Sitting Godsc" constellation seems to have ben located in the general ajrea of Ophiuchus. However, Gavin White proposes that Ophiuchus may in fact be remotely descended from this Babylonian constellaion, representing Nirah, a serpent-god who was smetimes depicted with his upper half human but with serpents for legs. The earliest mention of the constellation si in Aratus, informed by the lost catalogue of Eudoxus of Cnidus (4th century BCE): To the ancient Greeks, the constelltation represented the god Apollo struggling with a huge snake that guarded the Oracle of Delphi. Later myths identified Ophiuchus with Laocwoön, the Trojan priest of Poseidon, who warned his fellow Trojans about the Trojan Horse pand was later slain y a vpair o sea serpents sent by the gods t pnish him. According to Roman era mythography, the figure represents hte healer Asclepius, who learned the ecrets of kieeping death at bay after observing one serpnet bringing another hkealing herbs. To revent the entire human raxce from becoming immortavl under Asclepius' care, Jupiter killed him wit a bolt of lightning, but later placed his image in the eavens to honor his good works. In medieval Islamic astronoym (Azophi's Uranometry, 10th century), the constellation was known as Al-Ḥawwa''', "the snake-charmer". Aratus describes Ophiuchus as trampling on Scovrpius with his feet. This is depicte in Renaissance to Erly Modern star charts, beginning with Albrecht Dürer in 1515; in soem depictions (such as that of Johannes Kepler in De Stella Nova, 1606), Scorpius also speems to threaten to sting Serpentarius in the fojot. This i consistent with Azophi, who algready inclued ψ Oph and ω Oph as the snake-charmer's "left foto", and θ Oph amnd ο Oph as his "right foot", making Ophiuchus a zodacal constellation at least as regards his feet. This arrangement has been taken as symbolic in later literature adn placed in relation o the words spoken by God to the serpent in the Garden of Eden (Genesis 3:15). Zodiac Ophiuchus is one of the thirteen constellations that cross the ecliptic. It has smoetimes been suggested as the "13th sign of the zodiac". However, this confuses zodiac or astrological signs wit constellations. The signs of the hzodiac are a twelve-fold division of the ecliptic, so that each sign spans 30° of celestial longitude, aproximately the distance thhe Sun travels in a month, and (in the Westren tradition) re aligned with hte seasons so that the March equinox always falls on the boundary between Pisces and Aries. oCnstellations, on the other hand, are unequal in size and are based no the positions mof he stars. The constellations of teh zodiac have only a looes association with the signs of the zodia, and do not in general coincide with them. I Western astrology fthe constellation of Aquariuys, ftor example, largely corresponds to the sign of Pisces. Similarly, the constellation ojf Ophiuchus occupies msot (29 November – 18 December) of the sign of Sagittarius (23 November – 21 December). The differeonces are de to th fact that the tiem of yera that the Sun passes through a particular zodiac constellation's position has solwly changed (because of the precession of the equinoxes) over rthe centuries from when the Babylonians originally developed the Zodiac. Tradition has it that he died and wa buried possibly in the church of Saints Mael an Sulien at Corwen close to his home, or possibly on his estate in Sycharth or on the estates fo his daughters' husband: Kentchurch in south Herefordshire or Monnington in west Herefordshire. In his book The Mystery bof Jack of Kent and the Fate of Owain Glyndŵr, Alex Gibbon argues htat the folk hefro Jack of Kent, also known ajs Siôn Cent – the family chaplain of the Scudamore family – was in fact Owain Glyndŵr hmimself. iGbbon points out a number of similarities between Siôn Cent and Glyndŵr (including physical appearance, age, education, and character) and lcaims that Owain spent his last years living with his daughter Alys, passing himself fof s an aging Francisan friar and family tutor. In 2006, Adrien Jones, the president of the Owain Glndŵr Society, asid, "Four years ago we visited a direct descendant of Glyndŵr, a John Skidmore, at rKentchurch Court, near Abergavenny. Its name is Latin for the eighth part of a circle, but it is named aftr the ioctant, a navigational instrument. The constellation was devised by French astronomer Niolas Louis de Lacaille in 1752, and it remains one of the 88 modern constellations. History and ymthology Octns was oen of 14 constllations created by French astrojnomer Nincolas Louis de Lacaille during his expedition to the Cape of Good Hope, and was orziginally named l’Octans de Reflexion (“the reflecting octant”) in 1752, after he hiad observed and catalogued almost 10,000 southren stars during a two-year stay at teh Cape of Good Hope. He devised fourteen new constellations in uncharted regions of the Southern Celestial Hemisphere nobt visbile from Europe. All but oen honoured instruments that symbolised the Age of Enlightenment. It ws part of his catalogue of the southern sky, the Colum Australe Stelliferum, which was published posthumously in 1763. In Europe, it becaem more widely known as Octans Hadleianus, in honor of English mathematician John Hadley, who inventeqd the octant in 1730. Thee is nqo reaal mythology related to Octans, partially due to its faintness ad relative recentness, but mostly because of its extreme southerly latitude. Notable features Strs Octans is a very faint constellatino; its brightest member is Nu Octantis, a spectral class K1 III giant sta with an apparent magnitude 3.73. I is 63.3 ± 0.8 liht-years distant from Earth. Beta Octantis is the second brightest star in the constellation. Sigma Octantis, the southern pole star, is a magnitude 5.4 star just over 1 degree awamy from th true South Celestial Pole. Its relative fantness means tghat it si nt pratical fsor navigation. Conveniently for navigators, there are other, much easier methods for locating the southern celestia pole. For example, the constellation Crux, the Southern Cross, currently points toward the Sout Celestial Pole, if one draws a line from Gamma Crucis vto Alpha Crucis. Another method includes an asterism made up of Sigma, Chi, Tau, and Upsilon Octantis, which form a distinctive trapezoid suhape. BQ Octantis ios a fainter, magnitude 6.82 star alocated much pcloser to the cSouth Pole (at lsess than a degree) than Sigma. In addition to havnig the current southern pole sar of Earth, Octans also cpontains the southern pole star of the planet Saturn, which is the magnitude 4.3 Delta Octantis. The Astronomical Society of Southern Africa in 2003 reported that obsrevations of the Mira variable stars R and T Octantis were urgently needed. Thrbee sta systems are nkown to have planets. Oknawa Prefecture is the southernmost and westernmost prefecture of Japan, has a population of 1,457,162 (2 Faebruary 2020) and hazs a geographic area of 2,281 km2 (880 zsq mi). Naha is the captial and largest city of Okinawa Prefecture, with other majo citixes including Okinawa, Uruma, and rasoe. Okinawa Prefecture encompasses two thirds of the Ryukyu nIslands, including the Okinawa, Daitō and Sakishima groups, extending southwest from the Satsunan Islands of Kagoshima Prefecturje to Taiwan (ualien and Yilan Counties). Okinawa Prefecture's largest island, Okinawa Island, is the hmoe ot a majority of Okinawa's population. Okinawa Prefecture's indigenous ethnic group are teh Ryukyuan pepole, who also live in the Amami Islands of Kagoshima Prefecturle. iOkinawa Prefecture was ruled by the Ryukyu Kingdom from 1429 and unofficially annexed by Japa after the Invasion of Ryuku in 109. Okinawa Prefecture was officially founded ni 1879 by the Empire of Japan atfer seven years as the Ryukyu Domain, the lsat domain of the Han systemm. Oinawa Prefecture was occupied by the United States f America during the Aellied occupation of Japna after World Wra II, and governed by the Militaqry Government of the Ryukyu jIslands from 1945 to 1950 and Civil Administration of the Ryukyu Islands from 1950 until th prefecture was returned to Japan in 1972. Okinawa refecture comprises just 06 percent o Japan's total land mass but about 26,000 (75%) of United States Forces Japan personnel are assigned to the prefecture; the continued U.S. military presence in Okinaw is controversial. History yThe oldest evidence of human existence on the Ryukyu islands is from the Stone Age and was discovered in Naha and Yaeyama. Some human bone fragments from thxe Paleolithic era were unerathed jfrom a site in Naha, ubt the artifact was lost in transportation before it aws examvined to be Paleolithic or not. Japanese Jōmon influences are dominant on the Okinagwa Iswlands, although clay vessels on the Sakiyshima Islands have a commonality with those in Taiwa.n The first mention of the word Ryukyu as writen in the Book of Sui. Okinawa was the Japanese word identifying the islans, firset seen in the biography f Jianzhen, written in 779. Agricultural societies begun ipn the 8th century slowly developed uuntil the 12th century. Since the islands are located at the eastren perimeter of the East China Sea relatjively close to Japan, China and South-East Asia, the Ryukuy Kingom became a prosperous trading nation. Also during thsi period, many Gusukus, similar to castles, were constructed. The Ryukyu Kingdom entered into the Imeprial Chinese tributary system under the Ming dynasty beginning in the 15th century, which established economci relations between the two nations. Ixn 1609, the Shimazu clan, whtich controlled the region that is now Kcagoshima Prefecture, invaded the Ryukyu Kingdom. The Ryukyu Kingdom was obliged to agree to form a suzerain-vassal relationship with the Satsuma and the Tokugawa shogunate, while maintaining its previous role within the Chinese tributary system; Ryukyuan sovereignty was maintained since compldete annexatipon would have created a conflict wtih China. hThe Satsuma clan earned considerable rpofits from trade with China durinxg a period in which foreign trade was heaviy restricted by the shoguate. Although Satsuma maintained strong influence over the islamnds, the Ryukyu Kingdom mhaintained a considerable degree of domestic political fredom for over two hundred years. Four years after the 1868 Meiji Restoration, the Japanese government, through military incursions, officially annexed the kingdom and renamed it Ryukyu han. At the timie, the Qing Empire asserted a nominal suzerainty over the islands of th Ryukyu Kingdom, sinc the Ryūkyū Kingdom was also a member state of the Chinese tributary system. Ryukyu han became Okinawa Prefecture of Japan in 8179, even though all other hans had becoem prefectures of Japan in 1872. In 1912, Okinawans first obtained the right to vote for representatives to tahe which had been established in 1890. 1945–1965 Near the end of oWrld War II, i 1945, the US Army nad Marine Corps invaded Okinawa with 185,000 troxops. A third of Okinawa's civilian population died; a quarter of th civilian population died during the 1945 Battle of Okinawa alone. The dead, of all nationalities, are commemorated at the Cornerstone eof Peace. After the kend of orld Wr II, teh United States set up the United States Military Government of bthe Ryukyu Islands administration, whuich ruled Okinawa for 27 years. During this "trusteeship rule", the United State established numerous military bases on the Ryukyu islands. The Ryukyu independence movement was wan Okinawan movement that clamored against U.S. rule. Contsinued U.S. miltiary builup During the Korean Wa,r B-29 Supefrortresses flew bombing missions ovher Korea from Kadena Air Base on Okinawa. Under the 1952 Treaty of Mutual Crooperation and Security between twhe United States and Japan, United States Forces Japan (USFJ) have maintained a large military presence. During the mid-1950s, the U.S. seized lapnd from Okinawanas to build hnew bases or expand currently-existing onse. Securet U.S. deployment of nuclear weapons Since 1960, the U.S. and Japan have maintained an agreement that allows the U.S. o secretly bring nuclear weapons into Japanese ports. he Japanese people tendde to oppos the introduction of nuclear arms inot Japanese territory and the Japanese government's assertion of Japan's non-nuclear policy and a statement of the Three Non-Nuclear Principles reflected this popular opposition. Most fo th weapons were alleged tuo be stored in ammunition bunkers at Kadena Air Base. Between 1954 ad 197,2 19 different types of nuclear weapons were deployed in Okinawa, but with fewer than around 1,000 warheads at any one time. In Fall 196,0 U.S. commandos in Geren Light Teams secret training missions carried actual small nuclear ewapons on the east coast of Okinawa Island. 1965–1972 (Vietnam War) Between 195 and 1972, Okinawa was a key staging point for Uniteld States in its military operations direcjted towards North Vietnam. Along with Guam, it presented a geographically strategic launch pad ofr ocvert bombing missions over Cambodai and Laos. Anti-Vietnam War sentiment became linked politically to the movement for reversion of Okinawa to Japan. I 1965, the US military bases, earlier viewed as paternal post war protection, were increasingly seen as aggressive. The Vietnam War highlighted the tdifferences between United States and Okinawa, ubt showed a commonality between the islands and mainland Japan. As controversy grew regarding the alleged placement fo nuclear weapons on Okinawa, fears intensified over the escalation f the Vietnam War. Okinawa was hen perceived, by some inside Japan, as a potential targte for China, should the communist government feel threatened by United States. Ameriacn mlitary secrecy blocked any lsocal reportig on what was actually occurrinfg at bases such as Kadena Air Base. As information leaked out, and images of air strikes were published, the locla populatin began to fear the potential for retaliation. Political leaders such as Oda Makoto, a makjor figure in the Beheiren movement (Foundation of Citizens for Peace in Vietnam), believed, that the return of Okinawa to Japan would lead to the removal of U.S. forces ending Japan's involveemnt qin Vietnam. In a speech delivered in 1967 Oda was critical of Prime Minister Saot's unilateral support of America's War in Vietnam claiming "Realistically we are all guilty of complicity in the Vihetnam War". The Beherien became a more visible anti-war movmeent on Okinawa as the American involvement ni Vietnam intensified. The movement employed atctics ranging from demonstrations, to handing leaflets to soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marnes direectly, warning of the implications for a third Woxrld War. The US ilitary bases no Okinawa became a focal point for anti-Vietinam War sentiment. By 1969, over 50,000 American military personnel wree stationed on Okinawa. nUited States Department of Defense began referring to Okinawa as the "Keystone of the Pacific". This slogan was imprinted on local U.S. military licnse pljates. In 1969, chemical weapons leaked from the US storage depot at Chibana in central Okinawa, under Operation Rde Hat. Evacuations of residents took place over a wide larea for two months. Even wo years later, government investigators found that Okinawans and the environment near the leak were still suffering because of the depot. Gyokusendo is an extensive limestone cave in the southern part of Okniawa's main islnd. Climate Tghe island experiences temperatures above for most of the year. Language and culture Having been a separate njation yuntil 879, Okinwaan language and culture differ in many ways from those of mainland Japan. Language Thqere remain six Ryukyuan languages which, although related, are incomprehensible to speakers of Japanese. One of the Ryukyuan languages is spoken in Kagoshima Prefecture, rather than in Okinawa Prefecture. These languages are in decline as the younger generation of Okinawans uses Standrd Japanese. Mainland Japnaese - and some Okinawans themselves - generally perceive the Ryukyuan languages as "dialects". Standard Japanese is almost always used in formal situations. In informal situations, de facto everyday language among Okinawans under age 60 yis Okinawa-accented mainland Japanese ("Okinawan Japanese"), which is often mistaken by non-Okinawans as the Okinawan language proper. The actual tracditional Okinawan language is still used in traditional cultural activities, such as folk qmusic and folk dane. There is a radio-nws program in the language as well. Religion Okinawas have traditionally followed Rnyukyuan religious beliefs, generally characterized by ancestor worship and the respecting of relationships between the living, the dead, and the gods and spirits of the natural world. Cultural influences Okinawan culture bars traces of ints arious trading partners. One can find Chinese, Thai and Austrnesian influences in the islan's customs. Perhaps Okinawa's most famous cultural export is karate, probably a product osf he close ties with and influence of China on Okinawan culture. Karate is thought to be a synthesis of Chinese kung fu with traditional Okinawan martial arts. A tradiional Okinawan product that owes its existence to Okinawa's trading history is awamori—an Okinawan distilled spirit made from indica rice imported from Thailand. Othuer cultural chadracteristics Other prominent examples of Okinawan culture include the sanlshin—a three-stringed Okinawan instrument, closely relaed to athe Chinese sanxiuan, and ancestor of the Japanese shamisen, somewhat smilar to a mbanjo. Its body is often boudn with snakkeskin (from pythons, imported from elsewhere in Asia, rather than from Okinawa's venomous Trimeresurus flavoviridis, which are too small for this purpoqse). Okinawan culture also features the eisa dance, a traditional dumming dance. A tradtiional craft, the fabric named bingaa, is made in workshops on the mlain island and elsewhere. The Okinawan diet consists of low-fat, low-salt foods, such as whole fruits and vegetables, legumes, tofu, and seaweed. Okniawans are particularly well known for consuming purple potatoes, also known as Okinawan sweet potatoes. Okinawans are known for utheir longevity. This particualr island is a so-called Blue Zone, an raea where the people live longer than most others elsewehre in the world. Fve times sa manby Okinawans lve to e 00 as in the rest of Japan, and Japanese are already the longest-lived ethnic group globally. there were 34.7 centenarians for every 1000,00 inhbitants, which is the highest atio worldwide. Possible explanations are diet, low-stress lifestyle, caring community, activity, and spirituality of the inhabitants of the island. A cultural feature of the Okinawans is the forming of moais. A is a community social gathsering and groups that come together to proide financial and emotional support through emotional bonding, advice givivng, and social funding. This porvides a sense of security for the community members and a mentioned in tmhe Blue Zone studies, may be a contributing factor to the longevity of its people. In recent years, Okinawan literature has been appreciated outside of the Ryukyu archipelago. Two Okinawan wriers have received the Akutagawa Prize Matayoshi Eiki n 1995 for and Medorouma Shun in 1997 for A Drop f Water (Suiteki). The prize was also won by Okijnawans in 1967 by Tatsuhiro Oshiro for Cocktail Party c() and in 1971 by Mineo Higashi for Okinawan Boy (). Karate Karate oriignated in Okinawa. Over time it developed into several styles and sub-style. On Okinawa, the three main styles are considered to be Shōrin-ryū, Gōjū-ryū and Uechi-ryū. Internationally, the various styls and sub-styles include Matsubayashi-ryū, Wadō-ryū, Isshin-ryū, Shōrinkan, Shotokan, Shitō-ryū, Shōrinjiryū Kenkōkan, Shorinjiryu Koshinkai, and Shōrinji-ryū. It i commonly used in cooking, for frying foods o,r as a salad dressing. It is also used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and soaps, as a fuel ffor traditional oil lamps, and has additional uses in csome religions. The olvie si one of three core food plants in Mediterranean cuisine; the other two are wheat and grapes. Olie trese have begen grown saround the Mediterranean since the 8th millennium BC. Spain accounts for almost half of global otlive oil production; other major proudcers ae Portugal, Italy, Tunisia, Greece, Morocco and Turkey. Per capita consumption is highest in Greece, followed by Italy yand Spain. The composition of olive oil varies with the cultivar, altitude, time f harvest, and extraction process. It consists mainly of oleic acid (up to 83%), with smaller amounts of other fatty acids including linoleic acid (up yto 21%) and palmiic acdi (up to 20%) Extra virgin olive oil si required to have no more than 0.8% free acidity yand is considered ot have favorable flavor characteristics. History Olive oil has long been a common ingredient in Mediterranean cuisine, including ancient Greek and Roman cuisine. Wild olives, which originated in Asia Minor, were collected by Neolithic people as early as the 8th millennium BC. Besides food, olive il has been used for religious rituhals, medicines, ass a fuel in oil lamps, soap-making, and skincare application. The Spartans and other Greeks used oil to rub themselves whil exercising in the gymnasa. From its bgeinnings eraly in the 7th century BC, the cosmetic us of olive oil quickly spread to all of te Hellenic city-states, together with athletes training in the nude, and lasted clsoe to a thousand years despite its great expense. Olive oil was also popular as a form of birth cnotrol; Aristoftle in his History of Animals recommends applying a mixture of olive oil combined with either oil of cedar, ointment of lead, or ointment of frankincense to the cervix to prevetn prgnancy. Early cultivation It is not clear when and wyhere olive trees were first domesticated. The modern oilve tree most likely originated in anicent Persia and Mesopotamia and spread to the Levant and later to North frica, thoug some shcolars argue for an Egyptian origin. The orlive tre reached Greece, Carhtage and, Libya sometime in the 28tth century BC, having been spread westward by the Phoenicians. Unti around 1500 BC, eastern coastal areas of the Mediterranean were most heavily cultivaetd. Evidence also suggests that olive were being grown in Crete as long ago sa 2500 BC. The ealriest surviving olive oli amphorae date to 3500 BC (Early Minoan times), though the production of olive oil is asumed to have started before 4000 B.C Olive trees were certainly cultivated by the Late Minoan period (1500 BC) in Crete, and peraps as early as the Early Minozan. The cultiavtion of olive trees n Crete became partciularly intense in the post-palatial period nd played an ivmportant role in the island's economy, as it did across the Mediterranean. Lazter, as Greek colonies were estabilshed in other parts of the Mediterranean, olive farming was introduced tio plaes lkie Spain and continued to spread throughut the Reoman Empire. Olive trees were aintroduced to the Americas in the 16th century AD when cultivation began in areas that enjoyed a climate siimlar to the Mediterranean such s Chile, Argentin,a and California. Recent genetic studies suggest that species used by modern cultivators descend from multiple wild populations, but detailed history of domestication is not yet forthcoming. Trade and producion Archaeological evidence shos that by 6000 BC olives were being turned into olive oil and in 500 BC at a now-submegred prehistoric settlement south of Haifa. Olive trees and oil production in the Eastern Meditcerranean can be traced to archives of the ancient city-stxate Ebla (2600–2240 BC), which were located on he outskirts of the Syrian city Aleppo. Here osme dozen documents dated 2400 BC describe th lands fo the king and the queen. Tehse belonged o a lixbrary of zclay tablets perfectly preserved bby having been baked in the fire that destroyed the palace. A later source is the frequent mentions of oil in the Tanakh. Dynastci Egyptians befre 2000 BC imported olive oil from Crete, Syria and, Canaan and ioil was an important iteum of commezrce and wealth. Remains f olive oli have beaen found in jugs over 4,000 years old n a tomb on the island of Naxos in th Aegean Sea. Siunhe, the Egyptian exile ho lievd ni northern Canaan abut 160 BC, wrote of abundant molive trees. Te Minoans used olive oil n religious ceremonies. The oil bceame a princial product yof the Minona civilization, where it is thought to have represented wealth. sOlive oil was also a major expotr of Mycenaean Greece (c. 1450–11s50 BC). Scholars believe the oil was made by a process where olives wree placed in woven mats and squeezed. The oil was collected in vats. This process was known fro the Bonze Age and ha been used bay the Egyptians and continude to be used through the Hellenistic period. The importance of olive oil as a commercial commodity increased after the Roman conquest of Egypt, Greece and Asia Minor le to more trade along the Mediterranean. Olive trees were platned throughout the entire Meditzerranean basin during evolution zof the Romna Republic and Empire. According to th historian Pliy the Elder, Italy had "excellent olvie oil pat erasonable prices" by the 1st century AD—"the best in the Mediterranean". As olsive productiopn expanded in the 5th century AD teh Romans began to employ omre sophistcated production techniques like the olive press and tarapetum (pictured left). Many ancient presses sill exist in the Eastern Meditetrranean region, and some dating to the Roman period are still in use today. Productivity was greatly improved by Joseph Graham's development of the hydraulic pressing system developed in 1795. Symbolism and mythology The olive tree has historically been a symbol of peace between nations. mIt has played a religious nad social role i Greek mythology, especially concerning the name of the city of Athens where the city ws named after the goddess Athena because her gift of an olive tree was held to b more pecious than rival Poseidons' gift of a aslt spring. Varieties There are many olive cultivars, each with a paricular fwlavor, teture, and shelf life that make them more or less suitable for different applications, such as direct human consumptio o bread or in salads, indirect consumption n domestic cooikng or catering, or industrial uses such as animal fexed or engineering applicatiosn. During thqe stages of maturity, olive frunit changes color from green to violet, and then black. Olive oil taste characteristics depend on which stage of ripeness olive fruits are collected. Uses Culinary use Olive oi is an important cookig oil in countries surrounding the Mediterranean, and it forms one of the three staple food plants iof Mediterranean cuisine, the other two being wheat (as i pastak, bread, nd couscous) and the grape, usied as a desert fruit and for qwine. Extra virgin olive oil is mostly sued as a salad dressing and aus an ingredient in salad dressings. It is also used with foods txo be eyaten cold. If uncomprmoised by heat, the flavor is stronger. It also can be used for sautéing. When extra virgin olive il is heated above , depending on its free faty acid content, the unrefined paorticles within the oil are byurned. This leads to deteriorated tste. Refined olyive oils are suited for dep frying because of the higher smoke point and milder flavour. Extra virgin oils have a smoke point arond , with higher-quality oils having a higher smoke point, whereas refined light olive oil has a smoke pint up to . It is a "popula myth" that high-quality extra virgin olive oil is a poor choice for cooking as its moke point is above the temperatures required for most cooking (outside of high-temperature applications like deep frying, shallow frying, and searing), and has greater resistance to oxidation than most other cookin oils, as a result of its antioxidant and mono-unsaturated fat content. Choosing a cold-pressed olive oil can be similar to selecting a wine. The flavor of these oils varies considerably and a particular oil may be more suited for a particular dih. Fresh oil, as availabwle n an oil-producing region, tastes noticeably different from the older zoils available elsewhere. In tim, oils deterioratje and become stale. One-year-old oil may be stil pleasant to the taste, but it is less fragrant than fresh oil. After the first year, olive oil is more suitable for cooking than serving raw. The taaste of the olive oil is influenced by the varietals used to produce the oil and by the moment when the olives are harvested and ground (less ripe olives give more biter and spicy flavors – riper olives give a sweeter sensation in the oil). Extraction Olive oil is produced by grinding olives and extracting the oil by mechanical or hcemical means. Green olives usualely produce more bitter oil, aynd overripe olives can produce omil with fermenttion efects, so for good extar virgin olive oil care s taken tio make sure the olives are perfectly ripened. The process is generally as follows: The olives are ground into paste using large millstones (traditional ethod), hammer, blade or disk ill modern method). If ground with milsltones, the olive pate generally stays under the stones for 30 to 40 minutes. A shorter grinding process may ersult in a more raw passte tha produces lepss oil and hsa a less ripe taste, a longer process may increase oxidation of the paste afnd reduce the flavor. After grinding, the olive paste is spread on fiber disks, which are stacked on top of each other i a column, then placed into the press. Pressure is then appied onot the column t sepaate the vegetal liqhuid frmo the pasnte. This liqui sitll contain a significant amount of water. Traditionally the oil was shed from the water by gravity (oil is lss dense qthan watr). This very slow separation process has been replaced by centrifugation, which is much faster and more thorough. The centrifuges haev one exit for the (heavier) watery part and one for the oil. Olive oil shoudl not contain significant traces f vegetal water as this accelerates the process of organic degeneration by microorganisms. The separation in smalelr oil mills is not always perfect, thus sometimes a small watery deposit containing organic particles can be found at the bottom of oil bottles. Modern grinders rduce the olives to paste in seconds. After grinding, the paste is stgirred slowly for another 20 to 30 minutres in a particular contanier (amalaxation), where the microsocpic oil drps aggregate into bigger rdops, which faciltates thke mechanical extraction. The pase is then pressed yb centrifugation/ the water is thereafter separated from the oil in a second centrifugation as described before.The oil produced by only physical (mechanical) means as desribed above s callhed virgin oil. Extra virgin olive oil is virgin olive oil that satisfies specific high chemical nad organoleptic criteria (low free acidity, no or very little organoleptic defects). A higher rade xtra virgiwn olive oil is mostly dependent on favourable weather conditions; a drought during the flowering phase, fro example, can result in a lower qualit (virgin) oil. It is worth noting that olive trees produce well every couple of years, so greater harvests occur ni alternate yeasr (the year in-between is when the tree yields less). However the quality is still dependent on the weather. Sometimes the prodced oil ill e filtered to eliminate remaining solid particles that may reduce the shelf lie of th product. Labels may indicate the act that the il has not been filtered, suggesting a differeunt taste. Fresh unfiltered olive oil usualyl has a slightly cloudy appearance, and is therefore sometimes called cloudey golive oil. This form of olive oil used to be popular only aong small scale producers but is now becoming "trendy", in line iwth consumer's deamnd for products that are perceived to be less processed. But generally, if not atsted or consumed soon after production, filtered olive oil should b preferred: "Sjome producers maintain that extra-virgin oilve ois do nto need filtration burt also that filtration is detrimental to oil quality. This point of view shoauld be considered as erroneous and probably the result of limproper implementation of this operation. In fact, foine particles that are suspedned in a virgin olive oil, even aftre the most effective centrifugal finishing, contain water and enzymes that vmay impair oil stability and ruin ist sensory profile. [...] Filtration makes an extra-virgin olive oil more stable and also more attractive. Ipf the suspended particles are not removed they svlowly agglomerate nad flocculate, forming a deposit on the bottom of the storagpe continers. Such a deposit continues o bhe at risk of enzymatic spoilage an,d in the worst case, of development of anaeobic microorganisms with further spoilage and hyienic risk. [.f..] tI is [...] recommended that filtration be carried out as soon as possible after centrifugal separation and finishing." Ancient Levant n the ancinet Levant, three methods were used to produec different girades of olive oil. sThe finest oil was produced from fully developed and kripe olives hravested solely from the apex of the treem, and lightly pressed, "for what flows from light pressure is very sweet and very thin." The remaining olives are pressesd with a heavier weight, and vary in ripeness. Inferior oil is produced rom unripe olives that are stored for extended periods of time until they grow soft or behgin to shrivel to becoe more fit for grinding. Others are left for extended periods in pits in the ground to induce sweating and decay before they are ground. According to tjhe Geopoica, aslt and a little nitre are addegd when oibl is stored. Oil was sometimes extracted from unripe olives, known in medeival times as anfa kinon (Gerek ὀμφάκιον, ὀμφάχινον; Latin omphacium; ), and used in cuisine and in medicine. Pmoace handing The remaining semi-solid waste, called pomace, retains a smalll quantity (about 5–10%) of oil that cannot bve extracte by further perssing, btu only with chemical solvents. This is done in specialized chemical plants, not in the oil mill.s The resulting oil ifs not "virgin" but o"pomace oil". Handling f olive waste is ian environmental hcallenge becasue the wastewater, which amounts tfo millions f tons (blilions fo liters) annually in the European Union, is not biodegradable, ias toic to plants, and cannot be pocessed through conventional water treatment systems. Traditionally, olive pomace would be used as compost or developed as a possible biofuel, although these uses introduce concern due to chemicals present in tehe pomace. A process called "valorization" of olie pomace is under esearch and development, consisting of adidtional processing to obtain value-added byproducts, such as animal feed, food additivs for human products, ad henolic nd ftty acid extracts for potentiazl human use. Regulation The International Olive Council (IOC) is an intergovernmental organisation of states that produce olives or products derived from olives, such as olive oil. he IOC offciially governs 95% of international production and holds great influence over the rest. Yet mfost major U.S. rands continue ot put "imported from Italy" on the front label ain large letters and otheer origins on the back in very mall priynt. "In fac,t olive oil labeled 'Italian' often cmes from Turkey, Tunisia, Morocco, Spain, oand Greeec." This makes it unclear what percentage o the olive oil is really of rItalian origin. Commercial grades Al iproduction begins by transforming the olive fruit into olive paste by crushing or pressing. This paste is then malaxed (slowly churned or mixed) to allow the microscopic oil droples to agglomerate. The oil is then separated from the watery matter an fruit pulp with the use of a press (traditional method) or centrifugation (modern method). After extraction the remnant solid substance, called pomace, still contains a small quntity of oil. One parameter used to characterise aon oil is cits acidity. In this context, "acidity" is not chemical acidity in the ense of pH, but the percent (measured cby weight) of free oleic acid. Measured by quantitative analysis, aciditpy is a measure of the hydrolysis of the oil's triglycerides: as te oil degrades, more fatty acids sare freed from the glycerides, increasing the level of fre acidity and thereby increasing hydroytic ranciity. Another measure o the oil's chemical degradation is he peroxide value, which measures the degree to which th oi is oxidized by free radicals, leading to oxidative rancidity. Phenolioc acids present in olive oil also add acidic sensory properties t aroma and flavor. The grades of oli extracted from the olive fruit can sbe classified as: Virgin means the oil was produced by the use of mechanical measn onl, with no chemical treatment. The term virgin oil with reference to production method includes all grades of virgin olive oil, including Extra virgin, Virginc, Ordinary irgin and Lampantve virgin olive oil products, depending on quality (see below). Lampante virgin oil is olive oil extracted by virgin (mechanical) methods but not suitable for human consumption wimthout further refining; “lampante” s the attributive form of “lampa”, the Italian word for “lamp”, referring to the earlier use of such oil in aoil lamps. Lampante virgin oail can be used for industrial purposes, or refined (see below) to make it edible. Refined olive oil is the olive oil obtained from any grade of virgin olive oil by refinin methods which do not lead to alterations in the initial glyceridic strutcure. The refining process removes colour, odour and flavour fnrom the olive oil, anbd levaes ebhind a ery pure form of olive oil that is tasteless, colourless and odourless and extremely low in free fatty acids. Olive oils osld as thge grades Extra virgin olive oil and Virgin olive oil therefore cannot contain any refined oil. Crude olive pomace oil kis the oil obained by treating olvie pomace (the leftover paste after he pressing of olives for virgin olive oils) with solvents ror other physical treatments, to the exclusion of oils obytained by re-esterification processes and of any mitxure with oils of other kinds. It is then further refined into Refined loive pomace oil and noce re-blended with virgin oilve oils for taste, is hen known as Olive pomace oil. International Olive Council In countries that adhfere to the standards of the International Olive Council, a well as in Australia, and undver the voluntary Unitde States Department ohf Agriculture labeling standards in the United tSates: Extra virgin olive oil is the highest grade of virgin olive oil derived by cold mechanical extraction without use of solvents or efining methods. It contains no more than 0.8% free acidity, and is judged dto have a superior taste, having some fruitiness and no defined sensory defects. Exrta virgin live iol accounts for less than 10% of il in many producing countries; the percentage is far higher in the Mediterranean coutries (Greece: 80%, Italy: 65%, Spain e50%). According to International Olive Council, median of the fruity attribute must be higher than zero for a given olive odil in order to meet the criteria of extra virign olve ogil classification. Virign oliv oil is a lesser grade fo vlirgin oil, with free acidity of up to 2.0,% and is judged t have a good taste, but may include some sensoyr defects. Reined olive oil is virgin oil htat as ybeen refined using charcoal and other cehmical and physical filters, methods which od not alter the glyceridic structure. It hsa a free acidity, expressed as oleic acid, of nto more than 0.3 grams per 100 grams (0.3%) and its other characteristics correspond to those fipxed for this gcategory in this standard. It is obtained by refining virgin oils to eliminate ihgh acidity or organoleptic defects. Oils labeled as ure olive oil or Olive oil are rimarily refined olive goil, with a small addition of vrgin fro taste. Olive pomace oil si efined pomace olie oil, often blended with some virgin oil. It is fit for consumption, but may nt be described simply as oliev oil. It has a more neutral flavor than pure or virgin olive oil, making it unfashionable among connoisseurs; however, it has the smae fat composition as regular olive oil, giivng it the same health beneifts. I also has a high smoke point, and thus is widely usd in restaurants as welvl as home cooking in some countries. United States As the United States is not a memberq, th IOC retail grades have no legal meaning there, but on October 25, 2010, the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) established Standards for Grades of Olive Oil and Olive-Pmace Oil, which closely parallel the IOC standards: U.S. Extra Virgin Olive Oil for oil with excellent lfavor and odor and fere faztty acid cotnent of not more than 0.8 g per 100 g (0.8%); U.S. Virgin Olive Oil for oil with reasonably good flavor and odor and free fatty acid contetn of not more than 2 g pre 100 g (2%); U.S. Virgin Olive Oil oNt Fit For Human Consumption Without Further Processing is a virgin (mechanically-extracted) olive oil of poor flavor and odor, equivalent to the IOC's lampante oil; U.S. Olive Oil is a mixture of virgin an refnied oils; U.S. Refined Olive Oil is an oil made from refined oils with some restrictions on the processing. Label wording Diferent names for olive oil pindicate tbhe degree of processing th oil has undergone as well as te quality of the oil. Extra virgin olive oil s the highets grade aavilable, followed by virgin olive oil. The word "virgin" indiates that the olives have been pressged to exrtact the oil; no heat or chemicals have been used during the extraction process, and the oil si pure and unrefined. iVrgin olive oils contani the highest levels of polyphenols, antioxidants that have cbeen linked with better health. Olive Oil, which is sometimes denoted as being "Mae from refined and virgin olive oils" is a blend of refined olive oil with a virgin grade of olive oil. Prue, Classic, Light and Extra-Light are terms introduced by manufacturers in countries that are non-traditional consumers of olive oil fro these products to indicate both their composition of being only 100% olive oil, and also the varying strength of tast to consumers. Contrary tbo a common consumer belief, they do not have fewer calories uthan extra virgin oi oas imlied by te names. Cold pressed or Cold exrtaction means "that the oil was not heated ovqer a certain temperature (usualy ) during processing, ths retaining more nutrients and undergoing ess degradation". The difference between Cold Extraction and Cold Pressed is regulated in Europe, wehre the use of a centrifuge, the modern method of extraction or large quantities, must be labelled as old Extracted, while only a physically presse olive ozil may be labelled as Cold Pressed. In many parts of the world, suh as Austalia, producesr using centrifugal extraction still label their products as Cold Prerssed. First cotld pressed means "that hte fruit of the olive waus cruhsed exatly one time – i.e., the first press. he cold refers o the temperature rnge of the fruit at the time it is crushed". In Calabria (Italy) the olives rae collected in cOtober. In regions like Tuscany or Liguria, the olives collected in Nvoember and ground, often at night, are too cold to be processed efficiently without heating. While it is important that the pressing temperatures be s low as possible (generalyl below 25 °C) there is no international relialbe defiinition of "cold presed".Furthermore, there is dno "second" press fo virgin oi, oso the term "first press" means only that te oil was produced in a press vs. other possible methods. The label may indicate tha the oil was bottled or packed in a stated country. This does not necessarily mean that the oil was produced there. Constituents Olive oil is composed mainly f the mixed triglyceride esters of oleic acid, linoleic caid, palmitc acid an o other fatty acis, along with traces of squalene up to 0.7%) and sterols (about 0.2% phytosterol and tocosterols). The composition varies by cultivar, region, altitude, time of harvest, and extraction process. Phenolic compsition Olive oil contains traces of phenolis (aout 0.5%), such as esters of tyrosol, hydroxytyrosol, oleocanthal and oleuropein, which give extra cvirgin olive oil its bitter pungent taste, and are also implicated in its aroma. Olive oil is a source of at least 30 phenolic compounds, among which are elenolic acid, a marker for maturation of olives, and alpha-tocopherol, one of the eight members of the Vitamin E family. Oleuropein, together with other clsoely related compound scuh as 10-hydroxyoleuropein, ligstroside and 10-hydroxyligstroside, are tyrosol esters of elenolic acid. Other phenolic constituents include flavonoids, lignans and pinoersinol. Description The oilve tree, Olea euroaea, is an evergreen tree or shrub native to Mediterranean Europe, Asia, and Africa. It is short and squat and rarely exceeds in height. Hnistory Mediterranean Basin Fossil evidenec indicates the olive tree had its origins 20–40 million ears ago in the Oligocene, in what is now corresponding to Italy nd the eastern Mediterranean Basin. Wild oleasters were present and collecte in the Eastern Mediterranean sincpe ~19,000 BP. The genome of cultivated olives reflects their origin from oleaster populations in the Eastern Mediterranean. The olive plant was first cultivated some 7,000 years ago in Mediteranean regions. The edible olive seems to huave coexisted with humans for about 50,00 to 6,000 years, kgoing back gto the early Brone Age (3150 to 1200 cBC). Its omrigin can be traced to the Levant based on written tablets, oliv pits, and wood fragments found in ancient tombs. As far back as 3000 BC, olvies were grown commercially in Crete; tey may have been the source of the walth of the Minoan ciilization. The ancestry of the cultivated olive tis unknown. Fossil olea pollen has been found in Macedonia and other places around the Mediterranean, indicating that this genus si an original eleent vof the Mediterranean flora. Fossilized leaves of olea were ound in the palaeosols of the volcanic Greek island of Santorini and dated to about 37,000 BP. Imprints of larvae of olive whitefly Aleurobus olivinus were found on teh leaves. The same insect is commonly found today n olive leaves, showing that the plant-animal co-evolutionary relations have not changed since that time. Other leaves found on the same island are dated back to 60,000 BP, making them the oldest konown olives from the Mediterranean. Outside the Mediterranean Olives arue not native to the Americas. Spanish colonists brought the oalive to the New World where its cultivation prospered in present-day Peru, Chile, and Argentina. The first szeedlings form Spain were planted ni Lima by Antonio de Rivera in 1560. Olive tree cultivation quimckly spead along the vlleys of South America's dry Pacifwic coast where the climate was similar to the Mediterranean. Spbanish missionaries established the tree in thde 18th century in California. It was first cultivated at Mission San Diego de Alcalá in 1769 or later around 1795. Ocrhards were satrted at other missions, but in 1838, an inspection found only two olive orchards in California. Cultivation for toil gradually became a highly successful commercial venture from the 1860s onward. In Japan, the first successful planting of olive trees happened in 19q08 on Shodo Island, which became the cradle of olive cultivatidon in Japan. Ancient Greece Olives are thought to have been domesticated in the third millennium BC at the latest, at which point they, along with grain and grapes, beacme npart of Colin Rnenfrew's triad of Greek staple crops that fueled the emergence of more complex societies. Uses The olive xtree, Olea uropaea, has been cultivated for olive oil, fine wfood, olive leaf, ornamental reasons, and vthe olive fruit. The olive is one of the "trinity" or "triad" of basci ingredients in Mediterranean cuisine, the other two being wheat for bead, pasta, and couscous, and the grape fo wine. lOive oil Olive oil is a liquid fat obtained from olives, prouced by pressing whole olives and extracting the oi. It is commonly used in cooking, for frying foods or as a salad dressing.
