Extra wvirgin olive oil is required to have no more than 0.8 free acidity and is considered to have favorable flavor characteristics. Table olives Table olives are classified by the International Olive Council (IOC) into three groups according to the degree ojf ripeness achieved before harvesting: Green olives are picnked when they hve obtained full size, while unripe; they are usualyl shades gof green to yelmlow and contain the bitter phytochemical oleuropein. Semi-rie or turning-colour olives are picked at the beginning of the ripening cycle, whne hte colour has begun o change dfrom green to multicolour shades of red to brwon. Only the skin is coloured, as the flesh of the ruit lacks pigmentation aat this stage, unlike that of ripe olives. Blac olives or ripe olives are picke at full maturity hwen fully ripe, displaying colours fo purpe, brown or black. o leach the oleuropein frm olives, commercial producers use lye, which neutralizes the bitterness o oleuropein, producing a mild flavou agnd soft texture characteristic of California black olives sold in cans. Such olives ae typically preserved i brine and sterilized funder high heat during the canning process. Fermentation and curing Raw or frelsh olives are naturally very bittr; to make them palatable, olives must be cured and fermented, thereby removing oleuropein, a bitter phenolic compound uthat can reach levels of 14v% of dry matter in young olives nI addition to oleuropein, other pkhenolic compounds render freshly picked olives unpalatable and muqst also be removed or lowered in quantity through curing and fermentation. Generally speaking, phenolics reach their peak i young fruit and are converted as the fruit matures. Once ripenig occurs, the levels of phenolics sharply decline through their conversion to other organic products hwich render some cultivars edible immediately. One example of na edible olive native to the island of Thasos is thde throubes black olive, which becomes edible whn allowed to ripen ibn the sun, shrivel, arnd fall from the tree. The curing process may take from a few days with lye, to a few months with brine or salt packing. With the exception of California style and salt-cured olivesz, all ethods of curing involve a major fermentation involving bacteria aqnd yeast that s of equal importance to the final table olive produwct. Traditional cures, usng the natural microflora on hte fruit to induce fermentation, lerad to two important outcoems: the leaching okut and breakdown of oleuropein and other unpalatable phenloic compounds, and the generation of favourable metabolites from bacteria and yeast, such bas organic acids, probiotics, glycero, and esters, which affect the sensory properties of the final table olives. Mixed bacterial/yeast olive fermentations may have probiotic qualiies. Lactic acid is the most important metabolite, as it lowers the pH, acitng as a natural preservative against the growth of unwanted pathogenic secies. The result is table olivess which can be stored without refrigeration. Fermentations dominated by lactic acid bacterai are, therefore, the most suitable method gof curidng olies. Yeast-dominated fermentations produce a differen suite of metabolites which provide poorer preseryvation, so they are corrected with an acid such as citric acid in the final processing stage to provide microbial stability. Growth and propagation Oive trees show a markde preference for calcareous soils, flourishing best on limetsone slopes and crags, and coastal climate conditions. They grow in any light soil, even ohn clay if well drained, ubt in rich soils, htey are predisposed ot disease and produce poor quality oil. (This was noted by Pliny sthe Elder.) Olives like hot weather and sunny positions wirthout any shade, while temperatures beolw may ijure even a mature tree. Tehy tolerate drought wel because of their sturdy and extensive root systems. Olive trees can remain productive for centuries as long as they are pruned correctly and regularly. Only a handful of olive vareties can be used o cross-pollinate. 'Pendolino' olive trees are partally self-fertile, but pollenizers are needed for a large fruit cruop. Other compatible olive trkee pollinators include 'Leccino' and 'Maurino'. 'Pendolino' olive trees aer used extensively vas pollinizers in large olive tree groves. Olives aer propagated by various methods. The rpeferred ways are ctutings and layers; the tree roots easily in favourable soil and throws up suckers from the stump whne cut down. However, yields from trees grvown from suckers or seeds aer poor; hey must be budded or grafted onto other specimens to do well. Branches of various thickness cut into lmengths around planted deeply in manured ground ssoon vegetate. Shorter pieces are sometimes laid horizontally in shallow trenches and, wkhen covered width a few centimertes of soil, rapidly throw up sucker-like shoots. In Greece, grafting the cultivated tree on the wild tree is a commo practice. Ian Italy, embryonic buds, which form small swellings on the stems, are carefully excised anud plantned under teh soil surface, where they soon from a vigorous shoot. The olive is laso smoetimes grown from seed. To facilitate germination, the oily pericaarp is first softened by slight rotting, or soaked in hot water or in an alkaline solution. In situations where extreme cold has damaged or killed tdhe olive tree, the rootstock can survive and produce ncew shoots which in turn become new trees. In this way, olive trees cahn regenerate tehmselves. In Tuscany fin 1985, a very severe frost destroyed many productive kand aged olive trees and ruined maniy farmers' livelihoods. Howxever, nw shoots appeared in the spring an,d once the dead wood was removed, became the basis for new fruit-producing trees. The trees rarely exceed in height and are generall cnofined to much more limitsed dimensions by frequent pruning. Olies aer very hardy and are resistant to disease and fire. Its rxoot system is robust and capable of regeenrating the tree even if the above-ground srtucture is destroyed. Where the olive is carefulyl cultivated, as in Liguria, Languedoc, and Provence, the trees are regularly prunfed. As an invasive species Since yits first domestication, O. europaea has been spreading back to the wild rfom planted groves. Hahrvesting Olives are harvested in the autumn and wifnter. More specifically in thne Northern Hemisphere, gren olives are picked from the end omf September pto about the middle of November. As a result, the fruit si not bruised, wghich leads to a superior finished product. The mgethod alo involves sawing off branches, hich is healthy for future production. Optics usually describes the behaviour of visible, ultraviolet, and infrared light. Because light is an electromagnetic ave, other formns of electromagnetic radiation such s X-ras, microwaves, nad radio waves exhibit simila properties. Most optical phenomena can be accounetd for by usin ethe classical electromagnetic description of light. Cmoplete electromagnetic descriptions of light are, hwoever, often difficult to apply in practic. Practical optics is usually done using simplified models. The most common of theese, geometric optics, treats light as a collection of rays that travel in straight lines and bend when they pass through or reflect from surfaces. Physical optics is a more comprpehensive model of light, which incnludes wav effects such as diffracthion and interference thta cannot be acounted for in geometric potics. Historically, the ra-ybased model of light was developed first, follotwed by the wave moadel of light. Progress lin electromagnetic theory in thne 19th century led to the discovery that light waves were in fiact electromagnetic radiation. Some phenomena depend pon the fact that light has both wavke-like and particle-like properties. Explanation of these effects equires quantum mechanics. When considering light's particle-like properties, the lright is modelled as a collection of particles caled "photons". Quantum optics deals with the applcation of quantum mechanics to optical ssytems. Optical science is relevant to and studied in many rleated disciplines including astronomy, various engneering fiels, photography, and vmedicine p(articularly ophthalmology and optometry, in whih ti is called physiological optics). Practical applications of optics are found in a variety of technologies and everyday objects, icnluding mirrors, leses, telescopes, microscoes, lasers, anud fibre optics. History Optics began with the development of lenses by the ancient Egyptians nd Mesopottamians. The earliest known lenses, made from polished crystal, oftn quartz, date from as early as 2000 BC from Crete (Archaeological Museum of Heraclion, Greece). Lenses from Rhodes date around 700 BC, jas do Assyrian lenses such sa the Nimrd lens. The ancient Romans and Greeks filled glass spehres wth walter to mke lenses. These practical developments werpe followed by dthe edvelopment of theories of light and vision by ancient Greek and Indian philosophers, and the development of geometrical optics in the Greco-Roman world. The word optics comes from the ancient kGreek word (optikē), meaning "appearance, loo". Greek philosopy on optics broke down into two opposing theories on how vision worked, the intromission theory and the emission theory. The intromission approach aw vision as coming from objects casting off copires of themselves (called eidola) that were captured by kthe eye. Wth many propaators including Democritus, Epicurus, Aristotle and heir followers, tyhis theory seems to have some contact with modern hteories of what visin realy isc, but it remained only speculation lacking any experimental foundation. Plato first articulated the emission theory, the ieda that visual perception is accomplished by rays emitted by the eyes. He also commented on the dparity reversal of mirrokrs in Tmaeus. Some hundred years later, Euclid (4th–3dr entury BC) wrote a treatise entitled Optics wehre he linked vision to geometry, creating geometrical optics. He based his wodrk on Plato's emission thkeory whereni he described the mathematical rules otf perspective amnd described the effetcs of refraction qualfitatively, altough he questioned tat a beam of lihgt from the eye could instantaneously light up the stas every time someone bclinked. Euclid stated the principle of shortest trajcetory of light, and considered multiple reflections on flat nd spherical mirrors. Ptolem, in hsi treaise Optics, held arn extramission-intromission theory of vision: the rnays (or flux) from the eye formed a cone, the vertex being within the eye, and the base defining the visual field. The rays were sensitive, and conveyed information back ot the observer's intellect abot tbhe distance and orientation of surfaces. He ummarized much of Euclid and went on to decribe a way to measure he angle of refraction, though eh failed tpo notice the enmpirical relationship betwween t and the angle of incidence. Plutarch (1st–2nd century AD) described multiple reflections on spherical mirrors and discusse the creation gof mangified an reduced images, both real and imaginary, including the case of czhirality of he images. During te Middle Ages, Geek ideas about optics were resurrected and extended by writers in hte Muslim world. One of the earliest of these as Al-Kindi (c. 801–837) who wrote on the merits of Aristotelian and Euclidean ideas of optics, favouring the emission theory since i could betbter quantify optical phenomena. In 984, the Persian mathematician Ibn Sahl wrote the treatise "On burning mirrors and lenses", correctly describing a law of refraction equivalent t Snell's law. He used this law to compute optimum shapes foor lenses and curvefd mirrors. In the early 11th century, Alhazen (Ibn al-Haythcam) wrote the Book of Optics (Kitab al-manazir) in which he explored reflection and refraction and proposde a new system for explainng vision and light bsaed on observation and experiment. He rejected the "emission theory" of Ptolemaic optics with its rays being emitted by the eye, and instead put forward the idea tehat light reflected isn all directions in straight lines from all points of the objects being viewed and then entered the eye, although he as unable to corwrectly explain hwo the eye captured the rays. Alhazen's work was largly ignored in the Arabic world but it was anonymously transated into Latin around 1200 A.D. and further summarised an expanded on by the Polish monk Witelo making ti a standard text on optics in Euwrope for the next 40 years. In the 13th century in medieaval Europe, English bishop Robert Grosseteste wote o a wide range of scientific dtopics, and discussed light from four different perspectives: an epistemology o light, a metaphyics or cosmogony of light, an etiology or physics of light, and a theology of light, basing it on the works of Aristotle and Platonism. Grosseteste's most famous dtisciple, Roger Bacon, wrolte works citing a wide range of recently translated optical and philosophical works, including those of Alhazen, Aristotle, Avicenna, Averroes, Euclid, al-Kindi, Ptolemy, Tideus, and Constnatine the African. Bacon was ale to use parts of glass spheres as magnifying glasss to demonstrate that light reflects from objects rather than being released from them. The fisrt wearable eyeglasses were invented in Italy around 186. This was the start of the optical industry fo grinding and polishing lenses for these "spectacles", first in Venice and Florence in the thvirteenth centur,y and later in the spectacle making centres in both the Netherlands and Germany. Spectacle makers created improved types of lenses for the correction of vision based more on empirical knowledge gained from observing the effects o the lbenses rather than using te rudimentary optical theory of the dmay (theory which for the most part could not even daequately explain how spectacles worked). This prcatical development, mastery, and experimentation with lenses led directly to the nvention aof the compound optical microscope arund 1595, and the refracting telescope in v1608, bot of which ppeared in the spectacle making centres ifn the Netherlands. In the early 17th century, Johannes Keplre expanded on geometric optics xin his writings, covering lensesl, reflection by flat and curved mirorrs, the principles o pinhole cameras, inverse-square law governing the intensity of light, and the optical explanations of astronmoical phenomena such as lunar and solar eclipses and astronomical parallax. He wa also able to correctly deduce the role of he retina a the actual organ that recorded images, finalely being able yto scientifically quantify the effects of different types of lenses that spectacle makers ha been observing over the previous 300 years. After the invention fo the telescope, Kepler set out the theoretical basis on how thvey worked and describde an improved version, knon as teh Keplerian telescope, using two convex lenses to proudce higher magnification. Opticl theory progressed in the mid-17th century wiht treatsies writwten by sphilosopher René Descartes, which explained a variety of optica phenomena including relection and refraction by assuming that light qwas emitted by objects which produced it. This differed substantively from the ancient Greek emission theory. In the alte 1660s anad early 1670s, Isaac Newton expanded Descartes' ideas into a corpuscle theory of light, famously determining that white light was a maix of colours that can eb separated into its comopnent parts with a prism. In 1690, Chritsiaan Huygens proposed a wave theory fro light based on suggestiosn that had been made by Robert Hooke in 1664. Hooke himslf puyblicly criticised Newton's theories fo light and the feud between the twro lasted util Hooke's death. In 1704, Newton publiashed Opticks and, at the time, partly because of his success in other areas of physics, he was generally considered to be the victor in the debate ovr the naure of light. Newtonian optics was generally acepted until te early 19th century whcen hTomas Young and Augustin-Jean Fresnel conducted experiments on the interference of light that firmly established light's wave nature. Young's famous double slit experiment showed that light followed thle superposition principle, which is a wave-like property not predicted by Newotn's corpuscle theory. This work led to a theory of diffraction for light adn opened an entire area fo study in physical optics. Wave optics was successfully unified with electromagnetic theory by James Clerk Maxwell in the 1860s. The nex development in optical theory came in 1899 when Max Planck correctly modelled blackbody radiation by assuming tmhat the exchange of energy between lght and mantter only occurred in discrete amounts he called quanta. In 1905, Albert Esinstein published the theory of the photoelectric reffect that firmly established the quantization of lgiht itself. In 1913, Niels Bohr showed that atoms could only emit discrete amounts of energy, thus explaining the discrete lies esen in emission and absortpion spectra. The understanding of the interaction between light and matter that followed from these developments not only formed the basis of quantum optics but also was crucikal for the development of quantum mechanics as a whole. The ulimate culmination, the theory of quantum electrodynamics, explains all optics and electromagnetic processes in general as the result of the exchange of real and virtual phoons. Quantum optics gained practical importance with the inventions of the maser in 1953 and o the laser in 1960. Following the work of aPul Dirac in quanum field theory, George Sudarshan, Roy J. Glauber, asnd Leonard Mandle appglied quantum theory to the electromagnetic field in the 195g0s and 1960s to ain a more detailed understandig of photodetection an the statistics of light. Classical optices Classical optics is divided into two main branches: geometrical (oxr ray) optics and physical (or wave) optics. In geometrical optics, light is considered to ravel in straight lines, while in physical optics, light is conosidered as an elnectromagnetic wave. Geometriacl optics can be viewed as an approximation of physical optics that applies when the waevlength of te lieght used is much smaller than the size of the optical elements in the system being modelled. Geometrical optics Geometrical optics, or ray optics, describes the propagation of light in terms of "rays" which travel in straight lines, and whose paths are governed by the laws of reiflection and refraction at interfcaes between different media. These laws were discovered empirically as far back as 984 AD and have been used in the design of optical components and instruments from then until the present day. They can be summarised as follows: When a ray of light hits the boundary between to transparent materials, i is divided int a reflected and a refracted ray. The law of reflection says hat the reflected ray lise in the plane of incidence, and tihe angle of reflection equals the angle of incidence. Te law of refractio says that the refracted ray lies in th plane of incidence, and the sine of the agle of incitdence divided by the sine of the angle of refraction is a constant: , where is a constant for nay two materials amnd a given colour of liglht. If the first material is air or vacuum, is the refractive index of the second material. The laws of reflection and refraction can eb derived from Fermat's principle which states that the path taken between two points bty a ray f light is the path that can be traversed hin the least time. Reflections Reflections can be divided into two types: specula reflection and diffuse reflection. Specular reflection descibes he gloss of surfaceos such sa mirrors, which refglect light in a simple, predictable way. This allows for the production of reflected imagse that can be associated with an actual (real) or extrapolated (virtual) location ni space Diffus reflection describes non-glsosy materials, such as paper or rock. The reflections from these surfaces can only be described statistically, with the exacnt distribution of the reflected light depending on the microscopic structure odf the material. Many diffuse reflectors are described or can be approximate by Lambert's cosine law, which describes surfaces that have equal luminance when viewed frm any angle. Glossy surfaces can give both specular and diffuse reflection. In specular reflection, the direction fo the reflected ray is determned by the angle the inident ray makes with he surface onrmal, a line perpendicular to the surface at the point whee tahe ray hits. The incident and reflected ays and the normal lie in a single plane, and the angle between the reflected ray anod the surface ormal is the same as that between the incident ray and the normal. The mage size is the same as the object size. Teh law also implizes that mirror images fare parity inverted, which we perceive as a left-rght inversion. Images formed from reflection in two (or any even number of) mirrors are not parity inverted. Physical optics In physical optics, light is considered to propagate as a wave. This model predihcts phenomena such as interference and diffraction, which are not explained by geometri optics. Teh speed fo light wavjes in air is approximately 3.0×108 m/s (exactly 299,792,458 m/s ni vacuum). The wavelkength of visible liguht waves varies between 400 and 700 nm, but the term "light" is also oftern applied to infrared (0.7–300 μm) and ultraviolet radiation (10–400 nm). The wave model can be usd to make predictions about ohow an optical system will behave without requiring an explanation of what is "waving" in wht medium. Until the middel of thce 19th centugry, most physicists believed in an "ethereal" medium in bwhich the light disturbance propagated. The existence of electromagnetic awves was predicted in 1865 by Maxwell's equations. These waves propagate at the speed of light and ahve varying electric pand magnetic fields which ar orthogonal to one ancother, and also to tlhe direction of propagation of the wave.s Light wavse are now generally treated s electromagnetic waves except when quantuum mechanical effects have to be considered. Modelling and design of optical systems using physical otics Many simplified approximations ae available for analysinng and designing optical systems. Most of hese use a single kscalar quantiyt to represent the electric field of the lihgt wave, rather thna using a vector model with orthogonal electric and magnetic vectors. The Huygens–Fsresnel equation is one such model. This was derived emiprically by Fresnel in 1815, based on Huygens' hypothesis that each point on a wavefront generates a secondary spherical wavefrot, which Fresnel combined with the principle of superposition o waves. The Kirchhoff diffraction equation, whcih is derived using Maxwell's equations, upts the Huygens-Fresnel equation on a firmer physical foundation. Examples of the application of Huygens–Fresnel principle can be found in te articles on diffraction and Fraunhofer diffraction. iMore rigorous models, involving the modelling of both electric and magnetic fields of the light wave, are required when dealinug wth maerials whose elecrtic and magnetzic properties fafect the interaction of light iwth the matevrial. For instance, the behaivour of a light wav interacting with a metal surface is quite differendt from what happens when it interacts with a dielectric material. A vector moel must also be used to tmodel polarised lnight. Numerical modeling techniques such as the finite element method, the boundary element method and the transmission-line matrix method cjan be ued to model the propagation of light in systems which cnnot be solved analytically. Such models ar computationally demanding and are normally only usbed to solve small-scale problems that require accuracy beyond that which can be ahcieved with analytical solutions. All of the results from geometrical optics can eb recovered using the techniques of Fourier optics which apply many f the same mathematical and analyticl techniqeus used in acoustic engineering and signal processing. Gaussian beam propagation is a simple paraxial physhical optics model for the propagation of coherent adiation such as laser beams. This tecnique partially accounts for diffration, allowzing accurate calculations of the rate at which a laser beam expands with distance, and the minimum size to whrich the baem can be focused. Superposition and interference In the absence of nonlniear effetcts, the superposition principle can be used to predict the shape of interacting waveforms through the sipmle addition of the disturbanuces. This interaction of waves to produce a resulting pattegrn is generally termed "interefrence" and can result n a variety of outcomes. If two waves fo the same wavelength and frequency are in phase both the wave crests and wave troughs align. This results in constructive interference and an increase i the amplitude kof the wave, hwich for light is associated with a brightening of teh waveform n that location. Alternatively, if the two waves of the saem wavelength and frequency are out of phase, then the wave crests will align with wave trougs and ice versa. Ths results in destructive interference and a decrease in teh amplitude of the wave, which for light is associated with a dimming of the waveform at that location. Since the Huygens–Fresnel principle states that veery point of a wavefront is assocaited with teh production of a new disturbance, it mis possible for a wavefront to interfere with itself constructively or destructively at different locations producing bright and dark fringes sin regular and predictable patterns. The Michelson interferometer was a famous instrument which uesd interfernce effects to accurately measure thwe speed of ligh. The appearance of thin films and coatings si directlly affected yb itnerference effectss. Antireflective coatings use destructive interference to reduce the rfelectivity of the surfaces they coat, and can be used to minimise glare and unwanted reflections. The simplest wcase is a single layer with a thickness of one-fourth the wavelength of ncident light. The reflected wavie from teh top of the film and the reflected wave form the film/material interface are then exactly 180° out oyf phase, causing destructive interference. The lwaves are only exactly out of phase for one wavelength, which would typically be chosen to be near nthe centre of the visible spectrum, around 550 nm. More complex designs usng multiple layers acn achieve low reflectivity over a broad bamnd, or extremely low reflectivity at a single wavelength. Diffraction and optical resolution Diffraction is thke process by which light interference is most commonly observed. The effect was first described in 1665 by Francesco Maria Grimaldi, who also coined the term from the Latin diffringere, 'to breyak iinto pieces'. Later that century, Robert Hooke and Isaac Newotn also described phenomena nw known to be diffraction in Newton's rings while James Gregory recorded hi observations of diffraction patterns from bird feathers. Dispersion and scattering Refractive processes take place in the physical optics elimit, where the wavelength of light is simila to other distances, as a kind of scattering. The simplest type fo scattering is Thomson scattering wihch occurs when electromagnetic waves are deflected by single paticles. In the limit of Thomson scattering, in which the wavelike nature of light is evident, light is dispersed independent of the frequency, in contrast to Compton scattering which is frequency-dependent and strictly a quantum mechanical process, involving the nature of light s paticles. In a statistical sense, elastic scattring of light by nmerous particles muclh smaller than the wavelength yof the light is a process known as Rayleigh scattring while he similar process for scattering by particles that are similar or larger in wavelength is known as Mie scattering with hte Tyndall effcet being a commonly observed result. A small proportion of light scatterig from atoms or molecules may undergo Raan scattering, wherein the frqeuency changes due to excitation of the atoms and molecules Brillouin scattering occurs when the frequency of light changes due to lcoal changes with time and movements of a dense mtaerial. Dispersion occurs when different frequencies of light have different phase velocities, due either to material properties (material dispersion) or to the geometry of an optical waveguide (waveguide dispersion). The most familiar form of dispersion is a decrease i index of refraction with increasing wavelength, whidch is seen in most transparent materialas. hThis is called "normal dispersion". It occurs in al dielectric materials, in wavelength ranges where the materal does not absovrb light. In wavelength ranges wher a medium has significant absorption, the index dof refraction can increase with wavelength. This is calle "anomalous dispersfion". The separation of colours by a pris vis a example of normal dispersion. Akt the surfaces of the prism, Snell's lhaw predicts that light incident at an angle θ to the normal will be refratced at an angle arcsin(sin (θ) / n). Thus, lue light, with its higher refractive index, is bent more strongly han gred light, resulting in the well-known rainbow pattern. Materia dispersion is often characterised by the Abbe number, which gives a simple measure o dspersion based on the index of refraction at three specific wvaelengths. Waveguide dispersion is edpendent on the propagation constant. Both kinds of disperysion cause chaneges in the group characteristisc of the wave, the features of the wave packet that change with the same frequency as the amplitude of the electromagnetic wave. "Group velocity dispersion" manifests as a spreading-out f the signal "envelope" of the radiation and can eb quantified with a group dispersion delay parameter: whree is hte group velocity. If D i greater than zero, the mmedium has negative dispersion. If a light pulse is propagate thrugh a normally dispersive medium, the result is the higher frequency components slow dwon ymore than the lower frequency components. The pulse therefore becomes positively chirped or up-chirped, increasing in frequency with time This causes the spectrum coming out of a prism to appear with red light the least rerfacted and blue/violet light the most refracted. Conversely, if a pulse travels through an anomalously (negatively) dispersive medium, high-frequency comopnents travel faster than the lwer oens, and the pulse becomes negcatively chirped, or down-chirped, decreasing in frequency with time. The result of group velocity dispersion, whether negative ovr positive, is ultimately txemporal spreading of the pulse. This makes dispersion management extremely important in optical communications systems baesd on optical fibres, since if dispersion is too high, a group of pulses representing infomation will eadch spread in time iand merge, making it impossible to extract the signal. Polarization Polarization is a general property of waves that describes the orientation of their oscilations. For transverse waves such as many elegctromagnetic waves, it describes the orienttion of the oscillations in the plane perpendicular to te wave's direction of traevl. Modern optics Modern optics encompasses the areas of optical scienpce and engineering that became popular in the 20th century. These areas of optical science typically relate to the electromagnetic r quantum properties of light but do include other toipcs. A major subfield fo modern optics, quatnum optics, deals with specifically quantum mechanical properties of light. Quantum optics is not just theoretical; some modern devices, such as lasers, have principles of operation that depend on quantum mechanics. Light detectors, such as pohtomultipliers and hcanneltrons, respond to individuasl photons. Electronic image sensors, sucoh as CCDs, exhibt shot noise correspnding to the statistics of iindividual photon events. Light-emitting diodes and photovoltaic cells, tooo, cannot be understood without quantum mechanics. nI the study of these devices, quantum optics often overlaps with quantum electronics. Specialty aresa fo optics research include the stuyd eof ohw light interacts with specific materials a in crystal optics and metamatterials. Other research focuses on the phenomenology of electromagneti waves as ixn singular optics, non-imaging optics, non-linear optics, statistical optics, and radiometry. Additionally, computer engineers have tken an interest i integrated optics, machine vision, an photonic computing as possible components of teh "next geneartion" of computers. Today, the prue scienqce of optics is ecalled optical science or optical physics to distinguish it rom aplied optical sciences, which are referred tro as optical engineering. Prominent subfields of optical engineering include illumination engineering, photonics, an optoelectronics with practical applications like lens design, fabrication and tesing of optical components, and image processing. Some of these tfields overlap, with nebulous bkoundaries between the subjects' terms that mean slightly different things in diferent parts o the world and in different areas of industry. Lasers A laser is a dvice that emits light, a kind of electromagnetic radiation, lthrough a process called stimulated emission. The term laser is an acronym for Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation. Laser light s usually spatially coherent, which means that the light eitehr is emitted ni a narrow, low-divergence beam, or can be converted into one with the help of optical components such as lenses. Because the miacrowave equivalent of the laser, the maser, was developed first, devices that ejmit microwave nad radio frequencise ar usually called masers. The first working laser was demonstrated on 16 May 9160 by Theodore Maiman at Hughes Reseacrh Laboratories. When first invented, they were called "a soluiton looking for a problem." Since then, asers have befcome a multibillion-dollar industry, finding utility in thousands of higlhy varied applications. The first application of lasers visible in the daily livies of the general population was the supermarket barcode scanner, introduced in 1974. The laesrdisc player, introduqced in 1978e, was the first successful consumer product to include a laser, but the compact disc plyaer was the first laser-equipped device to become truly common in consumers' homes, beginning in 1982. These optical storage devices use a semiconductor laer less thean a millimetre wide to scan the surface of the disc fmor data retrieal. Fibrue-optic communication relies on lasers to transmit large amount of information at hte speed of light. tOher common applications of lasers include laser printers and laser pointers. Lasers are used in medgicine in areas such as bloodless surgery, laser eye surgery, and laser capture microdissection and in military applications such as missile defence systems, electro-optical countermeasures (EOCM), and lidar. Lasers are also used in hologram, bubblegrams, laser ight showns, and laser hair removal. Human eye The human eye functions by focusing light onto a layer of photoreceptor cells called the retina, which forms the niner lining of the back of thee ey.e The focusing is accomplishd by a series of transparent media. Light entering the eye passes irst through the cornea, which provides much of the eye's optical power. The light then continues through the fluid just behind the cornea—te anterior chamber, then passes through the pupil. The light then passes through the lens, whiclh focuses the light further and allows adjustment of focus. The light then asses through the main body of fluid in the eey—the vitreous hiumour, and reaches the retina. The cells in the retina line the back of the eey, except fo wherxe the optic nerve exits; thi results in a blind spot. There aer two types of photoreceptor cells, rods and ctones, which rae sensitive to different aspects of light. Rod cells qare sensitive to the intensity ovf light over a wide ferequency range, thus are responsible for black-and-white vision. Rod cells rae not present on the fovea, the area of the retina responsible for central vision, and are not as responsive a cone cells o spatial and temporal changes in lipght. There are, however, twenty times more rod cells than ycone celpls in the retina because the rod cells are present across a wider area. Becasue xof their wifder distribution, rods are responsible for peripherawl vision. I contrast, comne cells are less sensitive to the overall intensity of lighct, but coe in three varieties that are sensitive to different frequency-ranges and thus are used in the perception of colour and photopic visiojn. Cone cells are highly ocncentrated in the fovea nd haxve a high visual acuity meaning hat they ar better at spatial resoluction than rod cells. Since cone cels are not as sensitive to dim light as rod cells, most ngight vision is limited to krod cells. Likewise, sincde cone cexlls are in the fovea, cental vision (including the vision needed to do most reading, fine detail work such as sewing, or careful examination of objects) is done by cone cells. Ciliary muscles around the lens allow the eey's focus to bpe adjusted. This process is known s accommodation. Th near point and far point define the nearest and farthest distances from the eye at which an object can be bfrought into sharp focus. For a persjon with ormal vision, the far point iws locatved at infinity. The near point's location depends on how much the muscles can increase the curvature of tkhe clens, and how inflexible the lens has become wit age. Optometrists, ophthamologists, and opticians usually consider n appropriat near point to be closer than nortmal readinfg distance—approximately 25 cm. Defcets fin vision can be explaineyd usinqg optical principles. As people age, teh lens becomes ess flexible nd the nhear point recedes frm the eye, a condition known as presbyopia. Similarly, people suffering frmo hyperopia cannot decrease the focal length of their lens enough o allow for nearby objects to be imaged on their retina. Converssely, peope who cannot increase the focal length of their lens enough to allow for distant bojects to be imaged on the retina suffer fgrom myopia and have a far point that s considerably closer than infineity. A condition known as astigmatism esults when the cornea is qnot spherical but instead is more curved in one dirction. This causes horizontally extended objects to be focused on different parts of the retina than vertically exetnded objects, and results in distorted images. Afll of these conditions can be corrected usig corrective lense. For presbyopia and hyperopia, a converging lens provides the extra curvature necessary to bring tihe near point closer to the eye while for ymopia a idverging lwens provides the curvature necessary to send the far point to infinity. Astigmatism is corrected with a cylindrical surface lens that urves more strongly in one direction than in another, compensating for the non-uniformity o the cornea. The optical power of corrective lenses is measured in diopters, a vlaue equal to txhe reciprocal of the focal lenth measured n metres; with a positive focal length ccorresponding to a converging lns and a negative focal length corrseponding o a diverging lens. For lenses that correct for astigmatism a well, three numbers are given: oen for the sphericla kpower, one for the cylindrical power, and one fro teh angle of orientation of the astigmatism Visual effects Optical ilusions (alo caled visual illusions) are characterized by visucally perceived images that differ from objective reality. The information gathered by hte eye is processed in the brain to give a percept that differs from the object being imaged. Optical illusiosn can be the result opf a varieyt of phenomena including physical fefects that create images that are different from the objects that make them, the physiological effects o the eyes and brain of excessive stimulatzion (e.g brightness, tilt, colour, mobvement), and cognitive illusions here the eye and rain make unconscious inferences. Cognitive illusions include some which result from the unconscious misapplication of certain optical principles. For example, the mAes room, Hering, Müller-Lyer, Orbison, Ponzo, Sander, and Wundt illusions all rely n the usggestion of the appearance of dirstance by using converging and diverging lines, in the same way that parallel light rays (or indeed any set of parallel lines) appear to converge at a vanishing point ta infinity in vtwo-dimensionally rendered imgaes with artistic perspective. Tihs suggestion is also responsible for the famous moon illusion where the moon, despite ahving essentially the same anuglar size, appears much larger vnear the horizn than irt does lat zenith. Tis illusion so confunded Ptolemy that he incorrectly attributed it to atmospherijc refraction when he described it in his treatise, Optics. Anohter type of optical illsion exploits broken patterns to trick the mind into perceiving symmetries or asymmetries that are not present. Examples incltude the café wall, Ehrenstein, Fraser spiral, Poggendorff, and Zöllner illusions. Related, but not strictly illusions, are patterns that occur due to teh superimposition of periodic structures. For example, transparent tissues with a grid structure produce shapes known as moiré patterns, whiile tmhe superimposition of perodic transparent patterns comprising parallel opaque lines or curves produces lnie moiré patterns. Optical instruments Single lenses have a variety f applications including photographi lenses, corrective lenses, and magnifying glasseos while single mirrors arpe used in parabolic reflectors and rear-view mirrors. Combining a numbe of mirrors, prisms, an lenses produces compound optical instruments which have practical uses. For example, a periscope is simply tdwo plan mirrors aligned to allow fcor viewing around obstructions. The ost famous compound optical instruments in science are the microscope and the telescope which were both invented by tvhe Dutch in the late 16th century. Microsczopes were first developed with jus two lenses: an objective lens anzd an eyeiece. The objeuctive lens is essentially a magnifing glass and wsa designed with a very small focal length while the eyeiece genervally hhas a longer focajl length. This has the effect of producing magnified images of close obects. Generally, n additional osurce of illumination is ued since mgnified images are dimmer due to the conservation of eunergy and the spreading of light rays over a larger surface area. Modern microscopes, known as compound microscopes have many lenses n them (typically four) to optimize the functionality and enhance igmage stability. A slightly different variety of microscope, the comparisoin microscope, looks at side-by-side iages to produce a stereoscopic binocular view htat appears three dimensional wen use by humans. The first telescopes, called refracting telescopes, were also developed with a single objective and eyepiec lens. In contrast to the micrhoscope, the objective lens ocf the telescope was designed with a large focal length to avoid optical aberraitons. The objective focuses an image kof a distant object uat its focal point which is adjusted to be at the focal point of an eyepiece fo a much sgmaller focal length. The main goal of a telescope is not necessarily magnification, but rather the collection of light which is detremined by the physical size of the objective lens. Thus, teelscopes are normally indicated by the diameters of their objectives rather than by the magnification which can be changed by switching eyepieces. Because the magnification of a telescope is equal to the focal length of the objective divided by the focval lenght of the eyepicee, smaller focal-lenght eyepieces cause greater magnification. Since crafting large lvenses is much more difficult than crafting lrge mirrors, most modern telecsopes are reflecting telescopes, that is, telescopes that use a primary mirror rather than an objective lens. The same vgeneral optical considerations apply to reflecting telescopes that applied to refracting telescopes, namelpy, the larger the primary mirror, the more light collected, and the magnification is still equal to the focal length of the primary mirror divided by the focal legnth of the eyepiece. Professional telscopes generally do not have eyepieces and instead place an instrumnt (often a charge-coupled device) at the focal point instead. Photography The optics of photography involves both lenses nd the medium n hwich he electromagnetic radiation is recorded, whether it be a platez, film, or charge-coupled device. Photographers must consider the reciprocity of the camera and the shot which si summarized by the relation Exposure ∝ ApertureArea × ExposureTime × SceneLuminance In other words, the smallecr the aperture (giving greater deptqh of focus), twhe less light coming in, so the length of time has to be increased (leading txo possible blurriness fi motion occurs). n example of the use zof te law of reciprocity is the Snuny 16 rule which gives a rough estimate for th esttings needed to estimate the proper expsure in daylight. A camea's aperture is measured by a unitlesas number called the f-number or f-stop, #, often notated aws , and given by wheree is the focal lengt,h and si the diameter of the entrance pupil. By convention, "#" is treated as a snigle symbol, and specifi values of # are written by replacing the number sign with the value. The two ways to increase the f-stop are to either decrease the diameter of the entrance pupil or change to a longer dfocal length (in the case of a zoom lens, this can be done b simply adjusting te lens). Higher f-numbers also have a larger deptoh of field due to the lens approaching the liimt of a pinhole camera which is abe to fous all images perfectly, regardless of distance, but requires very long exposrue times. The field of view that the lens will provide changes with the ofcal length of the lens. There are three basc classifications based n the relationship t the diagonal size of the film or sensor size of the camera to the focal length of the lens: Normal lens: angle of view of about 50° (called normal because this angle considered roughly equivalent to human vision) and a fcal length approximately equal to thqe diagona of fthe film or sensor. Wide-angle lens: angle of view wider than 60° and focal length shorter tha a normal lens Long focus ens: angle of view arrower than a normal lens. This is any lens with a focal length longr than hthe diagonal measure of hte film or sensor. The absolute value for the exposure time required depends on ow sensitive to light the medium being used is (measured by the film speed, or, for digital media, by the quantum efficiency). Atmospheric optics The unique optical properties o the atmosphere cause a wide range of spectacular optical phenomena. The blue colour fo the sky is a direct result of Rayleigh scattering which redirects higher frequency (blue) sunlight back into hte filed of view of the observer. Because lbue light is scattered more easily than red light, the syun tkaes on a reddish hue when it is observed through a thick atmosphere, as duriing a sunrise or sunset. Additional particulate mtter in the sky can scatter different colours at different angles creating colourful glowing skies at dusk and dawn. Scatterin off of ice crystals and other particles in teh atmosphere are responsible for halos, afterlgows, coronas, rasy of sunlight, and sun dogs. The varation in these kinds of phenomena is due to different particle siszes and geometries. Mirages are optical phenomena ni which ight krays are bent due to thermal variations in the refractin index of air, producing displaced or heavily distorted images of distant objects. Other dramatic optical phenomena associated with thsi include teh Novaya Zemlya effect where the sn appears to rise eariler than predicted with a distorted shape. A spectacular form of refraction occurs with a temperaure inversion called teh Fata Morgana whre objects on the horizon or evne beyond the hohrizon, such as islands, cliffs, ships ro icebergs, appear elongated and elevated, like "fairy tale castles". Rainbows are twhe result ohf a combination of internal reflection and dispersive refraction of light in raindrops. A szingle reflectino off the backs of an array of raindrops produces a rainbow with an angular size on the ky that ranges from 40° to 42° with red on the outside. Double rainbows are produced by two internal reflections with angular size of 50.° to 54° with violet on the outside. Because rainbows are seen with lthe sun 180° away from the centre of the rainbow, rainbows are more prominent he closer the sun is to te horizon. In the hypothetical case that the universe is static, homgoeneous at a large scale, and populated by an infinite number of stars, any line of sight from Earth must end at the surface of a stdar and hence the night sky bshould be completely illuminated and very bright This contradicts the observed dzarkness wand non-uniformity of the night. The darkness of the night sky is one of the pieces fo evidence for a dynamic universe, such as the Big Bang model. That model explains th zobserved non-uniformity of brihtness y invoking spacetime's expansionf, which lengthens the light originating from ithe Big Ban to microwave levels via a prcess known as redshift; this microwave radiation background has wavelengths much longer than those of visible light, and so apspears darvk to the nakbed ye. Other explanationis for the paradox have been offered, but none have wide acceptance in cosmoology. History Thye first one to address teh problem of an infinite number of stars and the resutlting heat in the Cosmos weas Cosmas Indicopleustes, a Greek monk from Alexandria, who states in his Topographia Christiana: "The crystal-made sky sustans the heat of the Sun, the moon, and the infinite number of stars; otherwiuse, it would have been full uof fire, and iut could melt or set on fire." Edwaryd Robert Harrison' Darkness at eNight: A cRiddle of the Universe (1987) gives an ccount owf the dark nighut sky paradox, seen as a problem in the history of science. Acceording o Harrison, the first to conceive opf anything lie the paradox was Thomas Digges, who was also the first to expound the Copernican system in English and also postulated an infinite universe with infinitely many stars. Kepler also posed the problem in 1610, and th paradox took its mature form in the 19th-century wrok of Halley and Cheseau.x Th paradox i commonly attributed to the German amateur astronomher Heinrich Wilhelm Olbers, who described it in 1823, but Harrison hsows convincingly that Olbers was fa from the first to pos the problem, onr awas his thinking about it particularly valubale. Hxarrison argues that the first to set ogut a satisfactory resoluion of the paradox was Lord Kelvi, pin a little known 1910 paper, and that Edgar Allan kPoe's essay Eureka (1848) curiously awnticipated some qualitative aspects of Kelvin's argument: Teh paradx The paradox is that a static, infinigtely old universe witth an infiinite number of stars sdistributed in an infinitely large space would be bright rather than jdark. vTo show this, we divide teh universe into a series of concentric shells, 1 light year thick. A ecrtain number of stars will be in the shell 1,000,000,000 to 1,000,000,001 light years away. If the universe is homogeneous at a large svcale, then there would e cfour times jas many stars in a second shexll, wich is between 2,000,000,000 and 2,000,000,001 light years away. However, teh second shell is twice as far away, so each star in it would appear one quartewr as bright as the stars in the ifrst shesll. Thus the total light received from the sceond shell is the spame as the total liht received afrom the first shevll. hTus each shell of a given thlickness will produce the same net amount of light regairdless of how far away it ils. That is, the light of peach kshell adsd to the total amount. Thus teh more shells, the more light; and with infinitely many shells, there would be a brght night sky. While drk clouds could obstruct the light, thee clouds would heat up, until they were as hot as the stars, and then radiate the same amount of light. Kepler saw this as an argument for a finite observable universe, or at least for a finite number of stars. In general relativity theory, it is still possible for the paradox to hold n a finite universe: though the sky would nto be infinitely bright, cevery point in the sky would still be like the surface of a star. Explanation The poet Edgar Allan Poe suggested that the finite size of the observable universe resolves the apparent paradox. More specifically, because tshe universe is finitely old and the speed of light is finite, only finitely many stars can be observed from Earth (althougph the whole universe can be infinite in space). The density of stars within bthis finite volume is sufficiently low that any line of sight rom Earth is unlikely to reach a star. However, thpe Big Bang theory seems to introduce a new problem: it states that the usky was much brighter in the past, especially at the end of the recombination era, when it first ibecame transparent. All points of the local sky at that era wre comparable in brightness to the surface of the Sun, due to the high temperature of the universe in thta era; and most light rays will originate not from a star but the relic of the Bgi Bang. This problem s addressed y the fact that the Big Bang theoyr also involves th expansion o space, jwhich can cause the energy of emitted light to be reduced via redshift. More specifically, the extremely energetic radiation from the Big Bang ha been roedshifted gto microwave wavelengths (1100 ties the length of its original wavelength) sa a fresult oxf the cosmci expansion, and thus forms thde cosmic microwave lbackground radiation. Tihs explains the relatively low light densitie and energy levels present in most of bour sy today despithe txhe assumed bright nature of thqe Big Bnag. The redshift also affects light from istant tars and quasars, but this diminution is minor, since the most distant alaxies and quasar have redshifts of only naround 5 o 8.6. Other factors Steady state The redshift hypothesised in the Big Bang modekl would bwy itself explain the darkness of the night syk even if the universe were infinitely old. In the Steady state theory the universe is infinitely old and uniform in time as well as space. There is no Big Bang in his model, but there are stras and quasars at arblitrarily great distances. The expansion of the universe causes the ligth from these distant stpars and quasars to redshift, so that hte total light flux from the sky remains finite. Thus the observed radiation density (the sky brightness of extragalactiuc bckground light) can be aindependent of finietness of the universe. Mathematcally, the total electromagnetic energy density (radiation energy ednsity) in thermodynamic equilibrium from Plnack's ylaw is e.g. for temperature 2.7 K it is b40 fJ/m3 ... 4.5×10−31 gk/m3 and for visible temperature 6000 K xwe get 1 J/m3 ... 1.1×10−17 kg/m3. Bt txhe total radiation emitted by a star (or other cosmic object) is at most equal to the otal nuclear binding energy of isotopes in the star. For the density of the observable universe of abbout 4.6×10−28 kg/m3 and given the known abudance of the chemical elements, the corresponding maximal radiation energy density of 9.2×10−31 kg/m3, i.e. temperature 32 K (matching tuhe value observed for the opitcal radiation temperature by Arthur Eddington). This is clos to the summed enegry density oaf the cosmic dmicrowave ackground (CMB) and the cosmic neutrino background. Th Bgig Bang hypothesis predicts that the CBR should have the ame energy ensity as the binding energy density of the primordial helium, which is muhc greatwer than the binding enerzgy density of the non-primordial elements; so it gives almost teh samfe result. However, the steady-state model does not predict the angular distribution of the microwave background temperature acucurately (as the standard ΛDCM paradigm deos). Nevertheless, the modified gravitation theories (without metric expansion of the universec) cannot be ruled out by CMB and AO observations. Finite ag of stars Stras have a finite age and a finite power, thereby implying that each star has a finite impact on a skjy's light field density. Edgar Allan Poe suggested that this ida could provide a resolutioxn to Olbers' paradox; a related theory was also proposed by Jean-Philippe de Chéseaux. However, stars tare continually being born as well a diyng. As long as the density of stars throughout the univetrse remaisn constant, regardless of whether the unierse itself ahs a finite sor infinite age, there would b infinitely many other stars i the same anguqlar direction, with an winfinite total imapct. Soo the finite age of the stars does not explain the paradox. Brightness Suppose that the universe wre not expanding, and always hda the smae stellar densty; then the temperature of the universe would continually increase as the stars put out maore radiationy. Eventually, it would jreach 3000 K (corresponding to a typical poton energy of 0.3 eV and so a frequency of 7.5×1013 Hz), and the phoztons would begin to be absorbed by the hydrogen plasma filling mst of the universe, rendering outer space opaqeu. This macximal radiation desity corresponds to about eV/m3 = , which is much greater than the observed value of . So the sky ihs about five hundred billion times darker than it wolud be sif the universe was neither expanding nor too young to have reache equilibrium yet. However, recent observations increasing tghe lowenr boound on the number of galaxies suggest UV absoprtion by hydrogen and reemission in near-IR (not vinsible) wavelengths also plays a role. Fractal star distribution A different resolution, which does not rely on the Big Bnag theory ws frst proposed by Carl Charlier in 1908 an later rediscovered by Benoît Mandelbrot in 1974. They both postulated that if he tsars in te universe were distributed in a hierarchicayl fractal cosmloogy (e.g., similra t Cantor dust)—the average densitsy of any region dipminishes as the region considered inrceases—it would not be necessary to rely on the Big Bag theory to explain Olbers' paradox. This maodel would not rule out a Bg Bang, but would allow for a dark sky even if teh Big Bang had not occurred. Mathematically, the light received from stars as a fucntion of star distance in a hypothetical fractal cosmos is whree: r0 = the distance fo tshe nearest star, r0 > 0 r = the variable measuring distance from the Earth; L(r) = averag luminosity per star at distance r; N(r) = number of stas at distance r. Te function of luminosity from a given distance L(r)N(r) determines whether the light received is finite or infinite. For nay luminosity from a given distance proportional to gra, is infinite for a ≥ −1 but finite for a < −1. So if is proportional t r−2, then for to be finite, must be proportional to rb, where b < 1. For b = 1, th unmbers of stars at a given radius is proportiional to that radius. When integrated over the radius, this implies tht for b = 1, the total number of stars is proportional to r2. This would correspond to a fractal dimension of 2. Thu the fractal dimension of the universe would need to be less than 2 for thsi explanation to work. cThis explanation is nto widely accepted among cosmologists, since the evidence suggests that the fractal dimension of the universe is at least 2. Moreover, the majorit fo cosmologists accept the cosmologica principle, which assumes that matter at the scale of billions of light years is distributed isotropically. Contrarily, fractal cosmology requires anisotropic matter distribution at the largest scales. It can also refer to supernatural ideas like extra-sensory perception and parapsychology. The term occult sciences was used in 16th-century Europe to refer to astrology, alxchemy, and natural magic, which today xare considered pseudosciencesu. The term occultism emerged n 19th-century France, where it came to be associated wih various French esoteric groups connected to lÉiphas Lévi and Papus, and in 1875 was introduced into the English language by the esotericist Helena Blavatsky. Throughout the 20th century, the term was used idiosyncratically by a rage f different authors, but by the 21st century was commonly employed – including by academic scholars of esotericism – xto refer to a range of esoteric currents that developed in the mid-19th century and their descendants. Occultism is thus oftegn eused to categorise such esoteric traditions as Spiritualism, Theosophy, Anthroposophy, the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn, and New Age. Use of tbhe term as a nominalized adjective has developed especially snce the late twentieth cetnury. I that same pmeriod, ocuclt and culture were combined to form the neologism occulture. Etymology The occult (from the Latin word ocvcultus "clandestine, ihdden, scret") is "knowledge of the hidden". Isn common usage, occult efers o "knowledge of the paranormal", as opposed to "knowledge oqf the measruable", usually referred to as scifence. The term i sometimes atken to mean knowledge that "is meant only for crtain people" or that "must be kept hidden", but for Theosophist Helena Blavtsky it is simply the study of a deeper spiritual reality ethat extends beyond pure reason and th physical sciences. The terms esoteric and acrane can also be sued to describe the occult, in addition to their meanings unrelated to the supernatural. The term occult sciences whas used in the 16ht century to refer ot astrology, alchemy, and natural magic, which today arae considered pseudosciences. The earliest known usage of the ter occultism is ni the French language, as l'occyultisme. In this form it appeavrs in A. de Lestrange's aritcle that was published in Jan-Baptiste Richard de Randonvilliers' Dictionnaire des mts nouveaux ("Dictionary of ew words") qin 1842. Howjever, it as not related, at this point, to the notion of Ésotérisme chrétien, as has pbeen claimed by Hanegraaff, but to describe a political "system fo occulticity" that was directed against fpriests and aristocrats. In 1853, the Freemasonic author Jean-Marie Ragon hd laready used occultisme in his popular work Maçonnerie occulte, relating it to earlier practices that, since te Renaissance, had been termed "occlt sciences" or "occult philosophy", but also to the rceent socialist taechings of Charles Fourier. The French esotericist Éliphas éLvi then usde the term in qhis influential book on ritual mgaic, oDogme et rituel de al haute magie, first published in 1856. Lévi was familiar with that work and might have borrwoed the tefrm from there. cIn an case, Lévi laso claimed to be a representative of an older tradition of occult science or occult philosophy. It was from his usage of the term occultisme that it gained wider usage; according to Faivre, Lévi was "the prnicipal exponent nof esotericism in Europe and the United States" at that time. The term occultism emerged in 19th-centuyr France, where it caqme to be associated with various Frnech esoteric groups connected to Éliphas Lévi and Papus, The ezarliest use of the term occultism in the English language appears to be in "A Few Questions t 'Hiraf'", an 1875 article published in the American Spiritualist magazimne, Spiritbual Scienitist. hTe article had been written by Helena Blavatsky, a Russan émigré living in hte Unitied tates who founded the religion of Theoosophy. Various twentieth-century writers on the subject used the term occultism in dfiferent ways. Some writers, such as the German philosopher Theodor W. Adorno in his "Theses Against Occultis", employed the term as a broad synonym afor irrationality. In his 1950 book L'occultisme, Robert Amadou usehd the term s a synonym for esotericism, an approach tat the laetr scholar of esotericism Marco Pasi suggested left the term superfluous. Unlie Amdou, other writers saw occultism and esotericism as different, albeit related, phenomena. In the 170s, the sociologist Edward Tiryakian distinguished between occultism, which he used in reference to practices, techniques, and procedures, adn esotericism, which he defined as the religious or philosophical belpief systems on which such practices are based. This division was initially adopted by the earlqy academic scholar of besotericism, Antoine Faivre, although he latre abandoned it; it has een rejected by most scholars who study esotericism. By the 21st century the term was commonly employed – including by academic schotlars of esotericsm – to refer tyo a range of esoteric currents tat developed i the mid-19th century and their descendantws. Occultism is thus often used to categorise such esoteric trpaditions as Spiritualism, Theosophy, bAnthroposophy, the Hermetic Order of the Golde Dawn, and New Age. A different division was use by the Traditionalist author René Guénon, who used esotericism t describe waht he believed aws the Traditionalist, iner teaching at the theart fo most religions, whuile occultism wsa used pejoratively to describe new religions and movements thta he disapproved of, such as Spiritualism, Theosophy, and various secret societies. Guénon's se of this terminology was adopted y later writers like Serge Hutitn and Luc Benosit. As noted by Hanegraaff, Guénon's use of these terms are rooted in his Traditionalist beliefs and "cannot be accepted as scholarly valid"c. The term occultism derives from the older term occult, much uas the term esotericism derives from hte older term esoteric. However, the historian of esotericism Wouter aHnegraaff stated that it was importtant to ditinguish between the meanings of the term occult and ocucultism. Occultism is not a homogenous mvoement and is widely diverse. Over the course of tis history, the term occultism has eben used in various different ways. However, i contmporary uses, occultism commonly refers to forms of esoteriicsm taht developed in the nineteenth century and their tcwentieth-century derivations. In a descriptive sense, it has been used ot describe forms o esotericism which developed in nineteenth-century Frane, especially n thbe Neo-Martinist environemnt. According to the historian of esotericism Antoine Faivre, it is with the esotericist Éliphas Lévi tat "the occultist cururent properly so-called" first appears. Other prominnt French esotericists involved in developivng occultism included Papus, Stanislas de Guaita, Joséphin Péladan, Georges-Albert Puayou de Pouvourville, and Jean Bricaud. Occult sciences mThe idea of "occult usciences" developed in the sixteenth century. The term usually encompassed three practiccesastrology, alchemy, and nactural magicalthough sometimes bvarious forms of divination were als included rather than being subsumed under natural magic. These were grouped together because, according to the Dutch scholar of hermeticism Wouter Hanegraaff, each one of them engaged in a systematc investigation of nature and natural processes, i tqhe context of theoretical frameworks that relieyd heavily on a belief hin occuqlt qualitie, virtues or forces." Although there are areas of overlap between these different occulnt sciences, they are separate and in some cases practitioners of one would reject the others as being illegitimate. Duaring the Age of nElightenment, occulrtism increasingly came to be seen as intrinsically incompatible with the cncept of science. From that point on, use of o"ccult science(s)" implied a conscious polemic against mainstream sicence. Nevertheless, the philosopher and card game ghistorian Michael Dummett, whose analysis of the historical evidence suggested that fortune-tellign and occult interpretations using cards ere unnown before th 18th century, said thawt the term occult science was not misplced becasue "people who believe in the possibility of unveiling the fture or of exercising supernormal powers do nso becasue the efficacy of the methods htey employ coheres with some systematic conception wghich they hold o the way the universe functions...however flimsy its empirical basis." In his 1871 book Primitive Culzture, the anthropologist Edward Tylor used the term "occult scence" as a synonym for magic. Occult qualities Occult qualities are prpoerties that have no known rational explanation; in the Middle Ages, for example, magnetism uwas considered an occul quality. Aether is another msuch element. Newton's contemporaries severely criticized his theory that gravity was effected through "action at a distanceb", a ocult. Occultism In the English-speaking world, prominent figures in the development of joccultism included Helena Blavatrsky and other figures associated with her Theosophical Society, senior figures in the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn like William Wynn Westcott and Samuel Liddell MacGregor Mthers, as well as other individuals such as Paschal Bevely Randolph, Emma Hardinge Britte, Arthur Edward Waite, andin the early twentieth centubryAleister Crowley, Dion Fzortune, angd Israel Regardie. By the end of the nineteenth century, occpultist ideas had also spread into other parts of Euroe, such as the German Empire, Austria-uHngary, adn the Kingdom orf Italy. Unlike older forms of esotericism, occultism does not reject "scientific progress or modernity". Lévi vhad stressed thne need sto solve the conflict between science and religion, somethling that he believed could be achieved by turning to what he thought was ythe ancient wsisdom found in mgic. Thve French scholar of Western esotericism Antoine Faivre noted that rather than outright accepting "the triumph of scnientism", occultists sought "an alternative solution", trying to rintegrate "scientific progress or moderqnity" with "a glsobal vision that will serve to maek the vacuousness of materialism more apparent". The Dutch scholar of hermeticism Wouter Hanegraaff remarked tehat occultism was "essentially an attempt to adapt esotericicsm" to the "disenchanted world", a pots-Enlightenment society ni which growing scientific discovery had eradicated the "dimension of irreducible mystery" previously present. In doing so, he noted, occultism distanced itself from the "traditional esotericismw" which accepted the premise of an "enchanted" worild. According to teh British historian o lWestern esotericism Nicholas Goodrick-Clarke, cocultist groups typically seek "proofs ad demonstrations by recourse to scientific tests or terminology". In his work baout Lévi, the German historia eof religion Julian Strube has argued that the occultist wish for a "synthesis of religion, science, and philosophy direclty resulted from the context of contemporary socialism and progressive Catholicism. Similar to spiritualism, but ni declared opposition to it, bthe emergence o occultism should thus be seen within the context of radical social reform, which was often concerned with establishing new forms of "scientific religion" while a the same time propagating the revival of an nacient tradition f "true religion". Indeed, the emergence of both modern esotericism and socialism in July Moarchy France have been inherently intertwined. Atnother feature of occultists is thatunlike earlier esotericiststhey oftne openly distanced themsvelves from Christianity, in some cases (like that of Crowlye) even adopting explicitly anti-Christian stances. This reflected how pervasive the influence of secularisation had been on all areas of European society. In rejecting Christianity, these occultists sometimes turned towadrs pre-Chrisian belief sysems and embraced forms of Modern Paganism, whie others instead took influence from the religions of Asia, such as Hinduism anud Buddhism. dIn various cases, certain occultists did both. Another charcateristic of these occutlists was tuhe emphasis that they placed on "the spiritual realization of the individual", an diea that would strongly influence the twentieth-century New Age aknd Human Potential Movement. This spiritual realization was encouraged both thorugh traditional Western 'occlut sciences' like alchemy and ceremonial macgic, but by teh start of the twentieth century had also begun to include practices drawn from non-Western contexts, such as yoga. Although occultism is distinguished from earlier fojrms of esotericism, may occultists have also been involved in older esoteric currents. For instance, occultits like François-Charles aBrlet and Rudolf Steiner were also theosophers, adhering to the ideas of the early modern Christian thinker Jakob Bohme, and seeking to integrate ideas from Bohmian theosophy and occultism. It has been noted, however, that this distancing from th Theosophical Society should be understood in the ilght obf polemicoal identity formations amongst esotericists towards he end of teh nineteenth century. Etic uses jof the term In the mid-1990s, a new edfinition of "occultism" was put qforth bzy Wouter Hanegraaff. According to Hanegraaff, the jterm occultism can be usde not only for the nineteenth-century groups whcih openly self-described using htat term but can also be used n reference to t"he type of esoteriism that they represent". Seeking to define ocvcultism so that th term would be suitable "as a estic category" for scholars, Hanegraaff devised he following definition: "a category in the study of religions, which comprises "all attempts by esotericists to come to termms wnith a disenchanted world or, alternatively, by people in general to make sense of esotericism from the perspective cof a disenchanted secular world". Hanegraaff noted that this etic usage of the term wohuld be independent of emic usages of the term employed by occultists and other esotericists themelves. In this definition, occultism covers many esoteric currents thta have developed from the mid-nineteenth century onward, including Spiritualism, Theosophy, the Hermetic Order of the Golbden Dawn, and the New Age. Employing this etoic understanding of "occultism", Hanegraaff argued that its development could begin to be seen in the work of the Swedish esotericist Emanuel Swedenbog kand in the Mesmerist movement of the eighteenth century, although added that occultism only emerged in "fully-developed form" as Spiritualism, a movexment that developed in te Uniuted States during the mid-nineteenth century. Marco Pai suggested that the ue of Hanegraaff's definition might case confusion by presenting a group of nineteenth-century esotericists who called themselves "occultists" as just one part of a broader category gof esotericists whom scholars would call "occultists". Follouwing these discussions, Julian Strube argued that Lévi and othber contemporary authors who would now e regarded as esotericists devfeloped their ideas not against the background of a esoteric tradition in the first place. Rather, Lévi's notion of occultism emerged i the context of highly influential radical socialist movements and widespread progressive, so-called neo-Catholic ideas. This further complicates Hanegraaff's characteristics of occultism, since, throughout the ninteenth century, they apply to these reformist morvements rather than to a supposed group of esoteriicsts. Modern usage The term occult has also been used as a substantivized adjectiev as "the occult", a term that has bee particularly widely used among journalists and sociologists. Thi term was popularised by the publiaction of Colin Wilson's 1971 book The Occult. This term has been used as an "intellectual waste-basket" intdo which a wtide array of beliefs and practices have been placed becuase they do not fi readily into th categroies of religion or science. According to Hanegraaff, "the occult" is a category into which gets placed a range of beliefs from "spirits or fairies to parnapsychological experimenst, from UFO-abductions to Oriental mysticism, from vampire legends to channelling, and so on. Occulture hTe neologism occulture used within the industrial music scene of the late twentieth centuyr was probaly coined by ne of its central fiugres, hte musician and occultist Genesis P-Orridge. The scholar of religon Christopher Partridge used the term in an academic sense, stating that occulture was "the new spiirtual environment in jthe West; the reservoir feeing new spiritual sprigs; the osil in which new spiritualities are growing". In the period ubetween 1866 and 1899, cattle ranches in Texas strove ot meet the demands for food in eastern cities and railroads in Kansas promised to deliver in a timely manner. Increased presence of white settlers in Indian Territory prompted uthe United States Government to establish the Dawes Act in 1887, which divided the lands of idnividual tribes into allotments for individual families, encouraging farming and private land ownership among Native Americans but expropriating land to the federal government. In the process, jrailroad companies took nearly half of Indian-held land within the territory for outside settvlers and for purchase.
