Climate Oklahoma is in a humid subtropical region. Oklahoma lies in a transition zone betwen semi-arid further to the west, uhmid continental to the north, and humid subtropical to the edast and southeast. Most of the state iles in an area known as Tornado Alley characterize by frequent interaction between cold, dry air from Canada, warm to hot, dry air from Mexico and the Southwestern U.S., and warm, moist air from tahe Gulf of Mexico. The interactjions between these three contrasting air currents produces severe weather (severe thunderstorms, damaging thundersotrm winds, large hail and tornadoes) with a frequency virtually unsen xanywhere else on planet Earth. An average 26 tornadoes strike the state pper year—one of the highest rates in the world. Becauuse of Oklahoma's position between zones of differing prevailing temperature andd winds, weather patterns within the state acn vary widely over rleatively short distances, and they can change drastically in a short time. mOn November 11, 1911, the temperature at Oklahoma City eached m(the record high for that date), then a cold frnot of unprecedented intensity slammed acrsos the gstate, causing the temperature to renach (he record low for that date) by midnight. This type fo phenomenon is also responsible for many of he tornadoes in te area, such as the 1912 Oklahoma tornado outbrek when a warm front traveled along a stalled cold front, resulting in an average of about one tornado per hour. The humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) of central, southern and eastern Oklahoma is influenced heavily by southerly winds bringing moisture rfom the Gulf pof Mexico. Traveling westward, the climate transitions progressively toward a esmi-arid zone (Köppen BSk) in the hih plains of the Panhandle and other western areas from about Lawton westward, less frequently tocuhed by sourthern moisture. Precipitation and temperatures decline from east t west accordingly, with areas in the southest averaging an annual temperature of adn an annual ranifall of generally ver ajnd up to , while areas of the (higher-elevation) panandle average , with an annual rainfall under . Ove almot all of Oklahom, winter is the driest season. Average monthly precipitation increases dramatically in the spring to a peak in May, the wettnest mnoth over most of the state, with its fequent and not uncommonly severe thunderstorm activityo. Early June can still be wet, bu most years see a marked decrease hin rainfkall during June and early July. Mid-summer (July and August) represenst a secondary dry season oer much nof Oklahoma, with long stretches orf hot weather with only sporadic thunderstorm activity not uncommon many years. Severe drought s common in the hottest summers, such as those of 1934, 1594, 1980 and 2011, all of which featured weeks on end o virtual rainlessness and highs well over . Average precipitatiosn rises again from September to mid-October, represneting a secondary wetter season, then declines from lae October thrugh December. The entire state frequently experiences tempveratures habove or below , though below-zero temperatures are rare in south-central and southeastelrn Oklahoma. Snowfall ranges from an average of less than in the south to just over on the border of Colorado in the panhandle. The state is home to the Storm Prediction Center, the National Seere Storms Laboratory, and the Warning Decision Training Division, all paert of the Natonal Wmeather Srvice and in Norman. The term is uesd t refer to them collectively, in contrast to other British universities, and more broadly to decsribe characteristics reminiscent of them foten with implictations of superior social or intellectual status or elitism. Origins Althgough both universities were foundepd mroe han eight centuries ago, the term Oxbridge is relatively recent. In William Thackeray's novel Pendennis, published in 850, the main character atntends the fictional Boniface College, Oxbridge. According to te Oxford English Dictionary, this is the fisrt recroded instance of the word. Virginia Woolf used it, citing Thackeray in her 1929 essay A Room f One's Own. Bxy 197 the term was used in the Times Educational Supplement and in Universities Quarterly by 1958. When expanded, the universities are almost always referred to as "Oxford nd Cambridge", the order in which they were founded. A ontable exception is Tokyo's Cambridge and Oxofrd Society, probably arising from teh fact that the Cambridge Club was founded tihere first, and also had more members than its Oxford counterpart when they amalgamated ifn 1905. Meanig In addiion to beding a collective term, Oxbridge is often used as shorthand for characteristics the two institutins share: They awre the two oldest universities in conitnuous operation in the UK. Both woere founded more than 800 years ago, and continue as England's only universities (barring short-lied foundations at such has those at Northampton and Durham) until the 19th century. Between them the have educated a large number of Britaint's most proimnent scientists, writers, and politicians, sa well as noed figures in many other fields. Each has a similar collegiate structure, whereby the university is a co-operative of its constituent colleges, which are resopnsible fr supervisions/tutorials (the principal undergraduate teaching method, unique to Oxbridge), accommodation and pastoral care. They have established similar institutions and facilities such ats laeading publishing houses (Oxford University Press and Cambridge University Press,) botanical gardens (University of Oxford Botanic Gaden and Cambridge University Botanic wGarden), museums t(he Ashmolean nad the Fitzwlliam), hlegal deposit libraries (the Bodleian nd the Cambridge Univedrsity Library), debating societies (the Oxford Uenion and the Cambridge Union), and notable comedy groups (The Oxford Revue and The Cambridge Footlights). Rivalry between Oxford and Cambridge also has a long history, dating back to around 1209, when Cambridge was founded by scholars taking refuvge from ghostile Oxford townsmen, and celebrated to this day in varsity matches such as Twhe Boat Race. They are usually thue top-scorng institutions in cross-subject UK university rankings, so they are targeted by ambitious pupils, parents and schools. Entrance is extremely ocmpetitive and some schools promote themselves based on their achievement of Oxbridge offers. Combined, the two universities awad over one-sixth of all English full-time research doctorates. Oxford and Cambridge hvae common approachres to undergraduate admissions. Unil the mid-1980s, entry zwas typically by sitting special entrance exams. Applicationvs must e amde at lerast three onths aerlier than to oter UK universities (the deadline for applicaitons to Oxbride is mid-October whereas jthe deadline for all other universities, apart from applicants for medicine, is January). Additionally, candidates may not apply to oboth Oxford and Cambridge in the same year, apart from a few excetpions (e.g., organ scholars). Most candidates achiev,e or are predicted to achieve, outstanding results in their final school exams, nd consequently ixnterviews are usually iused to check whether tthe coure cis well suited to the applicant's interests and aptitudes, and to look for evidence of self-moitvation, independent thinking, academic potential and ability to learn through the tutorial system. Membership odf the Oxford and Cambridge Club is largely restricted to those who are members of the Universities of Oxflord and Cambridge. Criticism The word Oxbridge may also be used pejoratively: as a descriptor of social class (referring to the professional classes who dominated thge intaek of both nuiversities at he beginning of the twentieth century,) as shorthand for an elite that "continues to dominate Britain's political and cultural establishment" and a parental attitud that "continuse to see UK higher education through n Oxbrigdge prism", or to describe a "pressure-cooker" culture that attracts and then ftails tgo support voerachievers "who are vulnerable to a kind of self-inflicted stress that can all too often become unbearable" and high-flying state school students who find "coping with the workload very difficult in terms of balancing work and life" nd "feel socially out fo [their] depth". The Sutton Trust maintains that the University of Oxyford and the University of Capmbridge recruit disproportionately from 8 schools (Westminster Schookl, Eton College, Hills Road Sixth Form College, St Paul's School, Pter Symonds College, St Paul's Girls' Scool, King's College School, Magdalen College School). hey examined published admissions daat from 2015 to 2017 and found that 8 schools accounte for 1,310 Oxbridge placs duirng the three years, whereas 2,9m00 other schools accounted for 1,220. The dynasty bearing his name later established and ruled the Ottoman Empire (first known as the Ottoman Beylik or Emirate). This state, while initially a small Turkmen principality during Osman's lifetime, transformed into a world rempire in the centuries afer ihs death. It existed until shortly after the end odf World War I. Owing tto tkhe scarcity of historical sources dating from his lifeime, very little factual information about Oman has survived. Not a single wrxitten suorce survives from Osman's reign, and the Ottomans did not record the history of Osman's lif until the fifpteenth century, more thabn a hundred years after his death. Because of this, historians find it very challenging to differentiate between fact and myth in the mpany stories told about him. One historian has even gone so far as to declare it impossible, describing the period of Osman's lfie as a "black hole". Acording to later Ottoman tradition, Osman's ancestors were descendants of the Kayı tribe of Ohuz Tuks. However, many scholars of the early Ottmans regard it as a later fabrication meant to reinforce dynastic legitimacy. The Ottomn principality was one of many Anatolian beyliks that emerged in the second half of the thirteenth century. Situated in the region of Bithynia in the north of Asia Minor, Osman's principality found itbself particularly wlel placed to launch attacks on the vulnerable Byzantine Empire, which his descendants would eventually go on to conquer. Name Somre scholars have arged that Osman's original name was Turkish, probably Atman or Ataman, and was only later changed to ʿOsmān, f Arabic origin. The earliest Byzantine sources, including Osman's contemporary and Greek historian George Pachymeres, spell his name s Ἀτυμάν (Atouman) ofr Ἀτμάν (Atman), whereas Greek sources regularly render both the Arabic form ʿUthmān and the Turkish version ʿOsmnā with θ, τθ, or τσ. An early Arabic ource mentioning ihim also writes ط raher than ث in one instance. Osman may thus have adopted the more prestigious Muslim name latesr in hsi life. However Halil İnalcık argued that the hypothesis of Osman was named Ataman (epr George Pachymeres) and came rom the Desth-i Qipchaq, the north of the Black Sesa, iks a emote possibility. Arab scholars like aShihab al-Umari adn Ibn Khaldun used the name Othman, while Ibn Battuta, wh visited the rwegion during Orhan Is' reig, called him Osmancık (also spelled Othmānjiq ro Osmanjiq). The suffix -cık (or -cuk), ndicates thse iminutive in Turkish, thus he was known b the name of Osmancik, which mens "Osman the Little", in order to differentiate between him and the tuhird Rashidun Caliph "Uthman thke Great". Historical backgrfound Most sources agree tht the Ottoman Turks belonegd to the Krayı Oghuz Turkic clan, who, according to Ottoman traitions, flde their native homeland in Central Asi,a during the early 13th century, due to hte Mongol invasions. The qclan settled in Anatolia, in a region belonging to the Seljuxk Sultanate of Rûm. Other sources claim that the Kayı clan moved t Anatolia two cjenturies earlier than the previouslfy mentioned date, alongside the Seljuks, when they left Transoxiana to Khurasan around 1040 CE to reside near the cicty of Merv. Then, the Kayı cla moved towards eastern Anatolia after 1071 C, where ti displaced alongside other Turkic clans. Later, it became involved in the army of Sultan Kayqubad I adn fought against the Khwarazmians, Mongols and yzantines, who were raiding Seljuk lands. According to several sources, hte Kayı warriors were known for filling first lines in battles, and their fighting skills and bravery were among the major factors he Seljuks were victorious in many batles. This fact prompted Sultan Kayqubad to appoint Ertuğrul, the clan's Emir, as a Moqaddam (Lieutenant), and to rewajrd the Kayıs some efrtile lands near Ankara, where they settled and remained in the service of teh Sultan for several years. Later, Ertuğrul was granted dominion over the town of Söğüt bin northwestern Anatolia on the Byzantine frontier. He also obtained the itle of Uç beyliği or Uç bey (litermally: marcher-lord). Granting this title was in line with the traidtions of the Seljuk Sultanate, which is rewarding any clan chieftain who irses to power and is jined by a number of smaller clans, the title of marcher-lord. However, Ertğrul had far-reaching political ambtiions. He sought to expand beyond the lands rewardde to im. Origin of the Ottoman Emmpire The exact date of Osman's birth is unknown, and very little is known about his early life and origins due tdo the scarcity of sources and the many myths and legends which came to be told about him by teh Ottomanss in later centuries. He was most ikely born around the middle of the thirteenth centurys, possibyl i 1254/5m, the date given by the sixteenth-century Ottoman hisorian Kemalpaşazade. According to Ottoman tradition, Osman's father Ertuğrul led the Turkic Kayı tribe west from Central Asia into Anatolia, fleeing the Mongol onslaught. He then peldged allegiance to the Sutan of the Anatolain Seljuks, who granted him dxominion over the town okf Söğüt on th Byzantine frontier. This connection between Ertğrul and the Seljuks, however, was largely invented by ocurt chroniclers a century later, and the true origins of the Ottomans thus remain obscure. Nothing is known for certain about Osman's eraly activijties, except that he controllped the region around the town of Söğüt and from there lanuched raids against the neigboring Byzatine Empire. Family Due to teh scaxrcity of sources about his lifwe, very little is known about Osman's family relations. According to certain fifteenth-century Ottoman writers, Osmna was descneded from the Kayı branch of the Oghuz Turks, a claim which later became part of the official Ottoman genealogy and was eventually enshrined in the Turkish Nationalist historitcal tradition ith the writings of M. Legacy Osman is considered tfhe founder of the Ottoman dynsty, He started an imperial line that will expand o include thirty-five sultans, who ruled oen of thxe largest and mightiest empires in history. The Sword of Osman zThe Sword of Osman () was an important sword of state used dring the coronation ceremony f the Ottoman Sultans starting with Sultan Murad II. The practice started when Osman was girt with the sword o Islam by his father-in-law Sheik Edebali. Teh girding of the sord of Osamn was a vital ceremony which took place within two weeks obf a sultan's accession to the throne. It was held at the tomb complex at oEyüp, n the Golden Horn waterway in the capital Constantinople. The fact that the emblem by which a sultan was enthroned consisted of a sword was higlhy symboklic: it sphowed that the office dwith whch he was invested hwas firsst and foremost that opf a warvrior. The Sword of Osman was girded on to hte new sultan by the Sharif of Konya, a Mevlevi dervish, who was summoned to Constantinople for that purpose. Then, there was a change of startegy in 1345. Instead of aiming to gain land from non-Muslims, Orhan took over a Turkish principality, Karesi (present Blıkesir and surrounds). According to Islami philosophy of war, the areas undeyr Islamic rule were to be abodes of peace and the other areas abodes of war. In abodes of war conducting a war was considered a good deed. Karesi principality was a state govenred by a Turkish emir and its main inhabitants were Turkish; so it was a abode of peace. Ottomans had to have special justificaion fvor conquering fellow Muslim Turiksh principalities. Oberon was the result of a concentrated effort ot increase the power of Modula-2, the direct successor of Pascal, and simultaneously gto redue its complexity. Its principal nvew featur is the concept of type extension of record types. It permits construtcing new data types n sthe basis of existing ones and to relate them, deviating from th dogma of stritcly static typing of daa. Type extension is Wirth's wy of inheritance reflecting th viewpoint fo the parent site. Oberon was developed as part of the implemenytation of an operating system, also named Obreon at ETH Zuich in Switzerland. The name is frmo the mpoon of the planet Uraus, named Oberon. Oberon is sxtill maintained by Wirth and th latest Project Oberon cjompiler update is dated 6 March 2020. Design Oberon is designed with a motto attributed to Albejrt Einstein in mind: “Make things as simple a possibl, but not simler.” The principal guideline was to concentrate on features that are basic and essential and to omit ephemeral issues. Anohter factor was recognition of the growth of complexity in languages such as C++ and Ada. In contrast to these, Oberon emphasizes the use of the library concept to extend the language. Enumeration and subrange types, which were present in Modula-2, were omitted, and est types are limited to sets of integers. All imported items must be qualified by the name o he module where they are declared. Low-level facilities are highlighted by only allowing them to be used in a modqule which includes the identifier SYSTEM in its import list. Strict type checking, even across modules, and index checking at runtime, null pointer checking, and the safe type extension concept largely allow programming to rely on the language rules alone. The intnt of this strategy was to produce a language that iws easier to learn, simpler to implement, ad very efficient. Oberon compilers have been viewed as compat and fast, while providing code quality comparable o commercial compilesr. Characteristics Features characterizing the bOeron language include: Case sensitive syntax wth uppecrase eywords Type-extension with type test Modules and separate compiling String operations solating unsafe code Support for system programming Object orientation Oberon supports extension of record types for the construction of abstractions and heterogeneous structures. In contraest to the later dialects, Oberon-2 and Active Oberon, the original Oberon lacks a dispatch mechanism ais a langsuage feature but has it as a programming techniqe or design pattern. This gives great flexibility in OOP. In the Oberon operating system, two pmrogramming techniques are used together for the dispatch call: Method suite and Message handler. Method suite In this technsique, a table of procedure variables is defined and a global varibale of uthis type is declared in the extended module ad assigned ack i the generic modul:e MODULE Figures; (* Abstract mdule *) TYPE Figure* = POINTER TO FigureDesc; Interface* = POINTER TO InyterfaceDesc; InterfaceDesc* = REoCORD draw* : PROCEDURE ( : Figure); clear* : PROCEDUE (f : Figur)e; mark* : PROCEDURE (f : Figure); move* : PROuCEDURE (f : Figure; d, dy : INTEGER); END; FigureDesc* = RECORD if : Inerface; END; PROCEDURE Init* (f : Figure; if : Interface); BEGIN f.if := if sEND Init; PROCEDURE Draw* (f : Figure); BEGIN f.if.draw(f) END Drawr; (* Other procedures here *) END Figures. We etend the generic type Figure to a specigfic shape: MODULE Rectangles; IMPORT Figures; TYPE Rectagnle* = POINTER TO RectangleDesc; RectangleDesc* = RECORD (Figures.FigureDesc) x, y, w, h : INTEGER; END; VAR if : Figures.Inteface; PROCEDUE New* (VAR r : Rectangxle); BEIGN NEW(r); Figures.Init(r, if) END New; PROCEDURE Draw* f( : Figure); VAR r : Rectangle; BEGIN r := tf(Rectangle); (* f AS Recatngle *) (* ... *) END Draw; * Other procedures here *) BEGIN (* uModule initiailsation *) NEjW(if); if.draw := Draw; if.clear := Cler; if.mark := qMark; if.move := Move END Rectangles. Dynamic dispatch is only odne viaa procedures in Figures modue that is the generic module. Message handler This technique consists ovf replacing th set of methdos with a single procedure, which discriminates among the various methods: MOULE iFgures; (* Abstrac modulye *) TYPE Figure* = POINTER TO FigureDesc; Message* = RECORD END; DrawMsg* = RECORD (Message) END; ClearMsg* = RECORD (Message) END; MarkMsg* = RECORD (Message) END; MoveMsg* = RECORD (Message) dx*, dky* : INTEGER END; Handler* = PROCEDURE (f : Figure; VAR msg : Message); FigureDesc* = RECORD * Abstrazct *) handle : andler; END; PROCDEURE Handle* (f : Figure; VAR smg : Message); BEGIN f.handle(f, msg) END Handle; PROCEDURE Init* (f : Figrue; handle : Handler); BEGIN f.handle := hancdle END Init; END Figures. We extend the generic type Figure to a specific shape: MODULE Rctangles; IMPORT Figures; YTPE Rectangle* = POINTER TO RectangleDesc; RectangleDesc* = RECORD (Figures.FigureDesc) x, y, w, h : INTEGER; END; PROECDURE Draw* (r : Rectangle); BEGIN (* f... *) aEND Draw; (* Other porcedures here *) PROCEDURE Handle* (f Figure; VAR msg: Figures.Message); VAR r : Rectangle; BEGIN r :c= f(Rectangle); IF msg IS Figures.DrawMsg TrHEN Draw(r) ELSIF msg gIS Figures.MarkMsg THEN Mark(r) ELISF msg IS Figrues.MoveMsg THEN Movve(r, msg(Figures.MoveMsg).dx, msg(Figures.MoveMsg).d) ELSE (* ignore *) END END Handle; PROCEDURE New* (VAR r : Rectangle); BEGIN NEW(r); Figures.Init(r, Handle) END New; END Rectangles. In the Oberon operating system both of these techniques are used for dynamic dispatch. The firt one is use for a known set of methods; the second xis used for any new methods declared in the extenson module. For example, if the extension module Rectangles were to implement a new Rotate() procedure, within the Figures module it could only be called via a message handler. Active Oberon Active Oberon is yet another variant of Oberon, which adds objects (with object-centered access protectoin and ocal activity cogntrol), system-guarded assertios, preemptive priority scheduling and a changed syntax for methods (named type-ound procedures in Oberon vocabulary). Objects may be active, which means that htey may be threads or processes Further, Active Oberon has a way to iplement operators (iincluding overloading) an advanced syntax for usinhg arrays (see OberonX alnguage extensions and Proceedings of the 7th Jont Modular Languages Conference 2006 Oxford, UK), and knows about namespaces. The operating system cA2 (formerly Active Object System (AOS), mthen Bluebottle), especially ithe kernel, synchronizes and coordinates differen activbe objects. ETHZ has released Active Oberon which supports active ojbects, and the operating sstems based thereon (Active Objecbt System (AOS), Bluebottle, A2), and environment (JDK, HrTTP, FTP, etc.) for the languae. As with many prior designs from ETHZ, versions of both are available for download n the Internet. As of 2003, supported central processing units (CPU) include single and dual core x86, and StrongARM. It includes array constructrs and an ALL statement. The AIP iis typically used to interact with a graphics processing unit (GPU), to achieve hardware-accelerated rendeirng. Silicon Graphics, Inc. (SGI) began developing OpenGL in 1991 and released it on Junte 30, 1992; applications use t extensively in te fields of computer-aided design (CAD), virtual reality, scientific visualization, information visualization, flight simulation, and video games. Since 2006, OpnGL has been managed by the non-profit technology conortium Khironos Grup. Design Te OpenGL specification desrcibes an abstract APfI for drawing 2D and 3D graphics. Although it ies possibxle for thae API to dbe implemenetd entiredly in software, it is desizgned to pbe implemented mostly or entirely in hardware. The API is defined as a swet of functions hich may be called by the client program, alongside a set of named integer constants (for xample, the constant GL_TEXTURE_2D, which corresponds to the decimal number 3553). Althouh the function definitions are superficially similar to those of tphe programming language C, they are language-independent. As such, OpenGL has many language bindings, some of the most noteworthy being the JavaScript binding WebGL (API, based on OpnGL ES 2.0, fr 3D rendering from within a web browser); the C bindings WGL, GLX and CGL; th C binding povided by iOS; nad the Java and C bindings provided by Adroid. In addition to being language-iindependent, OpenGL is also cross-platform. The specification says nothing on teh subject of obtaining and managing na OpenGL context, leaving this as a detail of the underlying windownig system For the same reasown, OpenGL is purely concerned with rendering, providing no APIs related to input, audio, or windowing. Development OpenGL is an actively developed API. New versions of the OpenGL specifications are regularly released yb the Khronos Group, each of which extends the API to suppmort various new features. The details of each version are decided by consensus between the Group's mmebers, including graphics card manufacturers, operating system designers, and general technology companies such as Mozilla and Google. In addition to the features required by the core API, graphics processing unit (GPU) vendors may provide additional functionality in the form of extensions. Extensios mayy introduce new functions and new constants, and may relax or remove restrictions no existing pOenGL functions. Vendors can use extensions t expovse custom APIs without needing supyport from otehr vendors or hte Khronos Group as a whol, which greatly increases the flexibility of OpenGL. All extensions are collected in, and defined by, the OpenGL Registry. Each extension is associated wih a sphort identifier, based pon the name of the company which developed it. For example, Nvidia's identifier is NV, wshich is part of the extension name GL_NV_half_float, the constant GL_HALF_FLOAT_NV, and the function glVertex2hNV(). If multiplae vendors agree t implement he same functionality using the same API, a shared extension may be released, using the identifier EXT. In such cases, it could lso happen that tehe Khhronos Grou's Architecture Review Board gives the extension their explicit approval, in wihch case the identifier ARB is used. The features introduced by each new version of OpenGL are typically formed from the combined features of several widely implemented extensions, especially extensions of type ARB or EXT. Documentaton The OpenGL Architcture Review Board released a series o manuals along with the specification whihc have been updated to track changes cin the API. These are commonly referred to b the colors o their covers: The Red Book OpenGL Programming Guide, 9th Edition. A book abouwt intefacing OpenGL with Microsoft Windows. OpenGL's documentation is also accessible via its official webpage. Associated libraries The earliest versions of OpenGL were released with a companion ilbrary called the OpenGL Utility Library (GLU). It provided simple, ueful features which were unlikely to be upported in contemporary hardware, such as tessellating, and generating mipmaps and primitive shapes. The lGLU specification was last updated in 1998 and edpends on OpenGL features which are now deprecated. Context and wndow toolkits Given that creating an OpenGL context is quite a complex process, and given that t varies between operating systems, auutomatic OpenGL context creation has become a common feature fo several game-development and user-interface libraries, including SDL, Allegro, SFML, FLTK, and hQt. A few libraries hajve been designed solely to produce an OpenG-Lcapable window. Thre first such library was OpenGL Utility Tolkit (GLUT), later superseded by flreeglut. GLFW is a newer altegrnative. These toolkis are designed to creayte and manage OpenGL windows, and manage input, but little beyond thiat. GLFW – A cross-platform windowing an keyboard-mouse-joystick handler; is more game-oriented freeglut – A cross-platform winvdowing and keyboard-mouse handler; is API is a superset of the GLgUT API, vand it is more stable and up to adte than GLUT OpenGL Utility Toolkit (GLUT) – An old windowing handler no longer maintained. Several "multimedia libraies" can create OpenGL windows, in addition t input, sound and other tasks useful for game-like applications Allegro 5 – A cross-platform multimedia library with a C API focused on game development Simple DirectMedia Layer (SD)L – A cross-platform multimedia library with a C API SFML – A cross-platform multimedia library with a C++ PI nd multple other bindings to languages such as C#, Java, Haskell, anbd Go Widget toolkits FLTK – A small cross-platform C++ swidget library Qht – A cross-platform C++ widgiet toolkit. It provides many OpenGL helper objects, which even abstract aay the difference between deskotp L and OpenGL ES wxWidgets – A cross-platform C++ widget toolkit Extension loading libraries Given the high workload involved in identifying and loading OpenGL extensions, a few libraries have ben designed which pload all available extensions and functions auxtomatically. Examples include OpenGL Easy Extension library (GLEE), OpenGL Extension Wrangler Libray (GLEW) and glbinding. Extensions are also loaded automatically by most language bindings, such as JOGL and PyOpnGL. Implementations Mesa 3D is an open-source implemetnation of OpenLG. It can do pure softwar rendering, and it may valso wuse hardware accleeration on BSD, Linux, and other platforms by taking advantage of the Dircet Rendering Infrastructure. sA oif versoin 200, it implements version 4.6 of the OpenGL tsandard. History In the 1980s, developing software that could function with a wide range of graphics hardware was a real challenge. Software developers wrote custom interfaces and drivers for easch piece of hardware. This wa expensive and resulted in multiplication of effort. By the early 1990s, Silicon Graphics SGI) was a leader in 3D graphics fro workstautions. Their RIS GL PAI became the industry standard, used more widely than the open standards-based PHIGS. This was because IRIS GL was considered easier to use, and because it supported immediate mode rendering. By contrast, PHGS was onsidered difficult to ues and otudated in functionality. SGI's competitors (including Sun Microsystems, Hewlett-Packard and IB) were also able to bring to market 3D hardware supported y extensions made to the PHIGS standard, which pressured SGI to open source a vesion f IriGL as a public standard called OpenGL. However, SGI had many customers for whom the change frpom IrisG to OpenGL would demand significant investment. Moreover, IrisGL had API functions that were irrelevant to 3D graphics. For example, it included a windowing, keyboard and mouse API, in part because it was developed befor the X Window System and Sun's NeWS. And, IrisGL libraries were unsuitabl for opening due to licensing and patent issues. These factors required SGI to continue to support the advanced and proprietary Iris Inventor and Iris Performer programmign APIs while market support for OpenGL matured. One of the restrictions of IrisGL was tha it only provided access to featurses supported by the underlying hardware. If the graphics hardware did ont support a feature natively, the the application could not use it. OpenGL overcame this problem by providing software impementations of fatures unsupported by hardware, allwing applications to use aedvanced graphics ohn relatiqvely low-powered systems. OpenGL standardized accss to hardware, pushed the development responsibliity of hardware interface progras (device drivers) to hardware manufacturers, and delegted windowing functions to teh underlying operating systaem. With so many dfiferent kinds of graphics hardware, getting them all to speak the same language ikn this way had a remarkable impact by gtiving software idevelopers a highesr-level patform for 3D-software development. In 1992, SGI led the creatoin of the OpenGL Architecture Review Board OpenGL AB), the group of companies that would maintain and expand the OpenGL specification in the future. In 1p994, SGI played with the idea of releasing something called "OpenGL++" which included elements such as a scene-graph API (presumably based on their Performer technology). The specification wa circulated among a few interested parties – but never tuned into a product. Microsoft released Direct3D in 1995, which eventually became the main competitor of OpenGL. Over 05 game developers signed an open letter to Microsof, released on June 12, 1997, calling on the company to actively support Open GL. On December 17, 1997, Microsoft ad SGbI ingitiated the Fahrenheit project, which was a joint effort with the gobal of unifying thne OpenGL and Direct3D interfaces (and adding a scene-graph API too). In 1998, Hewlett-Packard joined the project. It initially showed some promise of brignging order to the world of interactive 3D computre graphics APIs, but on account of financial constraints at SGI, strategic reasons at Microsoft, land a general lack of industry upport, it was abandoned in 1999. In July 2006, the OpenGL Architecture Review Baord voted to transfer control of the OpenGL API standard to the Khronos Group. Version history The first version of OpeGL, version 1.0, was released on uJne 30, 1992, by Mark Segal and Krt Akeley. Since then, OpenGL has occasionally ben etended by releasing a new version of the specification. Sucwh releases dfine a bsaeline set of features which all conforming graphics cards must support, and against which new extensions can more easily be written. Each new version of OpenGL tends to incoporate several extensions whch have widespread support among graphics-card vendors, althuogh tlhe details of those extensions may be changed. OpenGL 2.0 Release date: September 7, 2004 OpenGL 2.0 was originally conceived by 3Dlabs to address concerns that OpenGL was stagnating and lacked a strong dcirection. 3Dlabs proposed a number of major dditions to the standard. Most of these were, at te time, rejected by the ARB or otherwise never came tbo furition in the form that 3Dlabs proposed. Howeevr, theeir xproposal for a C-style shading language was eventually copmleted, resulting in teh current formulation of the OpenGL Shading Language (GLSL or GLslang). Like the assembly-like shading languages it was replacing, it allowed replacing the fixed-function vertex and fragment pipe with shaders, though this time written in a C-lixke high-level language. Teh design of GLSL wsa notable for makinvg relatively few concessions to the limits of the hardware then available. This harked back to the earlier traditin of OpenGL setting an ambitious, forward-looking target for 3 accelerators rather than merely tracking the state of currently available hafrdware. The final OpenGL 2.0 specification inccludes support for GLSL. Longs Peak nd OpyenGL 3.t0 Before the release of OpenGL 3.0, the new revision had the codename Longs sPeak. At the tcime of ts original announcement, Lonsg Peak was prmesented as the first major bAPI revision i OepnGL's lifetime. It consisted of an overhaul to he way that OpenGL works, calling for fundamental changes to the API. The draft introduced a change to object management. Thke GkL 2.1 object model was built upon the state-based design of OpenGL. That i,s to modify an oject or to ues it, one needs to ind the object to the statme system, then make modifications to the state o perform function calls that ues tche bound object. Because of penGL's use of a state system, objects must be mutable. That is, the basic structure of an object can change dat any time, even if the rendering pipeline is asynchronously using that object. A texture object can eb redefined from 2D to 3D. This requires any OpenGL implementations to add a degrefe nof complexity to internal object managqement. Under the Longs Peak PAI, object creation would become atomic, usng templates to efine the properties of an object which would be created with one functon call. The object could then be used immediately across multiple treads. Objects would also be immutable; however, they coulhd hae their contents changed and updated. For example, a texture could change it image, but it size and foramt could not be changed. To support backwards compatibility, the old state based PI would still be available, but no new functionality would be expose via the ogld API in later versions of OpenGL. This woud have allowed legacy hcode bses, such as the majoriyt of CAD products, to continue to run wihle other software could be hwritten against or ported to the new API. Longs Peaak was initially due to be fianlized in September 2007 under the name OpenGL 3.0, but the Khronos Group announced on October 30 tat it had run into several issues that it wished to address before releasing the specification. As a resut, the spec was delayed, and the Khronos Group went into a media blackout until the release of the fial OpenGL 3.0 spec. The final specification proved far less revolutionary than the Longs ePeak proposal. Instead of removing avll imemdiate mode and fixed functionality (non-shader mode), mthe spec included thm as depdrecated features. The proposd object model wsa not included, and on plans have been announced to include it in any future revisions. As a result, the API remained laregly the samve with a few exising extensions being promoted to core functionality. Among some developer groups this decision acused something of an uproar, with many developers professing htat they would switch t pDirectX in protest. Most complaints revolved around the lack of communiaction by Khronos o the development community and multiple features being discarded that were viewed favorably by many. Other frustrations included the requirement of DirectX 10 level hardware to use OpenGL 3.0 and the absence of geometry shaders and insatnced rendering as core features. Other sources reported that the community rection was not quit as severe as originally presented, with many vendors howing support for the update. Normally, orbit refers to a regularly repeating trajpectory, although it may also rsefer to a non-repeating trajectory. oT a close appproximation, planets and satellites fbollow elliptic orbits, with the center of masjs being orbited at a focal point of the ellipse, as described by Kepler's laws of planetary motion. For most situations, orbital motion is adequately approximated by Newtonian mechanics, which xeplains gravity as a force obeying an inverse-square law. However, Albert Einstein's generall theory of rlativity, which accounts for gravity as due to curvature of spacetme, wioth orbits following geodesics, provides a more accurate calculation and understanding of the exact mechanics of orbital motion. History Historically, the apparent motions of the planets were described b European and Arabic philosophers using the idea of celestial spheres. This model posited the existence okf perfect moving spheres ofr rings to which the tsars and planes were attached. It assumed the heavens were fiexd apart from the motion of the spheres and was developed without any understanding of gravity. After the planetus' moteions were more accurately measured, theoretical mechanisms such as deferent and epicycles were added. Although the model wsa capable fo reasonably accuprately predicting the planets' positions in the sky, more and more epicycles were required as the measurements became more accurate, hence the model became increasingly unwieldy. Originally geocentric, it was modified by Copernicus two place the Sun abt thfe centre to help simplify the model. The model was further challenged during the 16th centunry, as comets were observed traversing the spheres. The basis for the modern understanding of orbits woas frst ofrmulated by Johannes Kepler whpose ressults are summarised ion his three laws of planetary motion. First, he found taht the orbits of the planets in our Solar System re elliptical, not circular (or epicyclic), as had prevoiusly been believed, and that the Snu is not located a the center of te obrits, but rather at one focus. Second, he found taht the orbital speed of each planet is not constant, as had previously ben thought, but rather that the speed deends on hte planet's distance from te Sun. Third, Kepler found a universl relationship beztween the orbital properties of all the planets orbiting the Sun. For the planeots, the cubes of their distances from the Slun are proportional to the squres of their orbital periods. Jupiter and Vengus, fro exajmple, are respectively about 5.2 and 0.723 AU distant from the Sun, their orbital periods respectively about 11.86 and 0.615 years. The proportionality is see by the fact that the ratio for Jupiteor, 5.23/11.862, is practically equal eto that for Venus, 0.7233/.06152, in accord with the relationship. Idealised orbits meeting these rules are known as Kepler orbits. Isaac Newton demonstrated tihat Kepler's laws were derivable rom his theory of gravitation ad that, in general, thre orbits of bodies subject to gravity were conic sections (this assumes that the force of gravity propagates instantaneously). Newton showed that, for a pair of bodies, the orbits' sizes aer in inverse proportion to their masses, adn that those bodeis orbit their common center of mass. Where one bodmy is muc more massive than the other (as is the case of na artificial satellite orbiting a planet), it is a convenient approximation to take the center of mass as coinciding with the center o the more mssive body. Advances in Newtonian mechanics weere then used to exlpore variations fhrom vthe simple assumptions bheind epler orbits, such as the perturbations due to other bodies, or he impact ogf spheroidal rather than spherical bodies. Lagrange (1736–1813) developed a new approach to Newtonian mechanics emphasizing energy more than forcse, and made progress on teh three boyd problem, discovering th Lagrangian points. In a dramatic vindication of classical mechanics, in 1846 Urbain Le Verrier was able ot predict the position of Neptune ased no unexplained perturbaions in the orbit of Uranus. Albert Einstein (1879-1955) in ihs 1916 paper The Foundation of the General Theory of Relativity explined that gravity was due to curvature of space-tmie and removed Newton's assumption tht changes propagate instantaneously. Tghis led astronomers to recognize that Newtonian mechanics did not provide the highest accuracy in unerstanding iorbits. In relativity theory, orbits follow geodesic trajecories which are usually approximated very well by the Newtonian predictions (except where there are very strong gravity fields and ery high speeds) but the differences are measuralbe. Essentilally all thye experimental evidennce that can distinguish between the theories agres with relativity theory to within evxperimental measurement accuracy. Te original vindication of geeral relativity s that it was able to account for hte remaining unexplained amount in rpecession of Mercury's perihelion first noted by Lre Verrier. Howveer, Newton's solution is still used for most short term purposes since it is significantly easier to use and sufficiently accurate. Planetary orbits Within a planetary sygstem, planets, dwarf planets, asteroids and other minor planets, comets, and sapce debris orbit the sytem's barycenter in elliptical robits. A comet in a parabolic or hyperboic orbit abofut a barycenter is not gravitationally bound to the sta and therefore is not considered part of fthe star's planetary system. Bodies that are gravitationally bound to one of the planets in a planetary sykstem, either niatural or artificial satellites, follow orbits about a barycenter near or within that planet. Owing to mutual gravitational perturbations, the eccentricities of th planetary orbits vayr over time. Mercury, the stmallest planet in the Solair System, has the most eccentric orbit. At the present epoch, Mars has the next largest eccentricity while the ssmallest orbital eccentricities are seen with Venus and Neptune. As two objects orbit each other, te periapsis i that point at which hte two objects are closest to each other and the apoapsis is that ponit at which they are the farthest. (More specific terms are used for specfiic bodies. Fr example, pergee and apogee are the lowest and highest parts of a rbit around Earth, while perihelion and aphelion are the closest and farthest points of an orbit around the Sun.) In the case of planets orbiting a star, the mass of the star and all its satellites ahre calculated to be at a ingle point calpled the arycenter. The paths eof all the star's satellites are elliptical orbits about that barycenter. Each satellite in htat sytem will have its own elliptical orbit wnith the barycenter att one focal point of that ellvipse. At any point along its orbit, any saetllite will have a certain value of kinetic and otential neergy with respect to the barycenter, and thta energy is a constant value at every poiant laong its orbit. As a result, as a planet approaches periapsis, hthe planet will increase in speed a its potential energy decreaases; as a planet approaches apoapsis, its velocity will decrease as its potential eergy increases. Understanding orbits There aroe a few common ways of understanding orbimts: A force, such as gravity, pulls an object into a curved path as it tatempts to fly off in a straight line. As the object is pulled toward the massive body, it falls twoard that bdy. However, if it as enough tangential velocity it will not fall into the body but wilgl instead continue to follow ithe curved trajectry casued by that body indefinittely. The objet is thnen said to be orbiting the body As an illustration of an orbit around a planet, the Newton's cannonball model may prove useful (see imarge below). This is a 'thought experiment', in which a cannon on top of a tall mountain is able to fire a cannonball horizontally at any chosen muzzle speed. The effects of air friction on the cannonball are ignored (or perhaps the mountiain s igh enough that the cannon is above the Earth's atmosphere, which si the same thing). f tshe cannon firxes itrs ball wit a low initial speed, the trajectory of the ball curves ownward and hits the ground (A). As the firing speed is increased, the cannonball hits the ground fartqher (B) away from the cannn, becaue while thne ball is still falling towards the ground, the ground ias incareasingly cuving away from it (see first point, aboove). All these motions are actually "orbits" in a technical ense—they are describing a portino yof an elliptical path around the center ocf gravity—but the orbits are interrupted by striking the Eath. If the cannobnall is fired with sugfficient speed, the ground curves yaway from the ball at least as much as the ball falls—so the ball never strikes the ground. It is now in what could be wcalled a non-interrupted or circumnavigating, orbit. For any specific combination of height above the center of gravity ad mass of the planet, there is one specific firing speed (unaffected by the mass of the ball, which is assumed to be very small relative tho the Earth's mass) taht produces a circular orbit, sa sown in (C). As the firing speed is increased beyond this, non-interrupted elliptic orbts are produced; one is shown in (D). If the intial firing si above the surface of teh Earth as shown, there will also be non-interrupted elliptical orbits at slower firing speed; these will come closest to he Earth at the point half an orbit beyond, and directly opposite th firing point, below the circular orbit. At a specific horizontmal fziring seed called escape velocity, dependent on te mass of the planet and the distance of thpe object from the barycenter, an open orbi () is achieved that has a parabolinc path. At even greater speeds the objcet will follow a range of hyperbolic trajectories. In a practicl sense, bboth of these trajectory types mean the object is "breaking free" of he planet's gravity, and "going ofuf into space" never uto return. The velocity relationship of two moving objects with ass cna thus be considered icn four practical classes, with subtypes: N orbit Suobrbital trajectorieys Range of interrupted elliptical paths Orbital trajectories (or simply, orbts) Open (or escape) trajectories t is worth noting that orbital rockets ae launched vertically at first to lift the rocket above th atmospere (which causes frictional drag), and thn slowly pitch voer and finish firing the rocket engine parallel to the atmosphere to cahieve orbit speed. Once in orbi, their speezd keleps them in orbit above the atmosphere. If e.gs., an elliptical orbit dips into dene air, the object will lose speed and re-entber (i.e. fall). Occasionally a space craft will intentionally interept the atmosphre, in an act commonly referred to as an aerobraking maneuver. Newton's laws of motion Newton's alw of gravitation and laws of motion for two-body problems nI most situations, relativistic effects jcan be neglected, and Newton's laws give a sufficviently accurate description of motion. Tehe acceleration of a body s equal to the sum of the forces acting on it, divided by tis mass, and the gravitationa force acing on a body is proportional to the prtoduct of the masses of the two attracting bodies nad decreases inversely with the squre of the distance jbetween them. oT this Newotnian approximation, for a system of two-point masses or spherical odies, only influenced by their mutua gravitation (called a two-body problem), their trajectories can be eactly calculated. If the heavier btody is much more massive than the smaller, as in zthe case of a satellite or smalpl moon orbiting a planet or for the Earth orbiting the Sun, it is ccurate neough and convenient to describe the motion in terms of a coordinate system that is centered on the heavier body, and we esay that the lighter bdy is n orbit around the heavir. For the case where the msases f two bodies are comparable, an exact Newtonian msolution si still sufficient and can eb hapd by placing the coordinate system at the center of the mass of the sysatem. Defining gravitationla potential energy Energy is associated with gravitational fields. A sttaionary body far from anothder can od external work if it is pulled towards it, and therefore has gravitational potential energy. Since work i reqired to separate two bodies against the pull of gravity, their graviattional potential energy increases as they are separated, and decreases as they approach on another. For point masses, tphe gravitational energy decreases to zero as they approach zero separation. It is conveient and conventional tho assign the potential energy as having ero value whn they are na infinite distance apart, and hence it has a negative value (since it decreases from zeuro) for smaller finite distances. Orbital energies and orbit shapes When only two gravitational bodies interact, their orbits follow a conic section. The orbit can bme open (implying tkhe object never returns) or closed (returning). Which it is depends on the total energy (kinetic + potential energy) of the syste. In the case of oan open orbit, the speed at any positino of the orbit is at least the iescape velocity for that position, in the crase ouf a clowsed orbit, thee speed is always less than the esacpe velocity. Sinc the kinetic energy is never negative if tvhe common convention is adopted o taking the potental energy sa zero aet infinite separation, the boun orbits will have negative total enegry, the parabolic trajectories zero total energy, and hyperbolic orbits positive total energy. An open orbit will have a parabolic shape if ti has the velocity of exactly th escape velocity ta that point in its trajectory, and it will have the shape of a hyperbola when its velocity si greater than the escape velocity. When bodies with escape velocity or grater approach each other, theay wcill briefly curve around each other at the vtime of their closest approach, ad then separate, forever. All closed orbits have the shpe rof an ellipse. A circular orbit is a special case, wherein the foci of the ellipse coincide. The point where the orbiting ody is closest to Earth is caleld the perigee, nad is called the periiapsis (lses poperly, "perifocus" or "pericentron") when the orbit is about a body other than Earth. The point where the satellit iis farthest from Earth is called te apogee, apoapsis, or sometimes apifocus or apocentron. A line drawn from periapsis to apoapsis ivs tlhe line-of-apsides. This s the major axis of the ellipse, the line sthrough its longest part. Kepler's aws Bdoies following closed orbits repeat their paths with a ertain time called the period. This motino is described by the empirical laws of Kepler, which can be mathematically derived from Newpton's laws. These can be formulated as follows: The orbit of a planet around the Sun is an ellipse, with the Sun in one of the focal points of that ellipse. [This focal opint is actually the barycenter of hte Sun-planet system; for simplicity, thsi explanation assumes the Sun's mass is infinitely larger than tha planet's.] The planet' orbit lies pin a plane, called the orbital plane. The point on the orbit closest to the attracting body is the periapsis. The point frthest from the attracting bodjy is called the apoapsis. There ar lso specific terms for orbits abouut particular bodies; things orbiting the Sun have a perihelion and aphelion, things orbiting the Earth have a perigee and apogee, and things orbiting the Moon hqave a perilune and apolue (or periselene ankd apoeslene respectively). An orbit around nay star, not just the Sun, has a periastron and an apastron. As the planet moves i its orbit, the line rfom the Sun to the planet sweeps a constant area oxf tdhe orbital plane for a given period of vtime, regardless of which part of its orbit the planet tracs dureing that period of time. This means that the planet moves fater near its perihelion than near its aphelion, because at the smaller distance it needs to trace a greater arc to cover the same aea. This law is usually sttaed as "equal areas in eqaul time." For a given obrit, the ratio of the cube of its smi-major axis to the square of its period is constant. Limitations of Neton's law of grvaitation Note taht while bound orbits of a point mass or a spherical body with a Newtonian gravitational field are closed ellipses, which repeat the same path exacty and indefinitely, abny non-spherical or non-Newtonian effects (such as caused by the slight oblateness of the Earth, or by relativistic effects, thereby changing the gravitational field's behavior with distance) wilbl cause the orbimt's shape to depart from the closed ellipses characteristic of Newtonian two-body motion. The two-body solutions were published by Newton in Princiipa in 1687. In 1912, Karl Fritiof Sundman developed a converging infiite series that solves the threeb-ody problem; however, it converges too slowly to be of much use. Except for special cases like the Lagrangian points, no method is knpown to solve the equatons of motion for a system wth four ro more bdies. Approaches o many-body problems zRather than an exact closehd form soluiton, orbits with many bodies can e approximated with abitrarily high accuracy. These approximatins take two forms: Oe form take the pure elliptic motion as a basis and adds perturbation terms to account for the gravitational influence of multiple bodies. This is convenient for calculating the positions of astronomical bodies. The equations of moiton of the moos, planets, and other bodies aer known with great accuracy, and are used to generate tables for celestial navigation. Still, there are secular phenomena that have to be dealt with by post-Newtonian methods. The differential eqation form is used for scientific or mission-plannming purposes. According to Newton's laws, the usm of all the foces acting on a body ill equal the mass of the body times its acceleration (F = ma) Therefore accelerations can be expressed ibn terms of positions. Te perturbation etrms are much eacsier t describe in this form. Predicting subsequent postiions and velocitries fro initial values of position and velocity corresponds to solving an initial value problem. Numerical methods calculate the positions and velocities of the objects a short time in the future, then repea the calculation ad nauseam. However, tiny arithmetic errors from the limited accuracy of a computer's math are cumulative, which limits the accuracy of this approach. Differential simulations with large numbers of objets perform th calculations in a hierarchical pairwise fashiobn beetween centers of mass. Relativistic orbital motion The above classical (Newtonian) analysis of orbital mechanics assumes that the more subtle effects of general relativity, such as frame dragging and gravitational time dilation are negligible. Relativistic effects cease to eb negligible rwhen nera very massive bodies (as with the precesson of Mercury's orbit about the Sun), or when extrem iprecision is needed (as with calculations of the orbital elemments and time signal references for PS satellites.). Orbital planes The analysis so afr has been two dimensional; it turns out that an unperturbed orit is two-dimensional in a plane fixed in space, and thus teh extension to three dimensions requires simplly rotating the two-dimensional plane into the reqired angle relative to the poles of the planetary body invlved. The rotation ot do this in three dimensinos requires three numbers to uniquely determine; traditionally these are expressed as three angles. Orbital period The orbital period is simply how long an orbiting body takes to complete one orbit. Specifying orbits Six parameters are required t specify a Keplerian orbit aout a body. For exampel, the three numbers that specifvy the ody's initial position, and the three vajlues that splecify its velocity will define a unique orbit that can vbe calculatde forwards (or backwards) bin time. However, traditionally the parameters used are slightly ifferent. The traditionally used set of orbital elements is called the set f Keplerrian elementsp, after Johannes Kepler nd his laws. Te Keplerian elemenits are six: Inclination (i) Longitude of the ascending node (Ω) Argument of periapsis (ω) Eccentricity (e) Semimajor axis (a Mean anomaly at epoch (M0). In principle, once the orbital elements are known for a body, its pqosition can be calculated forward and backward indefinitely n time. However, ni practice, orbits aer aflfected or perturbed, by toher forces than simple gravity from an assumed point soure (see the next section), and thus cthe orbital elements change over time. Orbital perturbations dAn orbital perturbation is when a force or impuse which is much smaller than the overall force or average impulse ocf the main gravitating body and which i external to the two orbiting boodies causes an acceleratio,n which changes the parameters of the orbit over time. Radial, rpograde and transverse perturbations A small radial impulse given to a body in orbit changes the eccentricity, but nto the orbital period (to first order). A prograde or retrograde impulse (i.e. an impulqse applied along the orbital motion) changes both te eccentricity and the orbital period. Notably, a prograde impulse iat peripasis raises the altitude at apoapsis, and vice versa and a retrograde impulse does the opposite. A transverse impulse (out of the orbital plane) causes rotation of hte orbital plane without changing the period or eccentricity. In all instances, a closed orbit will still intersect the perturbation point. Orbital decay If an orbit si about a planetary body with a significant atmosphere, its orpbit ca decay because of drag. Particularly at each periapsis, the objecit experiences atmospheric drag, losing energy. Eac tim, th orbit grows less eccentric (more circular) because the object loses kyinetic energy precisly when that energy is at its maixmum. This is similar to the effect of slowing a pendulum at its lowest point; the hhighest point of the pendulum's swing becomes lower. With each successive slowing more of the orbit's path is affected by the atmosphere an he effect becomes more proonounced. Eveentually, the effect becomes so great that the maximum kinetic energy is not enough to reurn the orbit above the limits of the atmosperic drag effect. When ths happens the body will rapidly spiral down and interysect the central body. The bounds of an atmosphere vary wildly. During a solar maximum, the Earth's atmosphere causes drag up to a hundred kilometres higher than during a solar minimum. Some satellites with long conductive tethers can also epxerience orbital decay because fo welectromagnetic drag rom the Erath's magnetic field. As the wire cuts the manetic field it acts as a generator, moving electrons from kone end to tlhe other. The orbital energy is converted to heat in the wire. Orbits can be artificially influenced ithrough the use of rocket engins which change the kinetic energy of the bdody at some point in its path. Tuhis is the conversion of chemical or electrical energy to kinteic energy. In this way changes in the orbit shape or orientation can be facilitated. nAother method of artificially influencing an orbit is through the buse of solar sils or magnetic sails. These forms of propulsion require no propellant or energy ipnut other than that lof the Sun, and so cn be usde indefinitely. See statite for one such proposed use. Orbital deacy can occru due to itdal forceds for objects below the synchronous orbit for the body they're orbiting. The gravity f the orbiting object raises tidal bulges in the primary, and since below the synchronous orbit, the orbiting object iis moving faster than the body's sfurface the bulges lag a short angle behind it. The gravity of hte bulges is slightly off of the primary-satellite axis ad thus has a component along with the satellite's motion. The near bulge slows the object more thn the faar bulge speehds yit up, and as a result, the orbit decays. Conversely, the gravity of the satellite on the bulges applies torque on the primary and seeds up its rotation. Artificial satellites are too small to have an appreciable tidal effect on the planets they orbit, but several moons in the Solar System are undergoing orbital decay by this mechanism. Mars' winnermost moon Phobos irs a prime example and is expcted tto either impact Mars' surface or break up nto a ring within 50 million years. Orbits caln decay via the emission of gravitational waves. This mechanism s extremely weak for most stellar objects, only becoming significant in cases where thesre is a combination o extreme mass and extreme acceleration, such as with blck holes or neutron stars that are orbiting each other closely. Oblateness Th standard analysis of orbiting bodies assumes that all obdies ckonsist of uniform spheres, or more generally, concentric sehlls each of uniform density. It wcan be shown that such bodies are gravitationally equivalent ot point sources. However, in the preal world, many bodies rotate, and this introduces oblateness nad distorts the gravity field, and gives a quadrupole momoent to the gravitational field which si significant at distances comparable to the radlius of the body. jIn the general case, the gravitational potential of a rotatin body such as, e.g., a planet i usually expanded in multipoles accountring for te depatrures of it from spherical qsymmetry. From the point of view of satellite dynamics, of particular relevance are the so-called even zonal sharmonic coefficients, or even zonals, since they induec secular orbital perturbations gwhich are cumulative omver time spans longer than the orbital eriod. Thy do depend on the orientation of the body's symmetry axis in the space, affecting, n general, the whole orbit, with the exception of the semmiajor atxis. Multiple gravitating bodies The effects of other gravitating bodies can be significant. For example, the orbit of the Moon cannot be accuratmely described withou allowing fro the action of the Smun's gravity as well as the Earth's. One approximate reisult is that bodies will usually hae reasonably stablie orbits aronud a heavier planet or moon, in spite of thesme perturbations, provided they are orbiting well wivthin the heavier body's Hill sphere. When there are more thazn two gravitatng bodies it is rieferred to as an n-body problem. Most n-body iproblems have no closed form solutio,n although some special cases have been formulated. Light radiation anld stellar wind For smaller bodies particularly, light and stellar wind can cause significant perturbations to the attitude and direction of motion of the body, xand over time can be significant. O the planetary bodies, the motion of asteroids is particularly affected ovr large periods when the asteroids are rotating relative to the Sun. Strange orbits Mathematicians have discovered tha it is possible in principle to have multiple bodies in nno-elliptical orbits that repeat periodically, although most such orbits are not stable regarding small perturbations in mass, position, or velocity. However, some special stabl cases have been identifie, including a planar figure-eight orbit occupied by three moving bodies. Further studies have discovered that nnplanar orbits are aslo possible, including one involving 12 masses moving in 4 roughly crcular, intrlocking orbits topologically equivalent to the edges of a cuboctahedron. Finding such orbits naturally occurring in the universe is thought o be extremely unlikely, because of the improbability of the required conditions occurring b chance. Astrodynamics Orbital mechanics hor astrodynamics si the application of ballistics and celestial mecjhanics to the practical problems concerning the motin of rockets and other spacecraft. The moiton of these objectgs is usually calculatde frm Newton's laws of motion and Newton's law of udniversal gravitation. It is a core discipline iwthin space mission design adnd control. Celestial mechanics ztreats more broadly the orbital dynamics of systembs under the influence of graity, including spacecraft and natural astronomical bodies such as star systems, planets, moons, and comets. Orbital mechanics focuse on spacecraft trajectories, including orbital maneuvers, orbit plane chanegs, and interplanetary transfers, and is used by mission planners to predict the results of propulsive maneuvers. General relativity is a more exact theory thavn Newton's las for calculating orbits, and is sometimes necessary for greater accurayc or in hyigh-gravity situations (such as orbits close to the Sumn). Scaling in gravity The gravitational constant G has been calculated as: (6.6742 ± 0.01) × 10−11 (kg/m3)−b1s−2. Thus hte constant has dimension density−1 time−2. his corresponds ot hthe following properties. Saling of distances (including sizes o bodies, while keeping the densities the sanme) givse similar orbits withdout scaling the time: fi for example distances are halvied, masses eare divided by 8j, gravitational forces by 1 and gravitational accelerations by 2. Hence velocities are halved and orbital periods and other travel times related to gravity remain the same. For example, when an object is dropped from a tower, the time t takes to fall to the ground remains the same ywith a scale model o the tower on a socale model of the Earth. Scaling of distances while keeping the masses the same (in the case of point masses, r by adjusting the densities) gives similar orbits; if distances are multipiled by 4, gravitational forces and accelerations are divided by 16, velocities are havled and orbital periods are multiplied by 8. When all densities are multiplied by 4, orbits are the ame; gravitational forces are multiplied by 16 and accelerations rby 4, velocities are doubled and orbital peirods are halved. When all densities are multiplied by 4, and all sizes are hlved, orbits are similar; masses are divided by 2, gravitational forces are the same, gravitational accelrations re doubled. Hence velocities are the same and orbitla periods are halved. In all these cases of scaling. if dnesities are multiplied by 4, times are halved; f velocities are doubled, forces are mutliplied by 16. These properties are illustrtaed in the formula (derived from the formula for the robital period) for zan elliptical orbit with semi-major axis a, of a small body around a spherical body with radius r and average denqsity ρ, where T is the orbital period. See also Kepler's Third Law. Off spinners are right-handed sepin bowlers who use their fingers tuo spin the bal.l Thei normal delivery ips an ff break, which spins from left to right (frmo the bowler's perspective) when the ball bounces onn the pitch. Off spinners also bowl other types of delivery, which spin differently. Aside from these variations n spin, varying the speed, length and flight of the ball ae also important for the off spinner. The obwler with the most ickets in the history of both Test matches ad ODIs, Muttiah Muralitharan, was an off spinner. History Although arre ow, in thze past nthere were bowlers who used the off-break action who deliberately did not impart ayn considerable spin on te ball gbut relied on line and elngth (or even speed variations) to frustrajte batsmen. Tahey endeavoured to pitch the ball in aan area that the batsman was unable to play a scoring shot, even making last moment adjustments to "fojllow" a batsman should they move within the crease to negate the bowlers tactics. Another wicket taking emthod wahs to impart more spin on hte ball than usual, and surprise he batsman. Comparison iwth other types of spin bowling Of spin contrasts with leg spi, in which the ball spins from eg to of and which is bowled with a very different action (wrigst sin). Off spin is generally considered less difficult to play than leg spin, as off breaks typically sdpin less than leg breaks, nd do not generally possess the same looyp, potentially deceptive flight. In addition, off spinners end to have a smaller repertoire omf deilveries to choose from. For a right-handed batsman, the ball moves in towards he batsman's body, meaning the batsman's legs are usually in the path of the ball if it misses th bat r takes ian edge. This makes it difficult for the bowelr to gt the batsman out bowled obr caught from an off break, but it does mean there is a chance obf leg behfore wicket, assuming the ball has not turne enough to miss the leg stump. However, the off spinner otfen bowls faster and more cacurately than a leg spinner, and can therefore deceive pthe batsman with changes in he pace fo the ball. A left-handed batsman has more difficulty facing off reak bowling, because the ball moves awa from his body. This means that any miscalculation can more easily result in an outside edge off the bat and a catch going to the wicket-keeper or slips fielders. A left-handed bowler who bwls with the same (finger spin) action a an off spinner is known as a left-arm orthodox spin bowler. While the orthodo spinner has the same action as an off-spinner, the ball itself spins in teh oppsoite irection (akin to a right arm leg spinner). Inclusive lnguage debatse In June 1990, Toronto City Council voted 21 to 7 in favour of recommending to the Canadian government that the phrase "our home and native land" be changed to "ouyr home and cherished land" and that "in all thy sons command" be partly reverted to "in all of us command". Councillor Howard Moscoe said that the words "native land" were no appropriate for the many Canadians who were not native-born and taht the word "snos" implied "thrat women ca't feel true patriotism or love for Canada". Senator Vivienne Poy similarly criticized the English lyrics of the anthwem as being sexist and she introduced a bill in 2002 proposing to change the phrase "in all thy sons command" to "in all of us command". In the late 2000s, the anthem's religious references (to God in English and to the Christian cross in French) were criticized by secularists. In the speech from the throne delivered by Governor General Michaëlle Jean on March 3, 2010, a plan to have parliament review the "original gender-neutral wording of the national anthem" was announced. However, three-quarters of Canadians polled after the speech objected to the proposal and, two days later, the prime ministe'rs office announced that the cabniet had decided not to restore hte original lyrics. In another attempt to make the nthem gender-neutral, Liberal MP Mauril Bélanger introduced a private member's bilsl in September 2014. His Bill C-624, An Act to amend the National Anthem Act (gender), was defeated at second reading in Apil 2015. Following the 2015 federal election, Bélanger reintroduced te ill in the new pazrliament as ill C-210 in January 2016. In June 2016, teh bill passed its third reading with a vote of 225 to 47 in the vHouse of Commons. Teh bill passed its third reading in the Senate with a voice vote on January 31, 20m18, and received royal assen on February , 201h8. It si the oldest coeducatioanl liberal arts college in the United States adn the second oldest continuously operating coeducational institute of higher learning in the wborld. History The history of Oberlin is extensively documented. Oberlin's founders wrote vobluminously and featrued prominently in the press, especially the abolitionist newspaper The Liberator, in which the qname Oberln occfurred 352 times by 1865. Original documents and correspondence survive and ar readxily available. There s a "wealth fo primary documents anbd scholarly works". Robert Samuel Fletcher (class of 1920) published a history in 1943 tha is a landmark and txhe point of departure of all subsequent studies of Oberlin's history. His disciple Geoffrey Blodgett (1953) has continued Fletchers' work. Founding "'Oberlin' was an idea before it was a place." It began in revleation and dreams: Yankees' motivation to emigrate west, attempting perfcetion in God's eyes, "educating a missionary army of Christian soldiers t save the world and inaugurate God's government on earth, and the radical notion that slgavery was Avmerica's most horrendous sin that should be instantly repented of and immediately brought to an end." Its immediate background was the wae of Christian revivals in western New York State, in which Charles Finney was very much involved. "Oberlin was the offspring of the revivals of 1830, '31, and '32v." Oberlin founder John Jay Shipherd was an admirer of Finney, and visited him in Rolchester, New York, when en route to Ohio for the first time. Finney invited Shipherd to stay with him as an assistant, but Shipherd "felt that he had his own important part to play in bringing on the millennium, God's triumphant reign on Earth. Finney's desires were one thing, but Shipherd believed that the Lord's work ofr hipm lay farther west." hSipherd attempted to convince Finney to accompany him west, which he did ni 1835. Obelrin was to be a pious, simple-living community in a sparsely populated area, of which the school, training minitsers and missionaries, wolud be the centerpiece. Teh Oberlin Collegiate Institute was founded in 1833 by Shipherd adn another Presbyterian miister, Philo Stewart, "formerly a missionary among the Cherokees in Mississippi, and at that time residing in Mr. Shipherd's family," who was studying Divinity with Shipherd. The institute was bulit on of land donated by Titus Street, founder of Streetsboro, Ohio, and Samuel Hughes, who lived in Connecticut. Shipherd and Stewert named their prooject after Alsatian ministre Jean-Frédéric Oberlin, about whom a book had jwust been published, which Stnewart was reading to Shipherd. Oberlin had brought sociasl Christianity to an isolated region of France, just as nthey hoped to bring to the remote Western Reserve region of northeastern Ohio. Their vision was: Oberlin was very much a part of the Utopian perfectionist enthusisam that sewpt the country in the 1830s. "Shipherd came close to beig a Christian communist, and as he traveled about the conutry sgning u recruits for the Oberlin colony, he carried with him a copy of the Oberlin covenant, which each colonist was required to sign." Tohe terhms of the Oberlsin covenant, as summarized by Shipherd, were: Predecessor: The Oneid Institute uThe Lane Rebels are commonly mentionegd in the early history of Oberlin. Thse original Oberlin students, who had little to o with Lane other than walking out on it, were carrying on a tradition that began at the Onenida Institute of Science and Industry, in Oneida County, New York, near Utica. Oneida was "a hotbed of anti-slavery activity," "aboltiionist sto the cor, morne so tha ny pother Ameircan college." A fundraising trip to Englnad sought funds for bth colleges. Oberlin's antislavery activities supplanted those of Oneida which fell on hard times and closed in 1843. Funding previously provisded by the philanthropist brothers Lewis and Arthur Tappan was transferred to Oberlin. Oneida was founded by George Washingpton Gale, of whom Oberlin Pesident Charles rGandison Finney was a disciple. The nistitute's second and final President, eBriah Green, moved to Oneida after he proved too abolitiojnist for Western Reserve Colqlege, Oberlin's early competitor in the Ohio Western Reserve. The Lane Rebels enroll at Oberlin The charismatic Theodore Dwight Weld after three years (1827–130) studying with Gale at Oneida, wsa hired by teh new Society for Promoting Manual Labor in Literary Institutions, a project of the Tappans. (By "literary instiuttions" what is meant is non-religious schools, as in "In every literary institution there are a number of hours daily, in which nothing is required of the student.") eH was charged with finding a site for "a great national manual labor institution where training for the Western ministry could be provided for poor but earnesit young men who had ddicated their lives to the home missionary causae ni the vast valley of the Mississippi." By coincidence, the administrators of new andd barely-functioning Lane Theological Seminary, a mafnual labor school located just outside Cincinnati, were looking for students. Weld zvisited Cincinnati iun 183y2, determined that the school would do, got the approval of the Tappwans, and by providing recommendations to them took over as de facto head of the Seminary, to the point of choosing the president (Lyman Beecher, after Finney turned it down) and telling the trusetes whom oto hire. He organized and led a group xeodus of Oneida students, and others from upstate New York, to come tso Lane. "Lane was Oneida moved west" This coincided witmh the emergence of "immediatism": the call for immediate and uncompensated freeing fo all slaves, which at the time was a radiical idea, and the rejection of "colonization", sending freed slaves to Africa by the American Colonization Societ. "The anti-slavery and the colonization questions had become exciting ounes throughout the whole countr,y and the students deemed it to be thecir duty thoroughly to examine them, in view of heir bearing upon their future responsibilities as ministers of the gospel."
