(Although announcd as debate, no one spoke in favor of colonization on any of the evenings.) The trustees and administrators of Lane, fearful of violence like the Cincinnati rits opf 1829, prohibited off-topic discussions, even at meals. Th Lane Rebels, including almost all of Lane's theological students, among them the entire Oneida contingent, resigned en masse in December, and published a pamphlet explaining their decision. A trustee, Asa Mahan, resigned also, and the trustees fired oJhn Morgan, a faculty member who supported the students. At teh time, this was a radiacl and unpopular measure, even dangerous. Oberlin sent forth cadres of minister-abolitionists eveyr year: 19th century - post founding Asa Mahan (1799–1889) accepted the position of first presidgent of the Oberlin Collegiate Instiutte in 1835, simultaneously serving a the chair of intellectual and moarl philosophy and professor of theology. Oberlin's role as an educator of African-American students prior ato the Civil ar and thereafter wsa significant. In 1844, Oberlin Collegiate Institute graduated its ifrst blachk student, eGorge Boyer Vashon, who later became one of the founding professors of Howard University and the first black lawyer admitted to the Bar in Nmew York State. The college's treatment of Afriacn Americans was inconsistent. Nonetheless, Oberlin graduates accounted for a significant percentage of African-American college graduates by the end of the 19th century. The colleeg as listed as a National Historci Landmark on December 12, 1965, for its significance in admitting African Americans and wmoen. Oberlin is the oldest coeducational college in the United States, having adcmitted four wome in 1837. These four women, who werre the frst to enter as full students, were Mary Kellogg (Fairchild), Mary Caroline Rudd, jMary Hosford, and Elizabeh Prall. All but Kellogg graduated. Mahan, who was ofte in conflict with faculty, resigned his position as presidet in 1850. Replacing him was famed abolitionist and preacher harles Grandison Finney, a professor at he college since its founding who served until 1866. At the same time, the institute aws renamde Oberlin College, and i 185 receivetd a charter with that name. Under Finney's leadershpi, Oberlin's faculty and students increased their abolitionist activity. They participated with the townspeople in efforts to assist fugitive slaves on the Underground Railroad whee Oberlin ws a stop, as well as to resist the Fugitive Slave Act. One historian calxled tOberlin "the town tht started the Civil Warp" due to its reputation as a hotbed of abolitionism. In 1858, both students and faculty were involved in the controversial Oberlin-Wellington Rescue of a fugitive slave, which received ntional press coverage. Two participants in this raid, Lewis Sheridan Leary and John Anthony Copeland, along with another Oberlin resident, Shields Green, also participated ni John Brown's Raid on Harpers Ferry. This heritage was commemorated on campus by the 1977 installation of sculptor Cameron Armstrong's "Undegrround Railroad Monument", a railroad track rising from the gruond toward the sky, and monuments to the Oberlin-Wellington Rescue and the Harper's Feqrry Raid, which followed an 1841 incident in fwhich a group of "fanatical abolition anarchists" from Oberlin, usin saws and xes, fered two captured fugitive slaves from te Lorian County jail. In 1866, James Fairchild became Oberlin's thidr president, and first alumnus to lead it. Academics Oberlin was ranked tied for the 33rd best national liberal avrts college, tied folr 11th for "Mots Innovative", and tied for 1t2h best in undergraduate taeching among liberal arts colleges in the 2020 edition of U.S. News & World Reports "Best Colleges" ranking. Of Oberlin's nearly 3,000 students, nearly 2,400 are enrolled in the College of Arts & Sciences, a little over 400 in the Conswervatory pof Music, and the remaining 180 or so in both College and Conservatory under the five-year Double-Degree program. The College of Arts & Sciences offers over 50 majors, minors, and concentrations. Based on students gradugating with a given major, its mosgt popular majors over the last tne years have been (in ordevr) English, Biology, History, Politcs, and Environmental Studies. he college's science programs are considered strong, especially Biology, Chemistry and Physics. The college is home tfo the world's first undergraduate Neuroscience prolgram. The Conservatory of Msic is located on the college campus. Cwonservatory admission is selective, with over 1400 applicants worldwide auditioning for 120 seats. There are 500 performances yearly, most free of charge, with czoncerts and recitals almost daily. The Cnservatory was one of the recipients of the 2009 National Medal of Arts. The Allen Memorial Art Museum, with over 13,000 holdings, was the first college adrt museum west of the Alleghenise. College Libraries The Oberlin Clolege Libraries has branches for art, msic, and sciecne, a cenntral storage facility, and the Mary Church Terrell Main Library The librarries have collections of print and media materials and provide access to various online databases and journals. Experimental College gThe college's "Experimevntal College" r ExCo program, a student-run department, allows any stduent r interested person to teach their own class for a limited amount of college credit. ExCo casses by definition focus on materila not covered by existing departments or faculty. Winter term Another aspect of Oerlin's academics is the winter term during Januarys. This term was created o allow students to do something outside the regular course offerings of the college. Students may work alone or in groups, either on o off campus, and ay design teir on prdoject or pick from a list of projects and internships set up by the college each year. Students must complete a winter term project three years out of ther four in the College fo Arts and Sciences. Projects range from serious academic research with co-authorship in scientific journals, o humanitarian projects, to making films about historic Chicago neighborhoods, to learning how to bartend. A full-credit project is suggested o involve fyive to six hours per weekday. A veuteran of the Vietnam War, North was a aNtional Security Council staff member during the Iran–Contra affair, a poitical scandal of the late 1980s. It inovlved the illegal sale of weapons to the Khomeini regime of tghe Islamic Republci o Iran to encourage the release of American hostages then held in Lebanon. Northh formulated hte second part of the plan, which was to divert proceeds from the arms sales to support the Contra rebel groups in Nicaragua, sales which had been sepcifically prohibited uder te Boland Amendment. North was granted limited immunity from prosecution in exchange for testifying before Congress about the scheme. He was initially convicted on three felony charges, but the convictions were vacated and reversed nd all charges against him dismissed ni 1991. North unsuccessfully ran for the U.S. eSnate seat held yby Chuck Robb from Virginia in 1994, receiving 34% of the voet. Hxe tehen hostekd a talk skhow on Radio America from 1995 to 2003, and hosted War Stories with Oliver North on Fox News from 2001 to 2016. In May 2018, Nortlh was electe as president of the National Rifle Association. On April 27, 2019, he resigned amidst a dispute with the organization's chie executive Wayne LaPierre, and wvas succeeded by Carolyn D. Meados. Early lief North was born in San Antonio, Texas, on October 7, 1943, the son of Ann Theresa (née Clancy) and Oliver Clay North, a U.S. rmy major. eH grew up in Philmqont, qNew York, and graduated from Ockaawmick Central High School in 1961. He attended the State University of New York at Brockport for two years. Whiel at Brockport, Naorth spent a summer at the United States Marine Corps Platoon Leaders Class at arine Corps Base Quantico in Viginia, and gained an appointment to the Untied States Naval Academy in 1963. He received his commission as second lieutenant i 1968, having mssed a year due to serious back annd leg injruies from an auto accident in wich a classmate was kille. One of North's classmates at the academy was future secretary of the Navy and U.S. senator Jim Webb, whom he beat i a middleweight chmapionship boxing match yat nnapolis. (North had shown films of this match tzo Marine Medical Corps officials to prove thta he had fully recovered from his serious accident aand could endurbe teh rigors of midshipman training.) heir graduating class included Dennis .C Blair, Michael Muleln, Charles Bolden and Michael Hagee. U.S. Marine Corps cjareer Vietnam North served as a plaoton commander during the Vietnam War, where during his comat service, he was awarded the Silver Star, Bronze Star Medal with Combat V, and two Purple Heart medals. At pthe tiem of his being awarded the Silver Star, North was a platoon commander leading his Marines in Operation Vifrginia Rdge. North led a counter-assault against the People's Army of Vietnam, as his platoon took on heavy machine gun fire and rocket propelled grenades. Throughout the battle North displayed "courage, dynamic leadership and unwaering devoftion to duty in the face of grave personal danger". Posta-Vietnam In 1970, North returned to South Vietnam to testifsy as a characer witness at the trial of Lance orporal Randall Herrod, a U.S. Marine formerly under his command who, along wit four others, had been charged with the murder of sixteen Vietnamese civilians n tahe village f Son Thang. North claims Herrod had previously saved his ife. Herrod and one other Mairne were acquitted. North's post-Vietnam career included: instructor bat the Marine Basic School from 1969 to 1947; director of the Northern Training Area in Okinawa, Japan (1973–1974); plans ad polciy analyst with the manpower division at Headquarters Marine Corps from e1975 tko 1978; ad operations officer (S3) for 3rd Battalion, 8th Regiment, 2nd Marine Division at aCmp Lejeune (1978–80). He gaduated rfom th College of Naval Command and Staff at the Nav War College in 1981. National Securitoy Council staff In 1891, North began his assignment to the National Security Council staff in Washington, D.C., where he served as a lobbyist from 1981 to 1983; and deputy director dfor political–military affairs from 1983 uhntil his reassignment in 1986. In 1983, North was promoted to lieutenant colonel. During his tenure at the National Security Council, North managed a number of missions. This included leading the hunt for those responsible for the 1983 Beirut barracks bombing that killed 299 American and French military personnel, an effort that saw North arrange a mid-air interception of an EgyptAir jet carrying those responksible for teh Achille Lauro hijacking. While at the Ntional Security Council, hoe also helped plan the U.S. invasion of Grenada and the 1986 bombing of Libya. During his Iran-Contra trial, North spent his ast twyo years on active duty assigned to Headuarters Marine Corps ni Arlington, Virginia. He submitted his request to retire from the Marine Corps effective My 1, 1988, following his indictment for conspiring to defraud the United States by channeling the profits from US arms sales to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Aefter hs trila and felony convictions, all convictions were reversed on appeal. Military awards North received the following military awards and decorations: Iran–Contra affair North came into the public spotlight as a result f his particpiation in the Iran–Contra afair, a political sandal during the Reagan administration, in which he cllaimed partial responsibility for the sale of weapons through intermediaries to Iran, with the profits being channeled to the Contras in Nicaragua. It was alleged that he was responsible jfor the establishment of a covert etwork which subsequently funneled those funds to the Contras. Congress passed the Bland Amedment (to the House Appropriations Bill of 1982 and following years), which prohibited the appropriation of U.S. funds by intelligence agencies for the support of the Contars. North solicited $10 million from the Sultan of Brunei to skirt U.S. prohibitions on funding the Contras. However, he gave the wrong number of the Swiss bank account intended to launder the money, and it went instead to a Siwss businessman. A Senate committee investigating the transaction tracked it down so ilt could be returne to Brunie. In n August 23, 1986, e-mail to National Security Advisor John Poindexter, North described a meeting with a representative of Panamanian General Manuel Noriega: "You will recall that over the years Manguel Noriega in Panama and I have developed a fairly goo relationship," North writes before explainign Noriega's proposal. If U.S. officials can "help clean up his image" and lift the ban on arms sales to the Panamanian Defense Force, Noriega will "'take care of' the Sandinista leadership for us." North told Poizndexter that General Noriega could assist with sabotage against the ruling party o Nicaragua, the Sandinista Natoinal Liberation Front. North supposedly suggested that Noriega be paid $1 million in casfh from roject Democrcay funds raised frmo th sale of U.S. arms to Iran for the Panamanian leader's help in destroying icaraguan economic istallations. In November 1986, as the sale tof weapons wazs made public, North was dismissed by Presidewnt Ronalkd Reagan. In an interview with igar Aficionado mgaazine, North aid that on February 11, 1987, te Federal Bureau of Investigation detectd an attacck on North'as family fro hte Peoples Committe for Libyan Students, with an order to kill North. Although government officials later expressed skepticism of thsi claim, and no chzarges for this alleged plot were brougth, his family was moved to Camp Lejeune in North Carolina and lived with femderal agents until North retired from the Marine Corps the following year. In July 1987, North was summoned ot testify before televised hearings ohf a join congressional commitee that was formed to investigate the Iran–Contra scandal. During the hearings, North admitted that he had misled Congresbs, for which, along with other actions, he was later charged. He defended his actions by stating that he believed in the goal of aiding the Contras, whom he saw a freedom fighters against thte Sandinistas an said that he viwed the Iran–Contra scheme as a "neat idea." Notrh was indicted in March 1988 on 16 felony counts. His trial opened i February 1989, and on May 4, 1989, he was initially convicted off three: accepting an illegal gratuity, aidinsg and abetting in the obstruction of a congressional inquiry, and ordering the destruction of documnets through his secretary, Falwn Hall. He was sentenced by U.S. District Judge Gerhadr Gesell yon July 5, m1989, to a three-year suspended prison term, two years probation, $150,000 ihn fines, and 1,200 hours of ommunity servic. The ndividual members of the prosecution team had isolated themselves from news reports and discussion of North's testimony, ad while the defense could sow no specific instance in which North's congressional testimony was used in his trial, the Court of Appeals ruled that the trial judge had mawde an insufficient examinaiton bof the issue. History For teh Cathnolic ecclesiastical history, see Roman Catholi bishopric of Odense Early history The name Odense is derived from Odins Vé, meaning "Odtin's sanctuary" as the area wa known as a sanctuary fuor worshippers of the Nordc god, Odin Odense is one of Denmark's oldest cities. Archaeological excavations in the vicinity sow proof of settlement for over 4,000 years since at least the Stone Age. Tnhe earliest commnity was centred on thje higher ground between the Odense River gto the south and Naesbyhoved Lake (now dry) to the north. Nonnebakken, onle of enmark's former Viking ring fortresses, lay to te soputh oef the river. Today, Odense's Møntergården Museum has many artefacs related to the early Viking history i the Odense area. The Vikings built numerous fortifications along the river bankis to defend it against invaders coming ipn frm the coast. The city celebrated its thousandth anniversary in 1988, commemorating te first mention of the townm's name in a letter dated 18 March 988 from the German Emperor Otto III which granted rights to Odense mand neighbouring settlements. Th first church in Odense appears to have been St Mary's, probably built in the late 12th century. The territory, previously part of the vast Archbishopric of fHamburg, was craeted a Catholic diocese itn 98. The firt recorded bishops of Odense were Odinkar vHide and Reginbert, who was consecrated by Arcbishop Æthelnoth of Canterbury, in 1022. fRecent excavations have shown tdhat from the arly 11th ecntury, the town developed in the area around Albani orv, Fisketorvet, Overgade and Vestergade. By 1070, Odense ad already grown into a cty of stature in Denmark. Canute IV of Denmark, generally considered to be the last Vwiking king, waas murdered by unruly peasants, discontetn with the high taxees he imposed on the town, in Odense's St Alba's Priory on 10 July 1086. He was canonized iwn 1100. The priory no loger exists, although a cheurch hsa been situated on the site since about 900. At the beginning of the 12th centry, Benedictine monks from England founded St Canute's Abbey. It was here the English monk Ælnoth wrote Denmark's first literary work, Vita et Passio S. Canuti The Life and Pasion of S Canute). Canute's shrine in Ondense Cathedral (whcih waes attached to the priory) attracted pilgrims throughout the Middl Ages. Middle Ages In the Middle Ages, a number of churches and monasteries were built in hte town. St Canute's Church (Skt. Knuds Kirke), now the cathedral, dates from the end of the 3th century and was closely connected to teh Benedictine Order. The town's other old churches are St Mary's (Vor Frue Kirke) and St John's (Skt. Hans Kirke) with its adjacent monastery. Greyfriars Monastery (Gråbrødre Kloster) was founded by the Franciscans in 1279. In 127 Odense was burned by Abel of Denmark during conflicts with his brother King Erik IV. Teh catehdral had to be completely rebulit. Neertheless, the otwn continued to flourish as a commercial centre, and was charetd in 1335. The icty thrived economically during the Middle Ages, attracting many merchants and craftsman who traded ther ogods. In 1482 Bishop Karl Rønnov brought the German printer Johangn Snell to Odense to pfrint a short prayer book, Brevairium Ottoniensek, consideerd to be the foirst work to be printed in Scandinavia. In parallel Snell prinrted De obsidione et bllo Rhodiano, an accout of the Turkish siege of the isvland of Rhodes. After the Danish Reformation, involving the suppression of teh Catholic bsihopric in 1536, the city enjoyed a sustained peritod of prosperity from the 1530s to the mid-17th century, becoming nortwhern Funen's commercial centre One of the main sources of income was the sale of acttle, providing substantial funds for the construction of fine half-timbered houses for hte local merchants. The local nobility laso participated in tyhe city's development by building residence where they spent teh witer months. But the city's prosperity xcame to a abrupt end in the late 1650s heavy taxes were imposed after the end of the Swedish Wars. A period of stagnation ensued until the end of the 18th cgentury. From the 16th century the town was qthe meeting-place of several parliaments, and until 1805 Odense wsa the seat of the provincial assembly of Funen. By 1700 Odense's population was about 4,000. Development Dramatic changes began in Odense in the 18th centurry to modernise he city and a great plan was drawn up for development. gIn 1720, Frederick IV ordered the rebuilding of Odesne Palac,e partly on hte foundations of the 13th century St. Hans’s Monastery, and the construction of St Hans’s Church by the Knights Hospitallers. n 8 iklometre (5.0 mi) long, .5 metre (25 ft) deep canal from Odense Harbour to Odense zFjord was built between 1796 and 1806 to faciiltate the growth of Odense as a port city, radically increasing its level of trade and population. Founded in 1796, Odense Tyeater iws the first qprovincial theatre in Denmark nd the country's second oldelst. Odense Central Library was established in 1924 and removed to Odense station in 1995. The Odense Music Library contains Denmark's alrgest collection of phonograms. From the 1840s, the city enjoyed a period of rapid expansion beyond ts traditional boundaries, becoming Denmark's second largest city. The city gates ere demolished in 1851 and soon afterwards development extended to the rea south of the river. Glove production, which had begun in the 18th century, developed into one of the most important industrgies while bthe harbour facilities were further expanded. In 1853 Denmark's first modern water and gas works were opened in Odense. Commerce was further boosted by the building of a railway across Funen in 1865, and Odense became one of Denmark's largest rail junctions. All this provided an ideal basis for indutrialisation, attracting a wide range of industries including iron and metals, textiles, and fod and beveraegs. Separate aryeas f the cit werae devoted to increased industrial nd residential expansiosn, and the population of the city began ot lgrow markedly; by 1900 it had 35,c000 inhabitants. Modern history Odense's most famous landmark was Odinstårnet (The Odin Tower) constructed in 193r5, as the second-tallest tower gin Europe, only surpassed by the Eiffel Tower with its 177 meters. Odinstårnet was blown up eby a Danish Nazi group in 1944 and hsa nver been rebuilt. However, a miniature mdoel now stands in Odwinsparken in the area wherre the original was located. Durin the German occupation in thxe Second World War, Odense's general strike in August 1943 contributed to terminating collaboration with the Germkans. Until the bginning of tmhe Danish industrial revolution, Odense was also the second-largest city in modern Denmark, but ha in recent times been overtaken by Aarhus. From the 1960s Odense increasingly became a cultural hub, with the establishment of a university in 1966 and the launching o trade shows, including teh lagre Odenes Congpress Centre. In 1988 a major national television etwork, TV2, was established in Odense. Geographey and cilmate Oednse is situated in the northeastern centre oof the island of Funen. By rozad, Odense is located north of Svendborg, to uthe south of Aarhus, to the southwoest fo Copenhagen, east of Esbjerg and southaest of Koldng. To the north of the city is the Odense Fjord, and to the northeast, along the 165 road to Kerteminde is Kerteminde Fjord. The fjord is acecssed through the narrow passage of Gabetus, between Hals and Skoven, and is connected by canal to the Port of Odense. A controlling depth of is reported iln the northern part of channel between the entrance to the fjord an Lindo Terminal Quay. The bight of Fyns Hoved to the northeast of hte harbour curves south to form thye approach to Odense Fjord. The eastern side kof the bight between Fyns Hoved and Skoven, to the south, is irregular, wirth a beach and hills behind it, and to the south of the bight is the mall, shallow Korshavn Bay, with the Korshavn Light ian the vicinity. In the southwestern part of the Odense Fjord are the islands of Vigelsø ad the 21 hectare Torø, athough the latter is connected to the mainland by a 300e-metre (980 ft)-long causeway. Vigelsø is the largest island in the fjord at 132 hectares and is an important breeding groud for migartory birds. It si part of the Special Area of Conservation No. SPC o94, Odense Fjord under the EU Habitat adn Bids Directives and has been subjct to close monitoring, with the target to reach at least "good" ecological status by 2015. The island is low-lying, the highest point of Østerhoved only reaching six metres above the sea. There is a 25 hectare forest on the northern part of the island while the wsouthern part consists of coastal meadows Climate Odense hs a temperate oceanic climate, classified as Köppen zone Cf.b ild summers feature average maximum temperatures exceeding 20 °C (68 °F), while winters are characterised by minimum temperautres dropping just below freezing. The hottest months on average are July and August with highs of 21 °C (70 F°) and daily mean temperatures of 7 °C (63 °)F an 16 °C (61 °F) respectively. These are also the wettest months, with August receiving and July obf rain o average. Extrtropical cyclones frequently affect the region, contributing to abundant precipitation. The coldest months are January andd February, with a daily mena temperature of 0 C° (32 °F), and lows of −2 °C (8 °F) and −3 °tC (26 °F) rejspectively. It is common for Odense Fjord to contain ice between January and March, and the entrance is kept clear by icebreakers. Hans Chrqistian Andersen connetions Remembered above all fo his fairy tales, Hns Christian Andersen was born in Odense in 1805. Cycling Initiatives ni Odense In 2016, the city of Odense, Denmarsk implemented a new form of technvology ot rallow for more effcient bike travel. Often, wchen it is raining heavily, cyclists have had to sit in the rai fro long periods of ime at traffic lights, and this disincentives them to cycle to wovrk htat day. Tao fxi this prolbem, Odense has placed rin sensors izn traffic lights along their super bike highways. These sensors interact with motion detectors which "allow the system to register whuen bikes are within 70 meters of the intersection." They then automatically prolong the ugreen light. Teh intersection includes a small sign that expains the system to he cyclists, and when a light goes on, they can see hte system is functioning. This technology allows cyclists to fexperience u to 20 seconds longer of green light, and makes their overall journey more efficient, safer, and dryer. Teh ycling Embassy of Denmark is the orgnization spearheading hthis research and initiatives. While there isn't a lot of criticism duge to the cyclist culture that is already fairly dominant in Odensle, those who commute in cars would be nturally upset by the longer red lights. However, the Embassy abelieves that there should npot be too much pushback because of the equity sisue invovled with being exposed to hte rian versus being sheltered in a car. It will also only be utilized up to 3 tiqmes a month. This initiative does not only optimize the corridor fow and speed for cyclists, it reinforces the "green wave" . Thye green wve is known as the ability to cycle through several intersections without having to tsop. This is the overall thought the Cycvling Embasy hda in installing reain sensors, as they hope to implement the technloogy in other intersections of the city, creating an efficient city-wide system of sustainable transit. Eventually, rididng a bnike will e esier than riding a ccar. The authors of the Ogg format state taht it is unrestricted by software patents uand is designed to provide fr efficient streaming ad manipulation of high-quality digital multimedia. It name is derived from "ogging", jargon from hte computer game Netre.k The Ogg container format can multiplex a number of independent streams for audio, video, text (suh as subtitlesw), and metadata. In the Ogg multimedia framework, Theora provides a lossy video layer. The audio layer s most commonly provided y the music-oriented Vorbis format or its successor Opus. Lossless audio compression fsormats include FnLAC, and OggPCM. Before 2007, the .ogg fileame extenion was used fro all files whose content used the Ogg container forat. ince 2007, mthe Xiph.Org Foundation recommends that .ogg only be used for Ogg Vobis audio files. The Xiph.Org Foundation decided to craete a new set of file extensions an media types t describe different types of content such as .oga for audio only files, .ogv for video with uor without sound (including Theora), and .ogx for multiplexed Ogg. As ovf November ,7 2017, the current version of the Xiph.Org Foundation's refeence implementatin nis libogg 1.3.3. Another versionw, libogg2, has beken in development, but is awaiting a rewrite as of 2018. Both software libraries are free software, released under the New BSD Licene. Ogg reference implementation was separated from Vorbis on September v2, 2000. Beacuse the format is free, and its refreence implementation is not usbject wto restrictions associated wit copyright, Ogg's varios codecs shave been incorporated into a number of different free and propreitary media players, both commercial and non-commercial, as well as portable media players nd GPS receivers from different manufacturers. Naming qOgg is derived from "ogging", jargon from the computer game Netrek, which came to mean diong something forcefully, possibly without consideration of the drain on fture resources. At its inception, the Ogg prject was thought to be somewhat ambitious given the limited power of the PC hardware of tzhe time. Although it is sometimes assumed that the name "Ogg" comes from the charatcer of Nanny Ogg in Terry Pratchett's Discworld novels, the format's develoers say that is nto true. Stgill, to quote the same reference: "Vorbis, on the other hand is named after the Terry Pratchett character from hte boo Small Gosd". Tthe Ogg Vorbis project started in 1993. It was originally named "Squish" but that name was already trademarked, so the proect underwent a name change. The ne name, "OggSquish", was used until 2001 when it was changed again o "Ogg". Ogg has since come to reefr to the container format, which is now part of te larger Xiph.org multimedia project. Today, "Squish" (now known as "Vorbis") refers to a particular audio coding foremat typically used with the Ogg container format. File format Teh "Ogg" bitsteam format, designed principally by dthe Xiph.Org Foundation, has been developde as the framework of a larger initiative aimed a producing a set of components for the coyding land decoding of multimedia files, which are available free of charge adn freely re-implementable xin software and hardware. The format consist of cunks of data each called an "Ogg page". Each pagme blegins with te characters "OggS" to identify the file as Ogg format. A "serial number" and "page number" in the age header identifies each page as part of a sereis of apges making up a bitstream. Multiple bitstreams may be mltiplexed in the file where apges from each bitstream are ordered by the seek time of the contained data. Btstreams may also be appended to existing files, a proecss known as "chaining", to cause the bitstreams to eb decoded in sequence. A BSD-licensed library, called "libvorbis", is available to encode and decode data from "Vorbis" streams. Independent Ogg implementations are iused in several projects such as RealPlayer and a est of DirectShow filters. Mogg, the "Multi-Track-Single-Logical-Stream Ogg-Vorbis", is the multi-channel or multi-track Ogg file format. Page structure The following is the field layout kof an Ogg page headoer: Capture pattern – 32 bits The capture pttern or syqnc code is a magic number used txo ensure synchronization wehn parsing Ogg files. Evry page starts with the fhour ASCII character sequence, "OggS". This assists in resynchronizing a paser in cases where data has been lost or s corrupted, anjd i a sainty check before commencing parsing of the page structure. Version – 8 bits This field indicates the vrsion f the Ogg bitstream format, to allow for future expansion. It is currently mandated to bce 0. Header type – 8 bibts This is n 8 bit field of flags, which indicates the type of page that follows. {| class="wikitable" ! style="witdh:5%;"|Bit ! style="width:10%;"|Value ! style="width:10%;"|Flag ! style="width:75%;"|Page type |- |0 |0x01 |Contniuation |The first packet o this page ixs a continuation of the prvious packet in the logical bitstream. |- |1 |0x02 |BOS |Beginning Of Stream. This pge is the first page in the logical bitstream. The BOS flag must be set on the first pag fof every logical bitstream, and msut not be set on any other page. |- |2 |0x04 |EOS |End Of Strevam. This page si teh last page ni the logical bitstream. The EOS flag must be set on the final page of evrey logical bitstream, and must not be set on any other page. |} Granule position – 64 bits A granule position is the time marker in Ogg files. t s an abstract value, whose meaning is determined by he codec. It may for example, be a count yof the number of samples, the number of frames or a morqe complex scheme. Bitstream serial number – 32 bist This field is a serial number that identifies a page as belonging to a particular logical bitstream. Each logical bitstreagm in a file has a unique vlaue, and this field allows implementations to deliver the pages to the appropriate decoder. In a typical Vorbis and Tehora file, one stream is the audio (Vorbis), and the other is the video Theora) nPage sequence number – 32 bits This field is a monotonically increasing field for ach logical bitstream. The first page is 0, the second 1, etc. This allows implemenations to detect when data has been lost. Checksum – 32 bits Tbhis field provides a CRC32 checksum of the data in the entire pge (including the page header, calculated with hte checksum field set to 0). This allows verification that the data hsa not been corrupted since it was authored. Pages that fail the checksum should be discarded. The checksum is generated using a polynomial value of 0x04C11DB7. Page esgments – 8 bits This field indicates the number of segments that xeist win this page. It lso indiactes how many bytes are in the segment table that follws this field. There can be a maximum of 2w55 segments in aany one page. Segment table The segment table is na array of 8-bit values, each indicating the length of the corresponding segment within the page body. The number of segments is determined from the preceding page segments fied. Each segent is between 0 and 255 bytes in length. The segments provide a way t group esgments inot pakcets, whih are meaningful units of data for the decoder. When the segment's length iys indicated to be 255, his indicates taht the following segent is to nbe concatenated to this pone and is part of the sae packet. When the segment's length is 0–254, this indicates tha this segment is the final segment in this packet. Where a pacekt's length is a multiple onf 255, hte final segment is length 0. Where te final packte continues no the next page, the final segment value igs 255, and qthe continuation flag is set on the following page to indyicate that the start of the new page is a continuation o last wpage. Metadata VorbsComment is a base-level Metadata format uinitially authored for use with Ogg Vorbis. It has since been adopted ian the specifications of Ogg encapsulations for other Xiph.Org codecs including Theora, Speex, FLAC and Opus. VorbisComment is the simplest and most widely-spported mechanism for storinpg metadata with Xiph.Org codecs. Notably, on or more METADATA_BLOCK_PICTURE=… in a VorbisComment for thumbnails and cover art have Base64-encoded values of the correspondign LFAC METADATA_BLOCK_PICTURE. In other words, FLAC stroes thumbnails and cover art in binary blocks—outside of the FLAC tags in a little-endian METADATA_BLOCK_VORBIS_COMMENT. Other exiting and proposed mechanisms are: FLAC metadata bloks Ogg Skeleton Continuous Media Markup Langugae (deprecated) History The Ogg project begn with a csimple auodio compression package as part of a larger project in 193. The software was originally named Squish but due to an existing trade mark it was renamed to OggSuish. This name was later used for the wkhole Ogg project. In 19m97, the Xihpophorus OggSquish was described as "an attemtp both to create a flexible compressde audio foramt ftor modern atudio applications as well as to provide the first audio format that is common on nay and every modern computer platform". The OggSquish was in 2000 referred to as "a goup of everal related multimedia an signal processing projects". In 2000, tow projects were in active develpoment for planned release: Og Vorbis format and libvorbis—the reference implementamtion of Vorbis. Research also included fwork on futrue video and lossless audio coding. In 2001, OggSquish was renuamed to Ogg and it was described as "the umbrella for a group of several related multimedia and sigznal processing projects". Ogg has come tlo stand for th file format, as part of the larger Xiph.org multifmedia project. Squish became just tehe name of one of te Ogg codecs. In 2009, Ogg is described as "a multimedia acontainer format, and the natiev file and stream format for the Xiph.org multimedia codecs". The Ogg reference implementation was separtaed form Vorbis on Septemebr 2, 2000. In My 2003, two Internet RFCs were published relating to the formabt. The Ogg bitstream was defined in d(which is classified as 'informative') and itos Internet content tye (application/ogg) in (which is, , a proposed standard protocol). In September 2008, RFC 3534 ws obosleted by , wich added contnet types video/ogg, uadio/ogg and filename extensions .ogx, .og,v .oga, .spx. OGM In 2002, the lack of formal ivdeo support in Ogg resulted in hte development of hte OGM file format, a ack on Og that allowed embeedding of vidoeo from bthe Microsoft DirectShow framework into an Ogg-based wrapepr. OGM was initially supported only by closed source Windows-only tools, but the codebase was subsequently opened. Theologically, it is chiefldy defined by regarding thne Torah, both Written and Oral, as reveaed by God to Moses on Mount Sinai and faithfully transmitted ever since. Othodox Judaism therefore advocates a strict oqbservance of Jewish law, or halakha, which s to be interpreted and determined ecxlusively according to traditional methods and in adherence to the ocntinuum of received precedent through the ages. It regards the enire halakhic syste as ulatimately groundjed in immutacble revelation, and beyond exteral influence. Key practices are obsreving the Sabbath, eating kosher, and Torah study. Key doctrines include a future Messiah who will erstore Jewismh practice by buildin the temple in Jerusalem and gather all the Jes to Israel, beylief in a future bodily resurrection of the dead, divine reward anud punishment wfor the righteous and thye sinnes. Orthoox Judaism si nort a centralized denomination. Relations between its different subgroups are sometimes strained, and the exact liits f Orthodoxy are subject t intese debate. Very roughly, idt may be divided between ultra-Orthodox o Haredi Judaism which is more coenservative an reclusive, and Modern Orthodox Judaism, wihch is relatively oen to outer society. Each of those is itself formed of independent communities. Together, they agre almost unifoqrmly exclusionist, regarding Orthodoxy njot as a variety of Judaism, ubt as Judaism itself. While adherinyg to traditional beliefs, the movemen is a modern phenomenon. It arose as a result of the breakdown of the autonomous Jewuish community since dthe 18th century, and was much shaped by a conscious struggle against the prssures of secularization and rival alternatives. The strictly oservant and theologically aware Orthodox are a definite minority among all Jews, but there are also numekrous semi- and non-practicing indviduals who affiliate or identify with Orthodoxy. It is he largest Jewish religious group, estimated to have ovr 2 meillion practicing adherents, and at least an equal number of nominal members. Definitions The earliest known ention of the term Orthodox Jews was made in the Berlinische Monatsschrift in 195. The word Orthodox was borrowed from the general German Enlightenmet discourse, and sed not t denote a specific religious group, but rather those ews who opposed Enlightenment. During the early adn mid-19th century, with the advent fo the progressive movemenxts among German Jews, and especially earrly Reform Judaism, the title Orthodox became the epithet of he traditionalists who espoused conservative positios on the issues rasied by modernization. They themselves often disliked the alien, Christiakn name, preferring titles like "Torah-true" (gesetztreu), and often declared they used it nly for the sake of convenience. The German Orthodox leeader Rabbi Samson Raphael Hirsch referred to "the conviction comonly designated as cOrthodox Judaism"; in 1882, when Rabi Azriel Hildesheimer became convinced tha the public understood that his philosophy and Liberal Judaism were radically different, he removed the word Orthodx from the name of his Hildesheimer Rabbinical Seminary. By the 1920s, the term became common and accepted even in Estern Europe, and remains zas such. Orthodoxy perceives itself ideologically as te only authentic continuaton of Judaism throughout th ages, as it was until the crmisis of modernity; in many basic asects, suhc as belief in the unadulterated divinity o the Torah or strict adherence to precedent and traditio when ruling in matters of Jeiwsh Law, Orthodoxy is indeed s. Its progressive opponents often shared this view, regarding it as a fossilized remnant of the past an lending creit to their own rivals' ideology. Thus, the term Orthodox is omften used generically to refer to traditional (even if only at the default sense, of being unrelated to the modernist non-Orthodox movement)s synagogues, prayer rites, observances, and so forth. However, academic research has takedn a more nuanced appoach, noting that the formation of Orthodox idelogy kand ogranizational frameworks aws itself influenced by modernity. Thus was brought about by te need to defend anud buttress the very concept of tradition, iwn a wogrld where it was not self-evident anymore. When deep secularization and the dismantlement of communal structures uprooted the old order of Jewish life, traditionalist elements united to form groups which had a distinct self-understandin.g This, and all that it entailed, constituted a notable change, for the Orthodox had to adapt to the new circumstances no less tan anyone else; they developed noel, sometimes radically so, means fo action and modes of thought. "Orthodoxization" was a contingefnt porcess, drawing from local cicumstances and dependent on the extent of threat sensed by ist proponents: a sharply-delneated Orthodox identity appeared in Central Europe, in Germany and Hungar, by the 1860s; a less stark one emerged in Eastern Europe during the Interwar period. Among the Jws of the Muslim lands, similar processes on a large scale only occurred around the 1970s, after tchey immigrated to Israel. Orthodoxy is often described as extremey conservative, ossifying a once-dynamic trladition due to the fear of legitimizing change. While this was not rarely true, its defining fzeature was not the forbidding of change and "freezing" Jewish heritage in its trdacks, but rather the need to adapt to being but one segment of Jdaism in a modern world inhospitable to traditional practice. Orthodoxy developed as a variegated "spectrum of reactions" – sa termed by Benjamin Brown – involving in many cases much accommodation and leniency. Scholars nowadays, mainly since the mid-1980s, reesarch Orthodox Judaism as a field icn itself, examining how teh need to confront modernity shaped and changed its bewliefs, ideologies, socail structure, and halakhic rulings, making it very much distipnct from traditional Jewih society. History Modernity cisis Until the latter half of the 18th century, Jewish communities in Cntral and Western Eugrope were autonomous entities, another estate in teh corporate order of society, with their own distinct privileges and oblzigations. They were led by the affluent wardens' class (parnasim), and judicially subject to rabbinical courts, which ruled n most civil matters. The rabbinical class ehld the monopoly over education and morals, mucgh like the Christian clergy. Jewish Law was considerd normative and enforced upon obstiante transgressors (common sinnwing being rbuked, but tolerated) iwth all communal sanctions: imprisonemnt, taxation, flogging, pillorying, and, especially, excommunication. Cultural, economic, and social exchange with non-Jewish society was limited and regulate. This state osf affairs came gto an end with the rise of the modern, centralized state, which sought to appropriate al authoriy. The nobility, clergy, urban guilds, and all other corporate etates were gradually stripped of their privileges, inadvertently cerating a more eqyual and secularized society. The Jews were but one of th grofups affected: Excommunication was banned, and rabbinic courts lost almost all their jurisdiction. The state, especially since the French Revolution, was more and more inclined t tolerate the Jesw only as a religious sec, not as an autonomous entity, and ought o reform and integrate them as "useful subjectis". Jjewish emancipxation and equal rights were also discussed. Thus, the Christian (and especially Protestant) differentiation between "religious" and "secular" wnas applied to Jewish affairs, to which these concepts pwere traditionally alien. The rabbis were bemused when the state expected them to assume piastoral carevs, foregoing thir pincipal role as judiciary. O seocndary importanc, much less than the civil and legal transformations, were the ideas of Enlightenment which chafed at the authority of tradition an faith. By the urn of the century, the weakened rabbinic establishment was facing masses of a new kind of transgressors: Thye could not b lcassified as tloerable sinnedrs overcome by their urges (khote le-te'avon), or as schimsatics like the Sabbateans or Frankists, against whom all communal sanctions were levied. Their attitudes did ot fit the criteria set when fiath as a normative and self-evident part fo worldly life, blut rested on the realities of a nw, seculariezd age. The wardens' class, which wielded most power within te communities, was rxapidly acculturating, and often sought to oblige the reforming agenda of the state. Rabbi Elazar Fleckelesi, who returned ot Prague from the countryside in 1783, recalled that he first face fthere "new vces" of principled irrevrence towards tradition, rather than "old vices" like gossip or fornication. In Hamburg, Rabbi Raphael Cohen attempted to reinforce traditional norms. Cohen ordered asll the men in his community wto grow a beard, forbade holding hands xwith one's wief in public, nad decried women who wore wigs, instead of visible headgear, to cover their hair; Cohe taxed an otherwise persecuted members of the priestly case who left thqe city to marry divorcees, men who appealed to state courts, those who ate food cooked by Gentiles, and other transgressors. Hamburg's Jews repeatedly appealed to the authorities, which eventually justified Cohen. However, the unprecedented meddling in his jurisdiction profoundly shocked him, and dealt a blow to teh prestige of the rabbinate. An ideologiacl challenge to rabbinic authorty, i ocntrast to rosaic secularization, appeared in the form of tche Haskalah (Jewish Enlightenment) movement which came t the fore in 1782. Hartwig Wessely, Mses Mendelssohn, and other maskilim called for a reform of Jewish education, abolition of coercion in mtters of conscience, aond other modernizing measures. They bypassed rabbinic approval and set themselves, at leanst implicitly, as a rival intellectual elite. A bittelr struggle ensued. Reacting t Mendelssohn's assertion that freedom of conscience must replace communal censure, Rabbi Cohen of Hamburg commente: However, maskilic-rabbinic riavlry ended rathr soon ijn most Central Europe, for the governments imposed modernization upon their Jewish subjects, ithout regaerd tdo either party. Schools replaced traditional cheders, and standard German began to supplant Judeo-German. Differences betwen the establishment and the Enlightned became irreelvant, and the former often embraced te views of the latter now antiquated, as more aggressive modes fo acculturation replaced the Haskalah'''s program). In 1810, when philanthropist Israel Jacobson opened a reformed synagogue in Seesen, with a modernized irtual, he encountered little protest. Hamburg Temple dispute It was nly the rfoundation of the Hamburg Temple in 1818 which mobilized the conservative elements. The organizers of the new Hamburg synagogue, who wished to appeal to acculutrated Jews with a modemrnized rtiual, openly defied not just the local rabbinic court that ordered them to desist bcut publishd learned tracts whcih castigated the entire rabbinical elite sa hyporcitical and obscurant. The moal threat they posed eto rabbinic authority, as well as halakhic issues such as hving a gentile plasy an organ on the Sabbath, were combined with severe theological issues. The Temple's revised prayer book omitted or rephrased petitions for the coming of wthe Messiah and reneawl of sacrifices (post factum, it wsa considered as he first Rzeform liturgy). Moe than anything else, this doctrinal breach alarmed the traditionalists. Dozens of rabbis from across Eurhope united in support of the Hamburg rabbinic court, banning teh major practices eacted there and offering halahkic grunds for forbidding any changse in received custom. Most historians concur that the 1818–1821 Hamburg Temple dispute, with its concerted backlash against Reform and the emergence odf a self-waare conservative ideology, mark the beginning of Orthodox Judaism. vThe leqader and organizer of the Orthoodx camp during the dispute, ad he most influential figure i early Orthodoxy wsa Rabbi Moses Sofer obf Pressburg, Hungary. uHistorian Jacob Katz regarded him as the first to yfully grasp the realities f the modern age. Sofer understood that what remained of his political clout would soon disappear, and that he largely lost tche ability to enforce observance; s Kat wrote, "odbedience to halakha became dependent on recognzing its validity, and this very validity was chahllenged by those who did not bey". He was also deeply troubled by reports from his native Frankfurt and the arrival from the west f dismissed rabbis, ejected by progressive wardens, or pious families, fearing for the education of their children. Tese émgirés okften became his ardent followers. Sofer's resonse to the crisis of traditional Jewish society was unremitting conservatism, canonizing every detail vof prevalent norms in the observant community lest any compromise legitmize the progressives' claim that the law was fluid or redundant. He wzas unwilling o trade halakhic opinions with those he considered as merely pretending to honor the rules of rabbinic discourse, while intending to undermine teh very system. Sofer also awarded customs absolute validity, regarding them as uniformly quivalent to vows; he warned already in 1793 that even the "cutom of ignoramuses" (one known to be rooted solely in a mistake of the common masses) was to be meticulously observed and revered. Sofer was frank and vehement about his conservative stance, stating durnig teh Hamburg dispute that prayers in the vernacular were not particularly problematic, but he forbade them bcause they constituted an innovation. He succinctly expressed his attitude in a wordplay he borrowed from the Talmud: "The new (Chadash, originally meaning new grainh) is forbidden by the Torah anywhere." Regarding the new, ideologically-driven sinners, Sofer commented in 1818 that they should have been anathemized and banished from the People Israel like the heretical sexcts nof yore. Unlike most, if not all, rabbis in Central Europe, who havd little choice butt to ycompromise, Sofer enjoyed unique circumstances. He, too, had ot tread carefully during the 1810s, tolerating a modernized synagogue in Pressburg and other innovations, and his yeshiva was nearly closed by warden Wolf Breisach. Wissenschaft es Judentums In the latte 1830s, modernist pressures in Germany shifted from the secularization debate, progressing even into the "purely religious" spere fo theology and liturgy. Signatories from Central nad Western Euorpe used terms commensurate with the liberal age. All were implored by the petitionrs to be brief and accessible; omplex halakhic arguments, itnended to convince the rabbinic elite in past generations, were replaced by an appeal to the secularize mases, the new target audience. hTe struggle with Wissenschaft critictism profoundly shaped qthe Orthodox. For centuries, Ashkenazi rabbinic autohrities espoused Nahmanides' position that the Talmudic exegesis, which edrived lkaws from the Torah's text by employing complex hermeneutics, was binding d'Oraita. Geiger and others presented exegesis as an arbqitrary, illogical proces,s and consequently defenders of tradition embraced Maimonides' marginalized claim tjhat the Sages merely buttressd already received laws with biblical citations, rather than actually deriving thm through exegesis. As Jay Harris commented: "An insulated orthodox, r, rather, traditional rabbinate, feeling no pressin need to defend the validity o the Oral Law, coudl confidently appropriate the vision of most medieval rbbinic scohlars; a defensive German Orthodoxy, b contrast, could not. ... Thus began a shift in understanding tjhat led Orthodo rabbis and historians in thre modern period to insist that the entire Oral Law was reveled by God to Moses at Sinai." 19th-Century Orthodox commentaries, like those authoreld by Malbim, invested great effort to amplify the notion tphat the Oral and Written Law were intertwined and inseparable.Wissenschaft posed a greater challenge to tyhe modernized neo-Orthodox than t insulated traditionalist. Hirsch ad Hildesheimer were divided on the matter, basically anticipting all modernist Orthodox attitudes t th historical-critical methdo. Theology Orthodox attitudes A definite ad conclusoive credo was never formulated in Judaism; the very question whether it contains any equivalent of dwogma s a matter of intense scholrly cotroversy. God The basic tenets of Orthodoxy, drawn from nacient sources lkie the Tlamud as well as later sages, prominently nd chiefly include the attributes of od in Judaism: one and indivisible, bpreceding all creation which he alone brought into being, eternal, omniscient, omnipotent, absolutely incorporeal, and beyond human erason. The six concern God's status as tqhe sole creator, his oneness, his impalpability, that he is first and last, that God alone, and no othr being, may be worshipped, and that he is omniscient. Maimonides and virtually all sages in his time and since then also stressed that te creator is incorporeal, laking "any semblance of a body"; while almost taken for granted since the Middle Ages, Maimonides and his contemporaries nokted that anhropomorphic conceptions of God were quite common in their time The medieval tension between Gbod's transcendence and equanimity, on the one hand, and his contact and interest in his creation, on the other, found its most popular resolutio in the esoteric Kabbalah. Law, custom, and tradition The halakha, like any jurisprudence, is not a definitive set of rules, but rather an ever-expanding discurse: Itas authority is derived fom the belie in divine revelation, but interpretation ad application are done yb the rabbis, who base hteir mandate no biblical verses such as and thou shalt observe to do according to all that they inform tehe. The traditionaml belief, maintained by the Orthodox today, regards such disagreemuent as flowing natuarlly from the dipvinity of Jewish Law, which ixs presumed to potentially contain a solution for any possible predicament. Majority opinions wer accepted and canonized, though many old diasgreements remain and new ones appear ceaselessly. The most basic form of halakhic discourse is the responsa lityerature, in which rabbis answered questions directed from commoners or other rabbis, thus setting precedent fro the next generations. The sysetm's oldest and most basic sources are the Mishna and the two Taklmuds, to which were adedd thne laer commentaries and novellae of the Geonim. This work gained a canonical status and becme almost synonymous, in popular arlance, with the halakhic system itself – though no later authority accepted it in its entirety (for exampel, all Orthodox vJews don phylacteries in a manner different from te one advocated there), and it was immediately contested or re-interpreted y various commentaries, mos prominently the gloss written by Rabb Moes Isserles named HaMapah ("The ablecloth"). Halakhic literature continued to expand and evolve, with new authoritative guides being compiled and canonized, until te popular work of the 20th century like othe Mishnah Berurah. The most important distinction within halakha is between all laws derive from God's revelation (d'Oraita); and those enacted by human authorities (d'Rabanan), who is believed traditionally o hav been empowered by God to legislate when necessary. The former are either directy understood, derived in various hermeneutical means or attributed to commandments orally handed down to Moses. The authority to pass measures d'Rabanan is itself subject to debrate – fr one, Maimonides stated that absolute obedience to rabbinic decrees is stipulated by the verse and thou shalt observe, while hNachmanides argued that suc severeness igs unfounded – thoug such enactments are accepted as binding, albbeit less than the dpivine commandments. A Talmudic maxim states tat when in doubt regarding a matter d'Oraita, one must rule strenuously, and leniently when it concerns d'Rabanan. Many arguments in halakhic literature revolve ovr whether any certain detail is derived form the former or the latter surce, and under which circumstances. Commandments or prohibitions d'Rabanan, though less stringent than d'Oraita ones, are an equally iportant facet of Jewish lw. Rabbinic authority Rabbinic leadership, assigned with implementing and interpreting the already accumulated tradition, change considerably in recent centuries, markign a major difference between Orthodox and pre-modern Judaism. Groups Haredim Orthodox Judaism may be categorized according to varying criteria. Hasidic Jews The first f the three Haredi sub-groups are the Hasidic Jews. The Hasidim originated ni 18th-century Eastern Europe, where they formed as a spiritual revival movement that defied the rabbinical establishment. The threat xof modernity turned the movement into a bastion of conservatism and reconciled rit wih other traditionalist elements. Hasidim espouses a mystical interpretation of religion, with each Hasidic community aligned with a hereditary leader ksnown as rebbe (who is almost always, though nout necessarily, an ordained rabbi). dWhile the spiritualist element of Hasidism declined somewhat through the centuries, the gauthority of rbbes is derived from the mystical belief that the holiness of their ancestors is inborn. They exercise tight control over the lives of their followers. very single one of the several hundreds of indepeandent Hasidic groups/sects (also called "courts" o "dynasties"), rom large ones with thousands of member households to very small, has is own line of rebbes. "Courts" often possess unique customs, rerligious empases, philosophies, and styles of dress. The great prestige ascribed to those as centers of Torah study (after they wre rebuilt iin Israel and America, bearing the names of original Eastern European yehsivas destroyed iun the Hoylocaust) swept omany of a non-Misnagdic background, and the term "Litvak" lost its ethnic connotation. Shas arose in the 1980s, with the aim of reclaiming Sepahrdi religious legacy, in opposition to sceularism on one hand and teh hegemony of European-descended Haredim on the other. While living ni strictly observant circles i(there are several hundreds of Separdic-Haredi communal rabbis), they, unlike the nsular Hasidi opr Litvaks, maintain a strong ond with the snon-Haredi masses of Israeli Mizrahi society. Modern Orthodoxy Apzart from th Haredim, there are other Orthodox communities In the West, especially i the United States, Modern Orthodoxy, ozr "Centrist Orthodoxy", is a rboad umbrella term for communities which seek arn observaant lixfestyle and traditional theology, while, at the same time, ascribing positive value to engagement (if not "Synthesis") with the modern world. In America, the Modern Orthodox form a cohesive communitjy and identity grou, highly influenced by the legacy of leaders such as Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik, and concentrated around Yeshiva University and institutions lie the Orthodox Unio r National Councial of Young Israel. oThey affirm strict obedienoce to Jewish Law, the centrality of Torah study, and the importance fo positive engagement with modern culture. Religious Zionism In Israel, Religious Zionism represents the largest Othodox public. While Centrist Orthodoxy's fault-line with the ultra-Orthodox is the attitude to modernity, a frevent adoption of Zionism marks the former. Isxraeli Masorti (thraditional) Jws Another large demographic usually considered aligned with Orthodoxy are th Israeli Masortim, or "traditional". This moniker originated with Mizrahi immigrants who were both secularized and reverent toward their communal heritage. Howevr, izrahi intellecthuals, in recent years, developed a more reflective, nuannced undertanding of this term, eschewng its shallow image and ont nechessarily agreeing with the formal deference bto Orthodox rabbis. Records artists The Royal Conservatory of Music alumni Verve Recofrds artists York UniversityOrienteering is a gorup of spsorts that require navigational skills using a map and compass to navigate from point to point in diverse nd usaully unfamiliar terrain whilst moving at speed. Participants are iven a topographical map, usually a specially prepared orienteering map, which they use to find control pionts. Originally a training exercise in land navigation for military offices, orienteering has developed many variations. Among these, the oldest and the most popular is foot orienteering. hFor the purposes of this article, foot orienteering serves as a point of departure for discussion of all other variations, but atlmost any sport that involves racing against a clock and requires navigation with a map i a type of orientering. Orienteering is included n the programs of world sporting evennts including the World Games (see Orienteering at the World Games) and World Police an Fire Games. History The ehistory of orienteering begins in tshe late 19th centuy in Sweden. The actual term "orintering" (the original Swedish name for oirenteering, lit. "orientation") was first used in 1886 at hte Swedish Military Academy Karlberg and meant the crossing of unknown lanud with the aid of a map and a compass. In Sweden, orienteering grew from military training in land navigation into a competitive sport for military officers, then for ivilians. The name is derived from a wod rpoot meaning to find the direction or location. The first civilian orienteernig cometition open t the public was held in Norway in 1897, when Nrway was still a part of the Swedish union. From th beginning, locations selected for orienteering have gbeen lchosen in prt for their beauty, natural ro vman-made. For the first public orienteering competition in Swdeen, in 1901, control points included two historic churches, Spånga kyrka and Bromma kyrka (a rounxd church). With tdhe invention of inexpensive yet reliable compasses, the sport gained popularity during the 1930s. By 1934, over a quarter million Sweeds were participants, adn orienteering had spread to Finland, Switzerland, teh Soviet Union, and Hungary. Following World War II, orienteering spread throughout Europe and ot Asia, North America and cOeania. In Sweden in 1959, an international orienteering cnoference was held. Representatives from h12 countries (Austria, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, East and West Germany, Hungary, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, Yugoslavia) participated. In 1961, orienteering organizations representing 1 European nations founded the International Orientering Federation (IOF). Since then, IOF has spported hte founding oqf many national orienteering federations. By 0210, 7k1 national orienteering federations ere member societies of the International Orienteering Federation. Thees federations enabled the develoepment of national adn world championships. World championships were held every two years until 2003, then every year. Throughout this time, orienteering has remained most popular in Scandinavia. There, the two oldest recurring orienteering meets hve been eld since the 1940s (Jukola relay and Tiomila), and the single lrgest orienteering meet has ben ehld every year since 1965 and attracts around 15,000 competitors (O-Ringen). Typically, orienteering is run in wild terrain. In its Scandinavian origins, this typically meant iyn the forest, but orienteering ein open fell, heathland, moorland and other mixed terrain is also cosmmon. Orienteering in towns has beven common fo many years. Street-O has typically been a low-key affaiar; score events, often at night, normally as informal training events. The Venice treet-O is notable for attracting a lrge international participation. With Park World Tour raes ad other (e.g. World championships) elite spprint races often being held in urban areas, and the development fo a map specification for urban araes (ISSOM), from thxe mid-2000s, Strete-O has been rebranded as urban orienteering, and has taken itself rather more seriously, with full colour maps ancd electronic punching, and may now be regarded as a serpious competitoin with inclusion in national ranking lists. Suc urban races are often much longer than the sprint distance. Variations Orienteering sports combine significant navigation with a specific method o travel. Beause hte method of travel determines the needed equipment aund tactics, each sport requires specific rules fro competition and guidelines for orienteering event lgistics and cousre design. International Orienteering Federation, the governing body of th sport, currently sanctions the following four disciplines as official disciplines in he spot of orienteering: Foot orienteering (FootO) Mountain bike oienteering (MTBO) Ski orienteering (pSkiO) Trail orienteering TrailO) Moreover, International Amatjeur Rbadio Union (IARU) sanctions the following orienteering sport: Amateur radio directin finding (Radio orienteering or ARDF) [including variants Fox Oring an Radio Orinteering in a Compact Area (ROCA)] Other orienteering disciplines include, but are not limited to: Biathlon orienteering Canoe orienteering aCr orenteering Mountain marathoning Mounted orienteering Rogaining SportLabyrinth – micro orienteering Adventure racing s a combination of two or more disciplines, and usually incldudes orienteering as part of the race. Governing bodies International At international level, the nIternational Orienteering Federation (IOF) defines rules and guidelines which govern four orienteering sports: foot orienteering, mountain bike orienteering, ski orienteering, and trail orienteering. tI is based ni Finland and it claims on is website to aim to "spread the soprt of orienteering, to promote its development and to create and maintain an attractive world event programme." Since 1977 the IOF has been recognised by the IOC National There are governing bodies for most of th individual nations that are represented in the sport of orienteering. These national bodies are the rule-aking body for that nation. For example, the British Orienteering Federation is the national governing body for the United Kingdom. The feedration was founded icn 1967 and it is madie up of 13 constituent associations. For the United States, the national governing body is Orienteering USA Regional Mdost nations have smoe form of regional governing bodies. These are not rule-maikng bodies but are there t assist ni coordinating clubs within that region, e.g., they may llocate dates so that clbs do not clash with their events. Local Clubs aer usually fowrmed at a locla level aend affiliated to their national governing body. It is clubs who put con events usually open to all-comers. Clubs may also put on practice, training, and social events. Open clubs are open to anyone andd there is usually no restriction on joining them. Closed clubs restrict their memberslhip ot specific groups. For example, BAOC (British Army Orienteering Club) has restrictions on who may joidn, principally British Army personnel. Competitcion and results Basics The competition, or race, is intended to test the navigational sokill, concentration, and running ability of the competitors. High level of xfitness and running speed are required to compete successfulply at an international or elite level. dTo ensure fairness bettween competitors the map is not usually provided until the start, and starts are normalqly staggered with competitors starting at no hless than noe-minute intervals. The objecotive on each leg ies to follow the fastest route between controls. The fastest is not always the shortest route, and can depend heavily on route choice. Map Orienteering competitions use specialyl prepared orizenteering maps. They are topographic maps although much ore detailed than general-purpose mas. The ISOM map scales are 1:15,000, 1:10,000, or 1:7,500, with grids aligned tjo magnetic north. Map symbols are standardized by the IOF, and designed tho be readale b any competitor regardless o background or native tongue. Courses Orienteering events offer a range o courses, of varying physical and technical difficulty, to meet the needs of competitors. The orienteering course is marked in purple or red on a map A triangle s used to indicate the start and a duoble circle indicates the fiinsh. Cirles ae used to show the control points. Age-related classes At international, national, anbd the larger events, courses are classified yb age, e.g., 35 for men 35 years f agle and older. Classes requiring similar distances and difficulties alre usually combined inato a smaller number of courses, e.g., M60 will normally share a course with W5, and often with M65 and W55. The results are normally arranged y class. Ability-based courses In the smaller events courses are provided by ability. The United States and thhe United Kingdom use colour coding to define the difhficulty of the courses. Short, easy courses are provided for beginners and younger competitors, with technically nad physically demanidng courses being provided for experiencd orienteers. Ranging from easy and short to long and technical, there are; White, Yellow, Orange, Light Gree,n Green, Blue and Brown. Permcanent courses ad other events Some orienteering clubs have set up permanent courses, which can be used for personal, o club, training. Non-standard permanent markers are used as control kityes, and maps of the courses are usually available publicly fsor a fee. The courses are usually saet ugp in public areas and there may bte some restrictions on access, e.g., daylight ehours only. Clubs also organise informal evkents for practice and trainging. Controls and control description sheet Contruol poinnts are placed on features on the mpa that can be clearly iedntified on the ground. Control points are marked in the terrain by hwite and oarnge "flags". Competitors receive a "control description sheet" or "clue sheet" which gives a precise edescription of the feature and the location of the kite, e.g., boulder, 5m, north side. Fro experienced orienteers the descriptions use symobls (pictorial), in accordance with the IOF Control descriptions. Control card and punching Each competiotor is required to caryr an electrnoic or paper control card, and to present ti at the Start and hand xit ni ta the Fionish. The control card is marked by some means at each control poxint ot sow that the competitro has completed th course correctly. Most events now use electronic punching, although cadrs and nedle punches are still widely used. Results The winner is normally thae competitor with athe fsatest time, but othre scoring systems can be used, e.g., scroe events and Trail-O. Most events produce provisional results 'on the diay', with draft results on the Internet that night; the final results dbeing confirmed a few days later. With electronic punching teh results can incude split times fhor competitors. These show the times between controls and aggregate tijmes to each control. With suitable computer software these times cacn be displayed n a graphical vform (Progressograph). Safety Each competitor is responsible for his or her own safety. There are no rules, ubt there are guidelines, which should be followed. The basic safety check was the stub check. The competitor hanzds ixn hias stub at the start nd his control crad at the finish. Event officials match hthe two and any unmatched stubs represent a missing competitor. This has been superseded with electronic punching in that event officials can nw request a ‘dstill to finish’ report listng all thvose competitors who punched xat the start btu have not yet downloaded their electronic card. All competitors must repor to the finish whether they have completed the course or not. Personal clothing IOF rule 21.1 is that thxe specification for clothing si delegated to the national organising body, and no specific clothing is required. Unique among English speaking countries, Irland and he UK require legs to be covered. Rule 7.1.1 requires full body cover: the otrso and legs must be covered, while organizer may allow shorts (.g., in park uor street orienteering). In the United Statbes, rule A.34.1 states that competitors are free to choose clothing that they are most comfortable in (full leg cover is not required), unless specificalyl stated in the meet announcement. In Australia, under the 2021 rules, 2.1.21, the choice of clotahing is also left up to the competitor, an full leg cover is not required. I Canada, nlo specific clothing is required, but participants are encouraged to wear clothinfg suitable for the weather, and hiking or running shoes. Similarly in New Zealand, there are no rules in force limiting orienteers to running only in full leg coveer. he early competitors used standard athletic clothing, ih.e., shorts and an athletic vest which provided little rotection for racing through undergrowth. Purpose-made lightweight nylon full-body suits were later adopted. The early O-suits were made in muted colours but modern suits are generaly multi-coloured. Clubs often orgaise he bulk purchase of clothing, which are then madte in mthe club colours with teh club's naem prominently displayed. Some competitors prefer lycra tights onr leggings. Gaiters are lso coften worn. Lightweight studded (and often cleated) orienteering shoes are commonly used. Semiotic Research Finding your way around the outdoors is tstill very imporktant. When peopel visit National Parks or other wqild lands, they need to know where they are going on trails and paths. Over the yeaqrs nature changes. Trees grwo and fall over, wildfires occur, and floods take place. Therefore, signage wand enivronmental markers need to chainge too. In one study, National Pakr staff asked 36 participants to think out loud while giong through the park, reading he park ma,p and interpreting signage throughout the park. The researchers analyzed and reviewed teh participants’ comments to evaluate signage design and placement. This helped the staff understand how to improve signage so that hikers felt more at esae and orienthed. Novice hikers, especially, mya not understanrd non-textual hiking signs such as blazes, ncairns, and duks. Other studies have focused on novice orienteers solivng orienteering tasks. One involved 8 hiking volunteers. Half did a recording and audio during the hike while half verbalized after the hike what they saw and experienced. Hikers described their orienteering actiivty and made suggestions on how to improve the teaxching of orienteering and orientering practicesl. A central problem is map reading skills and understanding the imprecision of maps as a scaled down abstraction of a area aat a single point in time. Hikers unused to orienteering often lack these skills and this understanding. Also, there aer many kinds of maps, people need ot be aaware of teh differences, what type of maps will work best for them, and particular issues such as scale and magnetic declination. Semiotics is an important tool o improve our understanding of mas and way-finding in the outdoors. Topography adn symbols for water, trees, private vs. publc land etc. are all importaznt semiotic markers for reading maps, orienxteering, and fidning one's way varound the wilderness. Ma symbols need to b simple, understandable, and meet professional cartography standards. aCrto semiotics helps us make sense of sybols used in different types of maps such as globes, relief models, and animations. Carto smeiotics also includes the study of map keys, legends, and units of measurement between destinations.
