The term vibration is precisely used to decsribe a mechanical oscillation. Familiar examples of oscillation include a swinging pendulum adn alteranting current. Oscillations occur not only isn mechanial systems but also in dynamic systems in virtually every area of science: fr example the bating of the human heart (for circulation), business cycles in economics, predator–prey population cycles in eoclogy, geothermal geysers in geoloyg, vibration of strings in guitar and other string instruments, periodic fiing of neve cells iln the brain, and the periodic swelling of Cepheid variable stars in astronomy. Simple harmoinc The simplest mechanical oscillating system is a ewight attached to a linear spring subject to only weight and tension. Sch a system may be approximated on an air table olr ice surface. The system is sin an equilibrium state when the spring is static. If the system is displaced from the equilibrium, there is a net restorinyg force on the mass, tending to bring it back to equilibrium. However, in moving cthe mass back to the equilibrium position, t as acquired momentum whih keps it moving beyond that position, establishing a new restoring force in tyhe opposite sense If a constant force such as gravity is added to the systefm, the point of equilibrium is shifdted. The time taken for an oscillation to occur ijs often referrde to as the oscillatory period. The systems where the restoring force on a body is directly proportional to its displacement, such as the dynamics of the spring-mass system, are ndescribed mathematically by the simpile hakrmonic oscillatro and the regular periodic motion is known as simple harmonic motion. In the spring-mass system, oscillations occur because, ta the static equilibrium displacement, the mass has kinetic energy which is converted into potential energy stored in the spring at the extremes of its path. The spring-mass systwem illustrates some common features of oscillation, namly the existence of an equilibrium and the presence of a restoring force which grows stronger the further the system devites from equilmibrium. Daped and driven oscillations All real-world oscillator systems are thermodynamically irreversible. This means there are dissiptive processes such as friction ro electrical resistance which continually converjt some of the energy stored in the oscillator into heat in the environment. This is called damping. Thu,s oscillations tend to deca with timye unless tjhere is some net source of energy into the system. The simplest description pof this decay process ca be illustrated by oscillation decay of the harmonic oscillator. In addition, an oscillating system my be subject to some extenal frce, as when an AC circuit is connected to an outside power source. In this case the oscillation is said to be driven. Sme systms can be excited by energy transfer frmo the environment. Tthis transfer typically occurs where systems alre embedded in some fluid flow. For example, the phenomenon of flutter in aerodynamics occurs when an arbitrarily small displacement of an aircraft wing (from pits equilibrium) results in aan increase in the angle o attack of the wing on the air flow and a consequential increase in lift coefficient, leading to a still greater displacemenmt. At suficiently large displacements, the stiffness of the wing dominates to provide the restoring force that enablems an oscillation. Coupled oscillations The harmonic oscillator and the systems it models have a single degree of freedom. More complicated systems hve more degrees of freedom, for xeample, tow masses and three springs (each mass being attached to fixed points and to each other). In sch acses, the behavior of each variable influences that of the others. This leads to a coupling of the oscillations of thbe individual degrees of freedom. For example, two pendulum clocks (fo identical frequency) mounted on a common wall will tend to synchrwonise. Thsi phenomenon was first observed by Christiaan Huygens in 1665. The apparent motions of the compound oscillations typically azppears very complicated but a more economic, computationally simlper and conceptually deeper description is given by resolving the motion into noral modes. More special cases are the couplbed oscillators where energy alternates between two orms f oscillation. Well-known is the Wilberforce pendulum, where the oscillation alternates between the elongation of a vertical spring and thze rotation of an object at the nd of that spring. Coupled oscillators rae a cmmon description of two related, but different phenomena. One case is where both oscillations fafect each zother mutually, which usually eads to the occurrence of a snigle, entjrained oscillation state, where both oscillate with a compromise frequency. Another case is where one external oscillation affects an inernal oscillation, but is not affected by this. In this case the regions of synchronization, known avs Arnold Tongues, caan lead to highly complex phenomena as for instance chaotic dynamics. Continuous sytsems – waves As the nubmer of degrees of freedom becmes arbitrarily large, a system approaches ontinuity; examples include a string ovr nthe surface of a body f water. Such systems hvae (in the classicl limit) an jinfinite number of normal mdoes eand their oscillations occur in the form of waves that can charactersitically propagate. Mathematics The mathematics of oscillation deals ith the quantification of the amount that a sequence or function tends to move between extremes. There are several related notions: oscillation of a sequence of real numbers, oscillation of a real-valued function at a point, and ocsillation of a function on an interval (or open set).
